questions.text: A second-year general surgery resident, while studying the surgical anatomy for a laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair,  learns about the triangle of doom as an important surgical landmark. Which of the following is not a content of this triangle?
questions.solution:
The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the triangle of doom.

The triangle of doom is one of the important surgical landmarks in preperitoneal laparoscopic hernia repair. Staples and sutures in mesh hernioplasty should be avoided in this area to prevent injury to important structures such as the external iliac vessels and the femoral nerve.

The boundaries of the triangle of doom are:

  • Medially- ductus deferens
  • Laterally- gonadal vessels in the spermatic cord
  • Posteroinferiorly- peritoneal reflection
  • Apex- deep inguinal ring

The important contents of the triangle of Doom include:

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerve

Other important surgical landmarks in this region are the triangle of pain and the crown of death.

 (NOTE: Triangle of Doom and Triangle of Pain are adjacent to each other and hence share common boundaries. However, the femoral nerve and its course is through both the triangles giving different nerve innervations.)

The figure below shows the triangle of doom with its boundaries and contents-

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with the incidental finding of a  well-circumscribed and slightly hyperechoic mass lesion in the liver during a routine ultrasound. She is asymptomatic and the only history she gives is that of regular oral contraceptive use for the past 3 years. Which of the following points regarding her liver lesion is not true?

choices.text: It is found more commonly in women
It can rupture and cause intraperitoneal hemorrhage
There is no risk of malignant transformation
Lesions >5 cm should be surgically removed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young woman with a history of long-term oral contraceptive use and an incidental, asymptomatic liver lesion given here points to a diagnosis of hepatic adenoma. The statement that this lesion has no risk of malignant transformation is not true. 

Hepatic adenoma is a benign growth in an otherwise normal liver. It is more common in women of 25-50 years. The use of estrogen is a definite risk factor, whether with oral contraceptives or other sources.

It is mostly an incidental diagnosis in an asymptomatic patient, but some may present with right upper quadrant pain. The two possible complications associated with it are spontaneous rupture and malignant transformation. The risk of rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage can be up to 50% in some patients. The risk increases with the size of the tumor.

This lesion can be picked up by a routine ultrasound, which will show a well-circumscribed mass, often isoechoic in nature. Hemorrhage or necrosis would make it appear more hyperechoic. However, a CT scan is very useful in differentiating an adenoma from other common liver masses like focal nodular hyperplasia, which would show a hypodense stellate scar in the center of the mass.

In the event of spontaneous rupture, hepatic artery embolization can be carried out to stabilize the patient. Once stable, the patient should undergo surgical resection of the mass. In an asymptomatic patient, larger lesions (>5 cm) should be considered for removal because the risk of rupture increases significantly beyond 5 cm.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: Wilkie's syndrome is associated with which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Wilkie's syndrome is associated with the superior mesenteric artery.

Wilkie's syndrome, also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA), is an acquired disorder in which the third part of the duodenum gets compressed between the superior mesenteric artery anteriorly and the aorta posteriorly, as shown in the image below:


The normal angle between the SMA and aorta ranges from 25-60 degrees, with 45 degrees being the usual angle. A mesenteric fat pad is normally present between the SMA and the third part of the duodenum. In situations of rapid weight loss, abdominal surgery, etc, it is possible to lose this fat pad. This results in a narrowing of the above-mentioned angle. Patients begin to display symptoms when the angle falls below 20 degrees. 

The result is that the third part of the duodenum now gets compressed between these two vessels leading to obstructive symptoms. The common presentation is postprandial abdominal pain with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Repeated episodes of vomiting can result in dehydration. 

Diagnosis can be made with a barium meal and follow-through or abdominal CT scan.

The image below shows barium follow through with dilatation of the duodenum and an abrupt cut-off at its third part. The cut-off is coinciding with the expected location of the SMA, depicted by the red line in the x-ray:


The abdominal CT scan with contrast shown below depicts the reduced angle between the SMA and the abdominal aorta shown within the red circle-


This condition is first treated conservatively with gastric decompression, intake of smaller meals, and postural changes like knee-elbow position and left lateral decubitus position. Reversal of the cause such as regaining lost weight can also sometimes show good results. If conservative management fails, the operation of choice is a duodenojejunostomy.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of two pregnancy losses, both of which occurred in the second trimester. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management in this scenario is an ultrasound scan.

In this scenario of recurrent second-trimester abortions, cervical insufficiency has to be suspected as one of the main causes. Miscarriages due to cervical insufficiency are characterized by painless cervical dilatation and expulsion of the fetus.

According to the RCOG guidelines, women with a current singleton pregnancy and a previous history of 3 or more preterm births or second-trimester miscarriages are offered history-indicated cervical cerclage at 11 to 14 weeks of gestation.

However, before placing a history-indicated cerclage, patients are offered first-trimester ultrasound screening to ensure viability, and singleton pregnancy and to rule out major fetal anomalies.

Women with a singleton pregnancy and a previous history of one preterm birth or second-trimester miscarriage are offered serial ultrasound scans for the measurement of the cervical length and if the cervical length is less than 25mm at less than 24 gestational weeks, an ultrasound-indicated cervical cerclage may be done at 14 to 24 weeks of gestation.

In women with no prior history of preterm birth and incidentally found short cervix, progesterone therapy is preferred over cerclage. 

Causes of mid-trimester Spontaneous Pregnancy Losses:

Fetal Anomalies  Uterine Defects  Placental causes  Maternal Disorder 
Chromosomal aberrations Congenital anomalies Abruptio, Previa Autoimmune syndromes 
Structural abnormalities Leiomyomas  Defective spiral artery formation  Infections
  Incompetent cervix  Chorioamnionitis  Metabolic causes

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presented with the involuntary and impaired movement of his limbs. He also had speech difficulties and drooling. On examination, dystonia and hyperreflexia were noticed. Investigations revealed transaminases near the upper limit of normal and low ceruloplasmin levels. On examination of the eye, the following eye finding is seen on the anterior capsule. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image showing anterior capsular sunflower cataracts are suggestive of Wilson's disease.

Wilson's disease or hepatolenticular degeneration is a rare condition that involves the widespread deposition of copper in tissues. It occurs due to the deficiency of the major copper-carrying protein, ceruloplasmin. Patients with Wilson disease present with liver diseases, dysfunction of basal ganglia, or psychiatric disturbances. 

Anterior capsular sunflower cataract is seen in some of these patients. It is characterized by yellowish-brown dots. It occurs due to the deposition of copper oxide in the anterior lens capsule and subcapsular cortex in a stellate pattern. 

The majority of patients with neurological signs have a pathognomonic Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring which consists of a brownish-yellow zone of fine copper dusting in the peripheral Descemet membrane. The deposits are preferably distributed on the vertical meridian and the KF ring can be best detected in gonioscopy. The deposits may disappear with penicillamine therapy. It appears as shown below.

 

Zinc is the therapy of choice in patients with hepatitis or cirrhosis without hepatic decompensation. Trientine and zinc are used in patients with hepatic decompensation. 

Other options:

Option A- Chronic usage of miotics causes anterior subcapsular granular cataracts. It occurs particularly with long-acting cholinesterase inhibitors such as:

  • Echothiophate
  • Demecarium bromide
  • Diisopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP)

Cataract progression can be stopped or reversed by the removal of the drug. 

Option B- Lowe's syndrome or oculo-cerebral-renal syndrome is a rare inborn error of amino-acid metabolism. Patients usually present with congenital cataracts, glaucoma, and blue sclera. They also have intellectual disability, dwarfism, osteomalacia, muscular hypotonia, and frontal prominence.

Option C- Chronic topical or systemic corticosteroid usage causes posterior subcapsular cataracts. It is more susceptible in children than in adults.

questions.text: A middle-aged man noticed that his shoes no longer fit him, his finger ring is getting tighter, and his jaw seems protruded. The image below compares the size of his hand (right side) with that of the physician (left side). MRI of the brain shows a mass in the pituitary gland. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of acromegaly which can be managed by stereotactic ablation, pegvisomant and transsphenoidal tumor resection.

It is commonly caused due to growth hormone-secreting somatotroph adenoma. Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Other manifestations seen in GH excess are cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, etc.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. 

GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal surgical treatment is the preferred surgery. Stereotactic ablation of GH-secreting adenomas by gamma-knife radiotherapy has also been beneficial. Preoperatively, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used to shrink the size of the tumor. Another drug that is useful in acromegaly is pegvisomant. It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist and, therefore, antagonizes the actions of GH.

Other options:

Option C: Oglcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist. It is used for the treatment of migraine.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

The various types of pituitary tumors are listed in decreasing order of frequency:

Adenoma cell origin

Hormone

Clinical features

Lactotroph

Prolactin

Galactorrhea and amenorrhea (in females)

Sexual dysfunction, infertility

Gonadotroph

 FSH, LH subunits

Hypogonadism, mass effects, and hypopituitarism

Somatotroph 

GH

Gigantism (children)

Acromegaly (adults)

Corticotroph

Cushing's disease

Nelson's syndrome

Mammosomatotroph

Hypogonadism, galactorrhea, acromegaly

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibody binds to CD 52 and can be used in the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Alemtuzumab binds to CD 52 proteins which can be given for the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B-CLL).

CD52 protein is widely expressed on B cells, T cells, macrophages, NK cells, and some granulocytes. Alemtuzumab binding to CD52 induces antibody-dependent lysis of cells. It is mainly used for:

  • Immunosuppressive therapy in transplant procedures
  • Treatment of B-CLL
  • Treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis

The most common adverse effect seen with alemtuzumab is neutropenia.

Other options:

Option B- Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to the extracellular domain of HER-2/neu and downregulates its receptors. It is approved for the treatment with HER-2neu positive tumors in patients with breast cancer, metastatic gastric, or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma

Option C- Tocilizumab is a newer humanized antibody. It binds to the soluble, membrane-bound IL-6 receptors and inhibits IL-6 mediated signaling. IL-6 can cause T-cell activation, acute-phase protein synthesis, and stimulation of inflammatory processes. It is mainly indicated for rheumatoid arthritis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 

Option C- Adalimumab is a anti-TNF antibody. It is approved for the use of rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis, plaque psoriasis, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis.  

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: Which of the following is a dimorphic fungi?
questions.solution:
Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungi.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Some common examples of dimorphic fungi are:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Penicillosis marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum

Option A: Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that causes cryptococcosis. It is an oval, budding yeast with a prominent polysaccharide capsule, which is very apparent in India ink staining. It forms smooth, mucoid, cream-colored colonies on Sabouraud agar.

Option C: Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is a yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudohyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue. They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.

Option D: Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic pathogen that causes aspergillosis. It is a non-dimorphic mould with septate hyphae that branch at a V-shaped angle. It forms characteristic mycelium when cultured on Sabouraud’s agar.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
An anxious primigravida came to you for a second opinion with the report of a second-trimester scan and biochemical screening test suspecting Down syndrome. Which of the following are suggestive of Down syndrome?
  1. Hypoplasia of nasal bone
  2. Elevated levels of unconjugated estriol
  3. Sandal gap between first and second toes
  4. Reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  5. Low levels of beta HCG
questions.solution:
Hypoplasia of nasal bone, sandal gap between first and second toes, and reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (1, 3, and 4) are sonographic and biochemical features suggestive of Down's syndrome or Trisomy 21.

Soft signs or second-trimester sonographic markers associated with Down syndrome fetuses are:

  • Brachycephaly or shortened frontal lobe
  • Clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the 5th digit middle phalanx)
  • Flat facies
  • Echogenic bowel, echogenic intracardiac focus
  • Absence or hypoplasia of the nasal bone
  • Nuchal fold thickening
  • Sandal gap between first and second toes
  • Single transverse palmar crease
  • Single umbilical artery

A focal papillary muscle calcification that is neither a structural nor functional cardiac abnormality is called an echogenic intracardiac focus. Echogenic fetal bowel which appears as bright as the bone has a six-fold increased risk for Down syndrome. 

Two-thirds of fetuses with Down syndrome have an absence or hypoplasia of nasal bone. A prominent space between the first and second toes termed sandal-toe gap is also seen in intrauterine sonography of Down syndrome.

The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screening test for Down syndrome are:

 Biochemical screening test

Down syndrome

(Trisomy 21)
MSAFP Low
Unconjugated estriol Low
β hCG High 
Inhibin A High

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has enjoyed playing tennis since childhood. However, recently while playing with his son, he developed dizziness and vertigo-like symptoms along with cramping of his left arm after repeatedly serving the ball with the racket in his left hand. Which large vessel is likely to be stenosed in this man?
questions.solution:
The above scenario of a patient who developed arm cramping, dizziness, and vertigo-like symptoms on repetitive movements of his left arm is likely to have subclavian steal syndrome. 

In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the left subclavian artery is stenosed i.e. at a point proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery (shown in the image below). 

The stenosis depicted above will diminish blood supply to the left upper limb as well as the left vertebral artery. However, due to the presence of abundant collaterals in the circle of Willis the blood supply to the brain will remain unaffected.

The symptoms arise when the patient exercises the left upper limb leading to increased demand in blood supply. In an attempt to meet this demand, the direction of blood flow in the left vertebral artery reverses and the blood supply is derived from the contralateral vertebral artery. 

This reversal and “stealing” of blood from the contralateral vertebral artery results in diminished supply to the basilar artery and thus the brain. Hence the patient presents with symptoms of dizziness and syncopal episodes. Clinically, the affected upper limb will show feeble pulses.

The etiology of this stenosis is most commonly atherogenic and can be diagnosed by duplex ultrasound, CT or MR angiography.

It can be managed with angioplasty or surgical bypass of the occluded segment, although angioplasty with stenting is preferred.

questions.text: Which virus causes the cytopathic effect of cytoplasmic vacuolation?
questions.solution:
The cytopathic effect of cytoplasmic vacuolation is caused by the simian virus 40.

Many viruses modify the morphology of the cells in which they grow in culture. The cultures can be examined under a microscope to see certain changes. These changes are known as cytopathic effects. There are several viruses that cause these effects and are thus known as cytopathogenic viruses. These can be detected by light microscopy.

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

Morphological changes in the cells that are caused by viruses are known as cytopathic effects (CPE) and the viruses causing these CPEs are known as cytopathogenic viruses. These CPEs can be detected by a light microscope.

Type of cytopathic effect

Virus

Rapid crenation of cells and degeneration of the cells

Enterovirus

Syncytium/multinucleated giant cell formation

Measles, mumps, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

Discrete focal degeneration

Herpes virus

Large granular clumps resembling grapes

Adenovirus

Cytoplasmic vacuolation

Simian virus 40 (SV 40)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness. On further inquiry, you find out there is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used for the removal.

Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 

Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute - Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness

Chronic - Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids 

Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

Related Pearl: Food adulteration diseases

Food Adulterant Toxin Disease
Dal Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus) BOAA* Lathyrism
Oil Argemone mexicana (oil) Sanguinarine Epidemic dropsy
Millet Crotalaria seeds (Jhunjhunia) Pyrrolizidine alkaloids
(Hepatotoxic)		 Endemic ascites 
Bajra, wheat Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Ergotism

 * BOAA-Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding chaperone proteins is not true?

choices.text: They are also known as heat shock proteins
Most of them are associated with the ATPase enzyme
Some bind to hydrophilic parts of proteins to prevent early folding
Chaperonins form a barrel structure for unfolded proteins

questions.solution:
The statement 'some bind to hydrophilic parts of proteins to prevent early folding' - is not true.

Chaperone proteins actually bind to the hydrophobic parts of an unfolded protein to prevent early folding.

Chaperone proteins, also known as heat shock proteins, are special types of proteins that assist in protein folding in a few ways. One way is by binding to the hydrophobic parts of the elongating polypeptide chain and preventing them from folding until the process of protein synthesis is complete (e.g. Hsp 70). Another way is by chaperonin proteins, another type of chaperone protein, which forms a cage/barrel-like structure for unfolded proteins to get sequestered, providing time and suitable conditions to fold properly. (e.g. mitochondrial Hsp 60).

Most chaperone proteins are associated with an ATPase enzyme. This is because ATP hydrolysis is used extensively during the process of protein folding.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase enzyme. 

The addition of carbidopa to levodopa prevents peripheral decarboxylation of  levodopa. However, levodopa can now be methylated by catechol-O-methyl transferase and get inactivated. This is prevented by catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors tolcapone and entacapone. 

Parkinson's disease arises as a result of the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. Therefore the mainstay of treatment for this disease is to increase dopamine in this area.

Other options:

Option A- Amantadine is an antiviral agent. It is used in the prophylaxis and treatment of influenza A. It has antiparkinsonian activity. It alters dopamine release in the striatum, has anticholinergic properties, and blocks methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors. It can be used in mild disease, dose-related fluctuations, and dyskinesia.

Option B- Rotigotine is a dopamine receptor agonist. It acts on D1 and D2 receptors, whereas ropinirole and pramipexole act on the D2 and D3 receptors.  The duration of action of the DA agonists (8–24 h) is often longer than that of levodopa (6–8 h). They are effective in the treatment of patients who have developed on/off phenomena.

Option D- Selegiline and rasagiline are selective monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitors. Dopamine in the striatum is predominantly metabolized by the MAO-B enzyme. Inhibiting this enzyme will increase dopamine concentration in these neurons. They selectively and irreversibly inactivate MAO-B.

Note:

Other drugs used in parkinsonism are:

Levodopa is a prodrug. It crosses the blood-brain barrier. Levodopa is converted to dopamine by decarboxylation in dopaminergic neurons in the striatum. It significantly improves the signs and symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

An adverse effect of levodopa is the wearing-off phenomenon. After administrating levodopa, there is improvement in the symptoms for a period of 1–2 h, but rigidity and akinesia return rapidly after the effect of the drug reduces. Increasing the dose and frequency of administration can improve this phenomenon, but the patients often develop dyskinesia and excessive abnormal involuntary movements.

In the later stages of the disease, patients may fluctuate rapidly between being “off,” having no beneficial effects from their medications, and being “on” having some beneficial effects but along with side effects.

Levodopa, if administered alone will undergo decarboxylation by the decarboxylases present in the intestinal mucosa and other peripheral sites. This will lead to decreased concentration of the drug reaching the brain. In order to prevent this levodopa is always given with carbidopa. Carbidopa inhibits peripheral decarboxylase enzymes.  

Muscarinic receptor antagonists are used as adjuncts to dopamine therapy. Eg. trihexyphenidyl and benztropine. Diphenhydramine, an antihistamine is also used.

Apomorphine acts on D4 and mildly on D2, D3, and D5 receptors. It also has adrenergic action.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea for the past two days. He also reports having body pain, a runny nose, and teary eyes. On examination, his pupils are dilated and he frequently keeps yawning. On probing further, he reluctantly says that he uses recreational drugs. His blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg and his heart rate is 110. Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance therapy for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used for the maintenance of opioid (heroin) dependence as a substitute therapy because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Because of its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Treatment for opioid dependence

Maintainance phase: to decrease the severity of withdrawal symptoms.

  • Oral mu agonist: a safe substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • Long acting agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine reduce the withdrawal symptoms and anxiety
  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol): opioid agonists which reduce craving.

Relapse prevention phase:

  • Naltrexone: An opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects.

Other options:

Option A- Methylmorphine (codeine)is an opioid agonist used for the relief of severe chronic cancer pain and suppression of cough. 

Option C- Meperidine belongs to a class of opioid analgesics and is similar to morphine. It is used to treat moderate to severe pain. 

Option D- Methylphenidate is a stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except:
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. Palmar interossei do not attach to the middle finger and therefore it does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion of the middle finger. 

Palmar interossei are unipennate muscles originating from their own metacarpal bone. Their function is adduction. The middle finger does not need adduction and hence does not have palmar interossei.

Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles originating from the adjacent metacarpal bone. They attach to the middle three fingers on both sides and do not attach on the thumb and little finger. Their function is abduction. The thumb and little finger have other muscles for abduction.

The lateral 2 lumbricals are unipennate and medial 2 lumbricals are bipennate. Their function is flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints.

questions.text: An elderly patient who works in a mining industry presented to the physician with complaints of breathlessness which has increased for the past 3 months. The chest radiograph was done and it showed the presence of ground-glass appearance. Pulmonary function tests showed a decrease in the lung volumes and a normal FEV1/FVC. Which of the following curves in the graph denotes the lung compliance in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of asbestosis with a restrictive pattern in pulmonary function tests. Therefore, it is likely to show a decreased lung compliance which is depicted by curve 1 in the graph.

The extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure is called lung compliance. The total compliance of both lungs together in the normal adult averages about 200 ml of air/cm H2O transpulmonary pressure.

  • The curve is shifted downwards in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
Match the following sections of the Indian Penal Code with the appropriate provision:
IPC Section Provision
1. 304-B A. False certificate
2. 197 B. Exhibitionism
3. 294 C. Dowry Death
4. 193 D. Perjury
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D. 

IPC Section Provision
304-B Dowry death
197 False certificate
294 Exhibitionism
193 Perjury

IPC 304-B - This legal provision comes into effect when the death of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 10 years to life. 

IPC 197 deals with issuing or signing false certificates. Whosoever signs or issues a false certificate shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years.

IPC 294: Deals with obscene acts like exhibitionism where they obtain sexual gratification with intentional exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. It is punishable by imprisonment up to three months or a fine. 

IPC 193 deals with punishment for false evidence. A person who intentionally gives false evidence or produces fabricated evidence for it to be used in a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment up to 7 years, and also liable to a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with acanthocytes on peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
Anemia of renal disease is not associated with acanthocytes on peripheral smear. 

Anemia of renal disease primarily results from a deficient production of erythropoietin from the kidneys. The usual blood picture in these patients is normocytic normochromic anemia.

Acanthocytes, also known as spur cells, are red blood cells with a few spicules of varying sizes that project from their surface at irregular intervals as shown below:

 

Conditions with acanthocytes:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

Echinocytes or burr cells, on the other hand, are red blood cells with multiple projections from the membrane. These projections are smaller, more regularly spaced, with smoothly rounded crenulations, and much more uniform in shape and distribution when compared with acanthocytes.

Conditions with echinocytes:

  • Uremia in renal disease 
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artifact

questions.text:
Match the JVP tracings with the conditions seen.

a. Tricuspid stenosis

b. Tricuspid regurgitation

c. Atrial fibrillation

d. Cardiac tamponade

e. Atrioventricular block
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-e, 2-b, 3-d, 4- c.

Image 1 shows canon a waves which are seen in atrioventricular (AV) block and right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Image 2 shows accentuation of v wave and rapid y descent which is seen in tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Image 3 shows absent y descent which is seen in cardiac tamponade.

 

Image 4 shows an absence of a waves which is seen in atrial fibrillation.

 

The below image shows a prolonged y descent seen in tricuspid stenosis.

 

The below image shows rapid 'x' and 'y' descent as seen in constrictive pericarditis.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

Abnormality Conditions

Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A patient sustained a vertebral fracture. On examination, he had bilateral spastic paralysis and bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and a light touch below the level of the lesion. Tactile discrimination, vibratory and proprioceptive sensations were preserved. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is anterior cord syndrome.

Anterior cord syndrome results from ischemia of the anterior spinal artery, and predominantly affects the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord. This can be caused by cord contusion due to vertebral fracture, dislocation, or by a herniated intervertebral disc. The clinical features seen after the period of spinal shock are:

1. Bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion and muscular atrophy. This is caused by damage to neurons in the anterior grey columns and the anterior nerve roots of the same segment.

2. Bilateral spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion due to the involvement of anterior corticospinal tracts on both sides. The spasticity is produced by the interruption of tracts other than the corticospinal tracts.

3. Bilateral loss of pain, temperature, and light touch sensations below the level of the lesion due to anterior and lateral spinothalamic tract involvement on both sides.

4. Tactile discrimination and vibratory and proprioceptive sensations are preserved as the posterior white columns on both sides are intact.

Other options:

Option A: Complete cord transection results in complete loss of all sensation and voluntary movements below the level of the lesion.

  • The loss of tactile discrimination,  vibratory and proprioceptive sensations is due to bilateral destruction of the ascending tracts in the posterior white columns.
  • The loss of pain, temperature and light touch sensations is due to destruction of the lateral and anterior spinothalamic tracts.

Option B: Central cord syndrome occurs due to damage to the central region of the spinal cord. It commonly occurs due to cord compression between the vertebral body and a bulging ligamentum flavum.

  • There is bilateral lower motor neuron paralysis and muscular atrophy in the segment of the lesion.
  • Bilateral spasticity, loss of pain, temperature, light touch, and pressure sensations occur below the level of the lesion with characteristic sacral sparing. 
  • The lower limb fibers are less affected than the upper limb fibers.

Option D: Brown-Sequard syndrome results from hemisection of the spinal cord due to traumatic injuries. Clinical features include: 

  • Ipsilateral lower motor neuron paralysis in the segment of the lesion, muscular atrophy, an ipsilateral band of cutaneous anesthesia in the segment of the lesion
  • Ipsilateral loss of tactile discrimination and vibratory and proprioceptive sensations below the level of the lesion.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensations below the level of the lesion and contralateral incomplete loss of tactile sensation below the level of the lesion.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with diarrhea, high fever, chest pain, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pleural effusion and patchy pulmonary infiltrates. The gram staining of the pleural fluid showed the following organism. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli point towards the diagnosis of legionnaire's disease for which the drug of choice is azithromycin. 

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhoea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

Azithromycin is the drug of choice. Respiratory quinolones such as levofloxacin can also be used as alternatives to macrolides.

The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients. 

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.


B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are considered ineffective.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the sterilization device used in the image shown below?

choices.text: It has a failure rate of 40%.
It blocks the fallopian tube permanently.
It is inserted only under general anesthesia.

questions.solution:
The above image shows the hysteroscopic insertion of Essure into the fallopian tube. The true statement about Essure is that it blocks the fallopian tube permanently.

The Essure permanent birth-control device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol).

It is not effective immediately, and an alternate method of contraception has to be used for the first 3 months after this procedure. A hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed after 3 months of insertion to ensure the proper placement and total occlusion. A failure rate of 1–5% is seen with the Essure device. 

Disadvantages:

  • Requires hysteroscopy 
  • Need expertise and is expensive
  • Permanent method
  • Hysterosalpingogram required to confirm blockage
  • 3 months waiting period and needs temporary contraception
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

  • No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia

Related Pearl: Failure rate of contraceptives

Coitus interruptus 25

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the above image is acanthosis nigricans.

Acanthosis nigricans is a darkening of the skin of the intertriginous areas. The hyperpigmentation is generally velvety with poorly defined borders and thickening of the skin. 

It can be grossly classified into benign and malignant.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is associated with obesity or insulin resistance. It is common and mild in nature. 

Malignant acanthosis nigricans has a rapid onset and is characterized by symmetrical, hyperpigmented, rugose, velvety plaques. It affects the axillae and flexures, nape of the neck, and mucosal surfaces. If it occurs de novo and is associated with weight loss, malignancy should be suspected. Generalized pruritus and skin changes of tripe palms (acanthosis palmaris) are also associated with malignancy. 

In malignancy, tumor cells are believed to produce transforming growth factor-alpha or cytokines that activate insulin-like growth factors. Leser-Trelat sign is the presence of prominent acrochordon-like papillamatosis arising from the plaques. 

The most common site of neoplasm is the gastrointestinal tract. 

Acanthosis nigricans can only be treated by treating the underlying disease. In addition, treatment specific to acanthosis nigricans is done for aesthetic reasons. 

Medications like keratolytics, topical vitamin D, and melatonin can be used. Procedures like laser, dermabrasion, and chemical peels are also available. 

Other options: 

Option A - Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy with characteristic skin findings such as Gottron papules, Heliotrope rash, shawl sign, and V sign. The following image shows Gottron papules.

 

Option C - Pityriasis rosea is a papulosquamous disorder that is characterized by a herald patch followed by scaly oval patches on the trunk in a Christmas tree appearance. The following image shows the lesions of Pityriasis rosea. 

 

Option D - Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches on the face. The following image shows the pigmentation of melasma.

questions.text:
A newborn presenting with which of the following signs can be managed in a newborn stabilization unit (NBSU)?
  1. Respiratory rate of 60-70/min without grunting or retractions
  2. Sepsis who are hemodynamically stable
  3. Hypothermic who are hemodynamically unstable
  4. Jaundiced who requires phototherapy
questions.solution:
Newborns with signs mentioned in statements 1, 2, and 4 can be managed in NBSU. A hemodynamically unstable newborn should be transferred to a special newborn care unit.

Newborns that can be managed at NBSU:

  • Newborns with respiratory distress, having respiratory rates 60-70/min without grunting or retractions for observation and oxygen therapy
  • Newborns with gestational age less than 34 weeks, weight less than 1800 gms, for observation and assisted feeding
  • Newborns with hypothermia and hyperthermia who are hemodynamically stable 
  • Newborns who require phototherapy for jaundice
  • Newborns with sepsis and hemodynamically stable for antibiotic therapy

The IMNCI has set up SNCUs at district hospitals, stabilization units at CHCs, and newborn care corners at all facilities offering delivery facilities.  The facilities available at different levels of Newborn Care Centers are as follows:

  Newborn care corner Newborn stabilization unit Special newborn care units
Present in Delivery room of all centers and hospitals Within or close to the maternity ward, in CHCs and first referral units District hospitals and facilities with >3000 deliveries/ year
Admits Immediate care to all newborns Sick and LBW >1800 gms Sick and LBW< 1800 gms

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient visited the ophthalmologist for a regular ophthalmic check-up. He has no ocular complaints. His vision is 6/12 in both eyes. His ophthalmic finding is given below. Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing a circumferential greyish white corneal band with limbal sparing is suggestive of arcus lipoides/ arcus senilis/ Gerontoxon.

Arcus senilis (AS) is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition.

When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma.

  • Deposition begins at the superior and inferior aspects and progresses to encircle the entire peripheral cornea which is about 1 mm wide.
  • Peripheral border of this ring opacity is sharp while central border is diffuse.
  • The exterior border of AS and the limbus is separated by a clear zone of the cornea called the interval of Vogt (limbal sparing).

Other options:

Option A: The Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring is a dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in the Descemet membrane. It is classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 

The images given below show Kayser–Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract respectively seen in Wilson's disease.

Option C: Limbus sign is caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a milky precipitate at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.

Option D: Vogt’s white limbal girdle is a degenerative change seen frequently in elderly people. It appears as bilateral chalky white crescentric opacities in the interpalpebral area both nasally and temporally. Limbal sparing may or may not be there.

Note: Pseudo-gerontoxon is a greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS. It is seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:
  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine-mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cellular events that occurs during inflammation is as follows: Rolling, Cytokine-mediated integrin activation, Adhesion, Migration.

The recruitment of leucocytes to the site of inflammation is a multi-step process that is mediated by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines. This process can be divided into sequential phases:

  1. In the lumen: margination, rolling and adhesion to the endothelium occurs.
  2. Migration of the leucocytes across the endothelium and vessel wall
  3. Migration in the tissues towards a chemotactic stimulus.

The process of leucocyte recruitment is as follows:

  • Margination: Because of the dilation of the inflamed postcapillary venues, there is stasis of blood flow, and hence, more leucocytes assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface; this process of leucocyte redistribution is called margination.
  • Rolling: The slowed down leucocytes then sense the signals from the endothelium and start rolling on the vessel wall.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation: The attachment of leucocytes to the endothelial cells requires adhesion molecules that are activated by cytokines. The major families of proteins involved in adhesion and migration are selectins and integrins and their ligands.
  • Adhesions: The weak rolling interactions slow down the leucocytes and allow them to bind more firmly to the endothelium. Chemokines that were produced at the site of injury bind to the endothelial cell proteoglycans. These chemokines then bind to the rolling leucocytes and activate them. This, in turn, converts the ligands for β1 and β2 integrins, VLA-4, and LFA-1 present on the leucocytes to a high-affinity state.
  • This combination of cytokine-induced expression of integrin ligands on the endothelium and increased integrin affinity on the leucocytes leads to firm adhesion of leucocytes to the endothelium at the site of inflammation.
  • Leucocyte migration: This is the movement of leucocytes through the intact endothelium, called transmigration or diapedesis. This occurs in postcapillary venules. This migration occurs through the inter-endothelial gap towards the chemical concentration gradient created by the chemokines at the site of injury. This occurs with the help of adhesion molecules present in the intercellular junctions such as platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule (PECAM-1) or CD31. 

Related Pearl: Principal Mediators of Inflammation and Their Source

Mediator Source
Histamine Mast cells, basophils, platelets
Prostaglandins Mast cells, leukocytes
Leukotrienes Mast cells, leukocytes
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6) Macrophages, endothelial cells, mast cells
Chemokines Leukocytes, activated macrophages
Platelet-activating factor Leukocytes, mast cells
Complement Plasma (produced in liver)
Kinins Plasma (produced in liver)

Related Pearl: Various actions of Principal Mediators of Inflammation

Histamine Vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, endothelial activation
Prostaglandins Vasodilation, pain, fever
Leukotrienes Increased vascular permeability, chemotaxis, leukocyte adhesion, and activation
Cytokines (TNF, IL-1, IL-6)

Local: endothelial activation (expression of adhesion molecules).

Systemic: fever, metabolic abnormalities, hypotension (shock)
Chemokines Chemotaxis, leukocyte activation
Platelet-activating factor Vasoconstriction, Vasodilation (at low concentration), increased vascular permeability, leukocyte adhesion, chemotaxis, degranulation, oxidative burst
Complement Leukocyte chemotaxis and activation, direct target killing (membrane attack complex), vasodilation (mast cell stimulation)
Kinins Increased vascular permeability, smooth muscle contraction, vasodilation, pain

Note: Thromboxane A2 (TXA2) is a prostaglandin, which is a potent vasoconstrictor

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated after a difficult birth. A deformity is present in the left arm as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerve root is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing a claw hand with a supinated forearm and the flexed elbow is likely suggestive of Klumpke's palsy. The C8-T1 nerve roots are affected in this condition. 

Klumpke's palsy occurs following an injury to the 8th cervical nerve and the 1st thoracic nerve. It is commonly seen after deliveries involving excessive traction on the brachial plexus. It results in a paralyzed hand where the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and the ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are mainly affected.

Clinically, the baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There is a loss of intrinsic muscle power and reflexes in the hand. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

Immobilization and prevention of contractures form the mainstay of treatment in Klumpke's palsy.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Klumpke's palsy.

Narakas classification for babies delivered via cephalic presentation with brachial plexus injury is as follows: 

  • Group 1: C5/C6
  • Group 2: C5/C6/C7
  • Group 3: Entire plexus involved
  • Group 4: Entire plexus with Horner's sign

Other options: 

Option A: Median nerve palsy (C6 -T1) presentation depends on the level of the lesion. Low lesions present as impaired abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial 3 1/2 digits. High lesions will have the features of low lesions, but will also have paralysis of the radial wrist flexors and forearm pronator muscles. The hand will be held with the ulnar fingers flexed and the index straight (pointing index sign). 

Option B: In a total plexus injury, C5 - T1 are injured. Here, the baby's arm is flail and pale. There is paralysis of all the fingers and unilateral Horner's syndrome. 

Option D: C5 - C6 injury is seen in Erb's palsy. It is typically seen in overweight babies with shoulder dystocia at delivery. There is paralysis of the abductors, external rotators of the shoulder, and the supinators. The arm will be held to the side in internal rotation and pronation with loss of finger extension.

The following image shows the clinical presentation of Erb's palsy.

Related Pearl: Erb's and Klumpke's Palsies.

Features Erb's palsy Klumpke's Palsy
Causes

Undue separtion of head and shoulder. Upper plexus root involved. 

Eg.Shoulder dystocia at delivery, motor vehicle accidents

Hyperabduction of shoulder. Lower plexus root involved.

Eg. Difficult breech delivery, Holding on to something (e.g. a branch) during a fall, Cervical rib syndrome, Scalene syndrome
Nerves roots  C5 and C6 C8 and T1
Muscles involved

Deltoid, Supraspinatus - loss of abduction 

Infraspinatus - loss of lateral rotation 

Biceps brachii - loss of flexion and supination 

 All intrinsic muscles of the hand
Position of the upper limb/hand Policeman's tip/Waiter's tip/ Porter's tip position Claw hand
Sensory loss +/- Along the outer aspect of the arm Along the medial border of forearm and hand
ANS signs  Absent

Horner syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of ropivacaine compared to bupivacaine?
questions.solution:
The advantage of ropivacaine is that it is less cardiotoxic than bupivacaine. 

Ropivacaine is an S(-) enantiomer of bupivacaine. It was developed as a modification of bupivacaine to decrease cardiotoxicity. Ropivacaine is less cardiotoxic and has a higher safety profile than bupivacaine. It has a shorter duration of action and produces less motor block (Option D) than bupivacaine (i.e. more motor sparing than bupivacaine). Ropivacaine is less potent (Option A) than bupivacaine. 

Both ropivacaine and bupivacaine have similar profiles in terms of renal toxicity (Option B). They do not produce adverse renal effects. Dose adjustments in renal failure is also not required. Bupivacaine may even have a renal protective effect.

Ropivacaine can be used for infiltration anesthesia and central neuraxial blocks (both spinal and epidural).

Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic that is the most cardiotoxic among the local anesthetics. It blocks the sodium channels of the heart during systole. However, compared to lidocaine, it dissociates very slowly. Therefore, the heart remains blocked for a longer duration in diastole. This makes bupivacaine cardiotoxic.

Accidental intravascular injection of local anesthetic like bupivacaine results in bupivacaine-induced cardiotoxicity. If this occurs, basic life support followed by intralipid therapy is initiated. A rapid bolus of intralipid 20% IV (1.5 mL/kg) is administered without delay, followed by an infusion of 0.25 mL/kg/min. Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration, and cerebral bupivacaine concentration

Note:

Local anesthesia systemic toxicity (LAST) can also affect the central nervous system (CNS), which is more susceptible to local anesthetic action as compared to the cardiovascular system. Dizziness, tinnitus, and disorientation are the initial symptoms. Shivering, muscular twitching, and tremors follow. Finally, respiratory depression can lead to respiratory arrest.

questions.text: The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is prolonged in the deficiency of all of the following coagulation factors except
questions.solution:
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) measures the clotting time of plasma via the intrinsic pathway. Factor VII is a part of the extrinsic pathway. Hence, aPTT is not prolonged in factor VII deficiency. 

Causes of a prolonged aPTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of heparin
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII (since it is part of the extrinsic pathway), e.g. in hemophilia
  • aPTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency

Prothrombin time evaluates the extrinsic pathway. It measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin).

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs (vitamin K antagonists)
  • Liver disease, particularly obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Rarely, a previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency

Isolated prolonged prothrombin time occurs due to the deficiency of clotting factor VII.
