questions.text: A hysterectomy was performed on a 46-year-old multiparous woman who presented with menorrhagia. The images shown below are the transverse section and histology of the specimen. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Dyspareunia is never seen as a presenting complaint
MRI has no role in the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The gross specimen shows thickened myometrium with a spongy, trabeculated surface, with focal areas of hemorrhage. The histological specimen shows endometrial glands and the surrounding stroma within the uterine myometrium. These findings are suggestive of adenomyosis. Hysterectomy is the definitive management of adenomyosis. 

Adenomyosis is also known as endometriosis interna.  Prior curettage, prior uterine surgery, repeated childbirth, excess of estrogen, intake of tamoxifen (selective estrogen receptor modulator) are the main causes for adenomyosis. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years.

Patients with mainly preset with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Dyspareunia can also be present in 10 percent of cases. 

On abdominal examination, a hypogastric mass arising from the pelvis is felt. It usually does not exceed the size of a 14-week uterus. Pelvic examination reveals a uniformly enlarged uterus.

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) and MRI are the imaging modalities caused for diagnosis in which MRI is more specific for diagnosis. 

Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Levonorgestrel- releasing or danazol-loaded intrauterine devices can be used to improve menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea.

questions.text: The WHO grading of the condition shown in the image below is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows corneal ulceration (keratomalacia) - a late-stage feature of xerophthalmia. According to the WHO grading, it is graded as X3A.

Xerophthalmia(epithelial xerosis) refers to all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

WHO grading of xerophthalmia is:

  • XN - Night blindness
  • X1A - Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B - Bitot’s spots
  • X2 - Corneal xerosis
  • X3A - Keratomalacia involving < 1/3 of cornea
  • X3B - Keratomalacia involving > 1/3 of cornea
  • XS – Xerophthalmic scarring
  • XF – Xerophthalmic fundus – white spots uniformly on the fundus at the level of the optic disc 

The earliest clinical manifestation of xerophthalmia is night blindness or nyctalopia.

Management includes treatment of the corneal ulcer, oral vitamin A, and topical treatment with artificial tears. Topical antibiotics should be given if a secondary infection is present.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

Related Pearl: Vitamin-A supplementation & treatment of Vitamin-A deficiency

Vitamin A supplementation
Target group
6 to 11 months age
12 to 59 month of age (1yr to 5yr)
Dose
100,000 IU (oral)
200,000 IU (oral)
Frequency
Once
Every 4–6 months

 

Note: A total dose of 17 lakh IU given as per the following schedule:

  • 100,000 IU is given with measles vaccine at 9 months
  • 200,000 IU is given with DPT booster at 15–18 months
  • 200,000 IU is given every 6 months (till 5years of age)

 

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency
Age < 6 months 6-12 months > 1 year
Dose 50,000 IU 100,000 IU 200,000 IU

 

Note: Route of administration is oral, in the form of retinyl palmitate.

questions.text:
In a scenario of ophthalmia neonatorum, match the causative agent to the time of presentation:
Time of presentation Causative Agents 
1. Within 48 hrs A. Chlamydia
2. 48-72 hrs B. Herpes Simplex Virus
3. 5-7 days C. Neisseria gonorrhoeae
4. >1 week D. Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Time of presentation Causative Agents 
1. Within 48 hrs Neisseria gonorrhoeae, chemical
2. 48-72 hrs Staphylococcus aureus, 
Streptococcus pneumoniae
3. 5-7 days Herpes simplex virus
4. >1 week Chlamydia

 

Ophthalmia neonatorum is also known as neonatal conjunctivitis. It presents with a mucoid, mucopurulent, or purulent discharge from one or both eyes in the first month of life. It mostly occurs in newborns due to a maternal infection of the genital tract at the time of birth. Any discharge from a newborn's eyes is suspicious as tears are not secreted so early in life.  

The common causes are:

  • Chlamydia
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • Chemical conjunctivitis
  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Herpes simplex virus

As it is a preventable disease, prophylaxis is important. Any suspicious genital discharge during the antenatal period should be treated. Aseptic conditions should be maintained at birth. The newborn's closed eyelids should be cleaned with sterile cotton soaked in normal saline. 

If despite these measures, ophthalmia neonatorum still occurs, further treatment is guided by the responsible causative agents: 

Causative agent  Treatment

Chemical

Chemical - Wash eyes, apply erythromycin, and observe

Neisseria gonorrhoeae

  Ceftriaxone injection i.m., gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

Staphylococcus aureus
Streptococcus pneumoniae

 Neomycin-bacitracin eye ointment, gentamicin
Herpes simplex II Acyclovir 3% eye ointment, systemic acyclovir for systemic involvement
Chlamydia Erythromycin eye ointment, oral for systemic infection

questions.text:
An elderly woman was brought with worsening memory for the past 4 years. Recently she has been unable to carry out her daily chores and got lost at the supermarket. There is no evidence of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following are the main neurotransmitters involved in this condition?
  1. Glutamate
  2. Acetylcholine
  3. Norepinephrine
  4. GABA
  5. Dopamine
questions.solution:
The clinical stem is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. Among the given options, the neurotransmitters that are most often implicated in its pathogenesis are acetylcholine and norepinephrine.

Main neurotransmitters involved:

  • Degeneration of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert- Reduced acetylcholine
  • Degeneration of the locus coeruleus - Reduced norepinephrine
  • Degeneration of dorsal raphe -Reduced serotonin

Two other neurotransmitters implicated in the pathophysiology of Alzheimer's disease are somatostatin and corticotropin, whose levels are decreased.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly. It begins with memory impairment which later progresses to language and visuospatial deficits. Later, the patient has difficulty in keeping track of finances, following instructions, driving, shopping, and housekeeping. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.

Language deficits appear as impairment in naming, comprehension, and finally fluency. Visuospatial defects include difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock. Risk factors for the development of Alzheimer's disease include:

  • Age >70 years
  • Positive family history
  • Female gender
  • Apo ε4 allele
  • Diabetes (increase the risk threefold)
  • Hypertension
  • Elevated homocysteine and cholesterol levels
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, and red wine
  • Low levels of exercise
  • Down syndrome
  • Mutation in presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 genes

Protective factors are nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and Apo ε2. 

Treatment: Cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding the effective duration of insulin formulations
  1. The effective duration of glulisine is 3- 4 hours.
  2. The effective duration of degludec is 12- 20 hours.
  3. The effective duration of afrezza is 2- 3 hours.
  4. The effective duration of detemir is 24 - 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Only 1 and 3 are correct.

Insulin is the mainstay for the treatment of all patients with type 1 and many with type 2 diabetes. According to the effective duration of action, insulin can be broadly classified as short-acting, intermediate-acting, and long-acting insulins.

Short-acting insulin preparation includes regular human insulin and rapidly acting insulin analogs. Regular insulin has an effective period of 4-6 hours. Insulin analogs like lispro aspart and glulisine have an effective period of 3-4 hours.

Intermediate-acting insulin is the NPH (neutral protamine Hagedorn, or isophane) insulin which has an effective period of 10 - 16 hours.

Long-acting insulin is insulin detemir, glargine, and degludec. Their effective duration is:

  • Detemir: 12-20 hours
  • Glargine: 12-24 hours
  • Degludec: 24- 42 hours

Afrezza is an inhaled insulin with an effective period of 2-3 hours.

Related Pearl: Insulin Classification According to Duration of Action

Inhaled insulin (2-3 hours)

  • Afrezza 

Rapid acting (3-4 hours)

  • Aspart
  • Glulisine
  • Lispro

Short acting (6-8 hours)

  • Regular

Intermediate acting (10-16 hours)

  • NPH
  • Lente

Long acting (12-24 hours)

  • Detemir
  • Glargine
  • Degludec (24-42 hours)

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with fatigue, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Investigations revealed hemoglobin levels of 9 g/dL and orotic acid crystalluria. Peripheral blood smear showed a large number of hypochromic macrocytes. Other red cells were microcytic and hypochromic. Serum folate, B12 levels, and blood ammonia levels appeared normal. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia with orotic acid crystalluria is consistent with orotic aciduria, a disorder of pyrimidine metabolism.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities. Treatment includes, administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/partial gastrectomy, ileal resection, Crohn's disease
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

Other options:
Option (A): B12 metabolic defect is unlikely since B12 and folate levels are normal.
Option (B): Urea cycle defect is also unlikely because the blood ammonia levels are normal.
Option (C): Purine metabolism disorders include gouty arthritis, adenosine deaminase deficiency, and purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Morphological Classification of Anemias

 

Microcytic Hypochromic

(MCV <80 fl)

Normocytic Normochromic    

(MCV 80 - 100 fl)

Macrocytic Normochromic

(MCV >100 fl)

Iron deficiency anemia

Sideroblastic anemia

Thalassemia

Lead toxicity

Acute blood loss

Anemia of chronic disease

Anemia of renal disease

Hemolysis*

Bone marrow suppression

  • Aplastic anemia
  • Pure red cell aplasia

 

  

Megaloblastic:

Vitamin B12 deficiency

Folate deficiency

Thiamine deficiency

Drugs - Methotrexate, Zidovudine, hydroxyurea

Orotic aciduria

Alcohol use

Liver disease

Hypothyroidism

*Hemolysis can be associated with macrocytosis because of compensatory reticulocytosis. However, MCV can be normal depending on the degree of hemolysis.

Note: In Orotic Aciduria, peripheral blood smear shows Hypochromic megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows numerous cells of the type shown below. Which of the following cells could they most likely be?
questions.solution:
The silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows a triangular cell with a broad base, that is likely to be a pyramidal cell.

Pyramidal cells have a triangular shape, with a broad base from which a single axon and many basilar dendrites emerge. A single apical trunk usually projects from the apex. The apices of these cells orient towards the pial surface of the cortex.

Pyramidal cells of Betz are larger pyramidal cells seen in the precentral gyrus. They measure up to 120 μm.

Pyramidal cells are the most abundant type of cortical neurons. Their fibers give rise to the corticospinal tract. 

Nerve cells present in the cerebral cortex include:

  • Pyramidal cells
  • Stellate cells or granule cells
  • Fusiform cells
  • Horizontal cells of Cajal
  • Cells of Martinotti

Other options:

Options A and B: Purkinje cells and Golgi cells are found in the cerebellum. Purkinje cells have flask-shaped cell bodies with axons containing efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells are large, stellate cells lying in the granular layer of the cerebellum with dendrites that branch extensively and are located deep to the Purkinje cells. 

Option D: Glomus cells are neuroendocrine cells found in the carotid body. Like neurons, they too have dendritic processes and cytoplasm containing numerous membrane-bound granules.

questions.text: Over the last 3 months,  an adult man has experienced difficulty swallowing with a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat during meals, postprandial vomiting, and a burning sensation in his chest. His symptoms do not improve on taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). A histopathological sample from his upper GI endoscopy is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dysphagia, food impaction, non-responsiveness to PPI therapy, along with histopathology showing eosinophilic infiltrates, is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Adult patients with eosinophilic esophagitis present with impaction of food, dysphagia, vomiting, and symptoms of reflux. Eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected in patients with heartburn that does not improve with PPIs. Children with this condition present with nausea, vomiting, chest/abdominal pain, and intolerance/aversion to food.

These patients are usually atopic and may have associated conditions like atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or moderate peripheral eosinophilia.

The cardinal histological feature is large numbers of intraepithelial eosinophils. Abnormal squamous maturation is also apparent. Other features include eosinophilic microabscesses, eosinophils in superficial layers of squamous mucosa, and lamina propria fibrosis. The histopathological appearance is helpful in differentiating eosinophilic esophagitis from GERD, Crohn's, and other causes of esophagitis.

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis and is shown below-

 

Barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus-

 

Treatment includes dietary restrictions of food allergen and topical/systemic corticosteroids.

Other Options-

Option (B): Crohn's disease of the esophagus is considered in the differential diagnosis of esophagitis and histopathological examination is required to confirm the diagnosis. On microscopy, it shows abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium forming clusters of neutrophils called crypt abscesses. Mucosal architecture is distorted.

Option (C): Reflux esophagitis too can present with heartburn. However, these patients are responsive to PPI treatment (unlike the given scenario). Histopathology showing basal zone hyperplasia and elongation of lamina propria papillae are common. Chronic GERD leads to intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa which is known as Barrett's esophagus.

Option (D): Infectious esophagitis - The most common infectious etiology for esophagitis in debilitated and immunosuppressed patients are herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, and candida esophagitis. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and from the base of the ulcer in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

  • HSV causes punched out ulcers with cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies on microscopy.
  • CMV causes shallow ulcerations and characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions on microscopy.
  • Candidiasis, in its most advanced form, is characterized by the adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis now presents with weakness and loss of the bulk of thenar muscles and was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome. Which of the following structure is spared in this condition?
questions.solution:
Radial nerve is spared in carpal tunnel syndrome as it is not a content of carpal tunnel. 

10 structures pass through the carpal tunnel, most of which are flexor tendons (not the muscles themselves).

Carpal tunnel contents (10 structures): Also can be taken as 4 structures only if FDP and FDS are counted as 2 structures. 

  • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP-4 tendons).
  • Flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS-4 tendons).
  • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL-1 tendon).
  • Median nerve between tendons of FDP and FDS.

Carpal tunnel syndrome occurs due to the entrapment or compression of the median nerve as it traverses underneath the carpal tunnel to enter into the wrist. Patients usually present with pain associated with tingling and numbness involving the thumb, index and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger. The little finger is usually spared as it is innervated by the ulnar nerve. Tinel's sign and Phalen's test are seen on examining patients with carpal tunnel syndrome. A late sign of carpal tunnel syndrome is thenar atrophy as seen in this patient. 

Some conditions associated with carpal tunnel syndrome include the third trimester of pregnancy, people with repetitive trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, and cysts from the carpal joints. 

Management involves measures to remove any repetitive insults that cause symptoms, wrist splinting, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, steroid injection, etc. Surgical decompression is usually indicated in patients that do not improve.

Note: Ulnar nerve passes superficial to carpal tunnel

questions.text: Which of the following is not a late sign of death?
questions.solution:
Mummification, adipoceree and putrefaction are late signs of death whereas post-mortem lividity is an early sign of death. 

Rigor mortis is a state of stiffening of muscles with slight shortening of the fibers. It occurs during the stage of individual cell death.

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Skin discoloration and loss of elasticity
  • Eye changes
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis
  • Muscle flaccidity

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

questions.text: A patient complains of epigastric pain for over 6 months, not relieved by over-the-counter medications. An endoscopic gastric biopsy tissue showed curved, gram-negative rods that were oxidase-positive. It grows at 37 degrees celsius in microaerophilic conditions. What is the organism most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of peptic ulcer disease caused by Helicobacter pylori.

H. pylori is a gram-negative motile rod with lophotrichous flagella. It has a unique feature of the production of urease, which is helpful in diagnosis. The sole source of H. pylori is the human gastric mucus. Gastric antrum is the commonest site of colonization. Infection is confined to the gastric mucosa in the stomach or in areas of gastric metaplasia and heteroplasia in the duodenum. 

In some patients, H. pylori causes mild acute gastritis lasting for about two weeks. In others, it can cause peptic ulcer disease, which in later stages may lead to chronic atrophic gastritis. This is a risk factor for gastric malignancies like adenocarcinoma and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphomas. 

Diagnosis can be made by performing a biopsy. A piece of biopsy material is added to a urease indicator medium which will show a positive result within minutes inside the endoscopy room. Part of the biopsy material is sent for microscopy and culture. On microscopy, Warthin-Starry silver staining can be done where spiral bacilli are seen, as shown below.

Culture requires an enriched medium. It grows at 37°C in microaerophilic conditions and takes 3–7 days. The organisms obtained from the colonies are curved and oxidase positive. Non-invasive diagnostic tests like the urease breath test can also be performed. In this, the patient drinks a carbon-labeled urea solution which is later detected in the breath. 

The standard treatment is a combination of bismuth subsalicylate, tetracycline, and metronidazole for 2 weeks. Alternatively, proton pump inhibitors like omeprazole are also used along with clarithromycin. Treatment is not given for asymptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae is a fastidious organism that grows well on blood agar at 37°C. It mainly causes diseases like meningitis, croup, and pneumonia. 

Option B: Vibrio parahaemolyticus grows only in media that contain sodium chloride. It can tolerate salt concentrations of up to 8% in the media. The most commonly used media for this is thiosulphate citrate bile salts sucrose agar (TCBS). This organism is known to cause food poisoning associated with seafood. 

Option D: Campylobacter jejuni is best grown under microaerophilic conditions at 5% oxygen concentration. It is also thermophilic and grows at 42°C. C. jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in many developed countries.

questions.text: An IT professional was found to have vitamin D deficiency during a routine health check-up. He purchased vitamin D 60,000 IU sachets over-the-counter and started consuming them every day. After two weeks, he presented with severe colicky pain over the renal angle. His vitamin D levels are found to be elevated (170 ng/mL). Which of the following medications will be helpful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts vitamin D toxicity, which has led to hypercalcemia and renal stones. Among the given options, calcitonin can be used for the treatment of this condition.

Vitamin D toxicity occurs due to excessive intake of vitamin D supplements, usually in amounts of >40,000–100,000 IU/day. The symptoms are mainly due to hypercalcemia. Laboratory investigations will show elevated serum vitamin D levels (>100 ng/mL) and calcium.

In such patients, vitamin D supplements should be discontinued immediately, along with restricted exposure to the sun and avoiding calcium supplements. Since vitamin D is stored in the body for a long time, the symptoms may persist for some days even after stopping the intake.

Calcitonin and bisphosphonates are used in cases of severe toxicity causing hypercalcemia. Some patients might require glucocorticoids, which lower plasma calcium levels by reducing calcium absorption from the intestines and increasing its urinary excretion. 

Other options

Option B- Aspirin is used in the management of niacin-induced flushing.

Options C and D- Trientine and zinc are copper chelators. They are mainly used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related

questions.text:
A patient with a history of decreased urine output reports to the hospital. Inulin clearance test revealed decreased clearance. Which of the following factors can lead to this finding?
  1. Chronic uncontrolled hypertension
  2. Strong activation of renal sympathetic nerves
  3. PGE-2 release
  4. Endothelin infusion
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, Options 1, 2, and 4 can lead to decreased clearance of inulin.

Inulin clearance is used to measure the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Decreased inulin clearance is associated with decreased GFR. 

GFR is the amount of plasma ultrafiltrate formed each minute and can be measured by estimating the plasma level of a substance and the amount of that substance that is excreted. The substance used to measure GFR must be freely filtered through the glomeruli and must be neither secreted nor reabsorbed by the tubules. Eg. Inulin.

GFR is determined by the equation GFR = Kf × net filtration pressure, where Kf is the filtration coefficient.

In chronic uncontrolled hypertension, there is increased thickness of the glomerular capillary basement membrane and loss of capillary function due to severe damage. Hence, there is a gradual reduction in Kf, which leads to a decrease in GFR.

The afferent and efferent arterioles of the kidney are richly innervated by sympathetic nerve fibers. Strong activation of the renal sympathetic nerves can constrict the renal arterioles and decrease renal blood flow, which brings about a decrease in GFR. However, moderate or mild sympathetic stimulation has little influence on renal blood flow and GFR.

Endothelin is a potent vasoconstrictor and pro-fibrotic growth factor. In the renal cortex, ET binds to the ETA receptor resulting in afferent vasoconstriction and decreasing renal blood flow and GFR.

Prostaglandins PGE2 along with PGI2 and bradykinin, serve as hormones and autacoids that cause vasodilation, thereby resulting in increased renal blood flow and increased GFR.

questions.text: A woman presented with confusion, constipation, and headache. Serum calcium was 13.1mg/dL and ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice?
questions.solution:
Sestamibi scan is the imaging of choice to delineate parathyroid abnormalities.

Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation. It shows passive diffusion across cell membranes and accumulates in mitochondria. Because of its accumulation in the mitochondria, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondria in each tissue.

In parathyroid adenomas, there is a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content. The three protocols for sestamibi scanning are:

  • Single-isotope dual-phase scan
  • Dual-isotope subtraction imaging
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT).

SPECT is commonly used because of its improved spatial resolution. Sestamibi combined with CT can be used to detect smaller parathyroid tissues.

Other imaging modalities for parathyroid localization:

  • Ultrasonography:
    • It is inexpensive and noninvasive
    • Mediastinal parathyroid tissue cannot be detected because USG cannot penetrate the sternum or clavicles.
  • Four-dimensional CT: 
    • It has a very high sensitivity 
    • Increased radiation exposure than other routine modalities is a potential disadvantage
  • Selective venous sampling for PTH can be used for the exact localization of adenomas

questions.text: A resident doctor sustained a needlestick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. As post-exposure prophylaxis, he was started with triple-drug therapy Lamivudine + Tenofovir  + Dolutegravir. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this treatment plan?

choices.text: Counseling and support should be provided
Should undergo HIV testing 3 months post exposure
Triple drug therapy is recommended for 3 weeks
Prophylaxis  should be initiated  within 72  hour

questions.solution:
Triple therapy with tenofovir 300mg, lamivudine 300mg, and dolutegravir 50mg for 4 weeks is recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) not for 3 weeks.

PEP should be offered and initiated as early as possible, to all individuals with the exposure that has potential for HIV transmission. It should be initiated ideally within 2 hours but certainly within 72 hours.

The exposure that may need occupational PEP are:

  • Parenteral or mucous membrane exposure like splashes to the eye, nose, oral cavity
  • Body fluids that may pose a risk of HIV infection:
    • Blood
    • Blood-stained saliva
    • Breast-milk
    • Genital secretions
    • CSF
    • amniotic fluid
    • Rectal, peritoneal, synovial, pericardial ,and pleural fluid

The exposures that do not require PEP include:

  • The exposed individual is already positive for HIV
  • The source individual was established to be negative for HIV
  • Body fluids that don't pose a significant risk like tears, non-blood stained saliva, urine, and sweat

All individuals potentially exposed to HIV should undergo HIV testing 3 months following exposure. An enhanced adherence counseling must be given to all individuals initiating HIV PEP. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir

questions.text: A 56-year-old AIDS patient presented with the following lesions on his legs. Examination reveals similar lesions over the buccal mucosa. Biopsy reveals spindle cell vascular proliferation and promontory sign. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows red-purple macules and plaques on the leg and buccal mucosa, with a biopsy showing spindle cell vascular proliferation and promontory signs suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi's sarcoma is a soft tissue tumor due to endothelial proliferation that occurs in immunosuppressed individuals and is caused by human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8).

It has three stages, namely patch, plaque, and nodular. The smaller patches may fuse to form plaques and tumors of several centimeters in size. The lesions may also ulcerate or fungate, and can also involve lymph nodes.

A definitive diagnosis requires a biopsy. The biopsy will reveal horizontally arranged vessels dissecting through collagen bundles around the adnexa and surrounding pre-existing vessels (promontory sign).

It is treated by local excision, liquid nitrogen, or injection of vincristine. It generally has a poor prognosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Classic

  • Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean origin
  • Not associated with HIV
  • Skin plaques and nodules

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric department with characteristic hair as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following genetic mutation will be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image showing an irritable child with kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination is suggestive of Menke's disease. It is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X.

Menkes disease is a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. In this condition, dietary copper is absorbed from the GI tract but it cannot be transported to blood due to the absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene). Copper deficiency results in the defective function of the lysyl oxidase enzyme and thus leading to reduced cross-linkage of collagen.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive (Chromosome 13) (Option D)

Other options-

Option (A) and (B) are not associated with disorders of copper absorption.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A patient with a history of renal calculi has been on a low calcium diet for several weeks. On further investigation, which of the following is the most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely finding in this patient would be elevated levels of parathormone (PTH).

A diet low in calcium eventually leads to hypocalcemia, which stimulates PTH release. Hence, this patient will have high PTH levels. 

Increased PTH causes

  • Hypophosphatemia due to increased excretion of phosphate via the kidneys.
  • PTH acts on the kidneys to increase the absorption of calcium.
  • PTH also increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D- 1,25 dihydrocholecalciferol.

In the presence of hypocalcemia, serum calcitonin levels decrease and the active form of vitamin D increases.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be removed by dialysis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options the drug that cannot be removed by hemodialysis is digoxin. 

Digoxin removal via hemodialysis is limited due to its large distribution volume, as digoxin is extensively distributed in the tissues. The efficiency of hemodialysis in drug overdose or intoxication depends on molecular weight, water solubility, protein binding, endogenous clearance, and distribution of the drug in the body.  A drug can be removed by hemodialysis if it has:

  • low molecular weight
  • low volume of distribution
  • high solubility in water
  • minimal protein binding
Hemodialysable drugs  Non-hemodialysable drugs
Methanol Digoxin
Salicylate Diazepam
Valproic acid Verapamil
Phenobarbital Opioids
Lithium Metoprolol
Metformin Amphetamines

Generally, dialysis is indicated when medical management fails to control:

  • Volume overload
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Acidosis
  • Toxic ingestions
  • Severe complications of uremia like asterixis, pericardial rub or effusion, encephalopathy, and uremic bleeding.

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis

Short time for treatment Longer time may be required

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Principle:

Must be done in hospital Can be done at home

  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: You plan to start disease-modifying therapy in a 40-year-old patient with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. Which of the following drugs would you not include in the treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
The disease-modifying therapy of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) does not include methylprednisolone. It is used in acute attacks and exacerbations for MS symptom control. The long-term value or disease-modifying potential of glucocorticoid therapy is unknown. 

FDA approved disease-modifying therapy of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis are:

  • Interferon-beta 1a 
  • Interferon-beta 1b 
  • Glatiramer 
  • Dimethyl fumarate 
  • Teriflunomide
  • Alemtuzumab
  • Natalizumab 
  • Fingolimod 
  • Mitoxantrone 
  • Cladribine

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is planning a trek to Mount Everest. His family physician advises him to start taking oral acetazolamide as prophylaxis against acute mountain sickness. This drug inhibits the enzyme 'X'. Which of the following micronutrients is required for the activity of 'X'?
questions.solution:
The drug acetazolamide acts by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase. Zinc is important for the functioning of this enzyme. 

Zinc is an important micronutrient that is an essential part of several metalloenzymes such as carbonic anhydrase, alcohol dehydrogenase, superoxide dismutase, and alkaline phosphatase.

Zinc helps to stabilize the intermediates formed during the reactions involving these enzymes. In addition, zinc forms a polynucleotide-binding structure called 'zinc fingers'. These zinc fingers function as transcription factors as well as DNA/RNA-binding proteins. Scientists are hoping to use zinc fingers in gene therapy because of their very specific binding sites on DNA and RNA. 

Other options:

Option (B) - Selenium is a known component of enzymes such as deiodinase and glutathione peroxidase.

Option (C) - Manganese can also be found in metalloenzymes like isocitrate dehydrogenase, arginase, and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase.

Option (D) - Copper is also a component of several important metalloenzymes such as lysyl oxidase, cytochrome oxidase, tyrosinase, and dopamine-beta-hydroxylase.

Related Pearl: Metals as cofactors and prosthetic groups in enzymes
