questions.text: All of the following are included in calculating the qSOFA score except______
questions.solution:
The rapid bedside screening tool for sepsis derived from the SOFA scoring system is called the qSOFA score. A heart rate >90 beats per minute is not a component of the qSOFA scoring system.

qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU).

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for

  • Low blood pressure (SBP≤100 mmHg),
  • High respiratory rate (≥22 breaths/min),
  • Altered mentation (GCS score, <15).

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes from sepsis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a cough, fever and dysphagia. On examination, there is inspiratory stridor,  stiffness of the neck and a bulge is seen in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline. Which of the following is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The most likely site of the lesion is the area marked as 1 which is the pharynx.

The patient with cough, fever, dysphagia, inspiratory stridor with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall is likely to have a retropharyngeal abscess. Inspiratory stridor is seen in conditions involving the pharynx and supraglottis.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both. A few causes of inspiratory stridor include conditions like laryngomalacia and a retropharyngeal abscess, as in this case.

Biphasic stridor can be seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea. These include laryngeal papilloma and vocal cord palsy. Expiratory stridor is seen in the conditions involving the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi like bronchial foreign bodies and tracheal stenosis.

The image below describes the various types of stridor and the corresponding sites. Grading of stenosis is done using Cottle-Mayer classification. 

Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It occurs due to suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to an infection involving the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity.

Clinical features include dysphagia and difficulty in breathing due to the abscess obstructing the air and food passages, stridor and a croupy cough may be present. Torticollis develops, which manifests as neck stiffness and the head is kept extended. 

A bulge along the posterior pharyngeal wall is observed, usually seen on one side of the midline. An X-ray will reveal a widening of the prevertebral shadow. Gas may also be present.

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is tubercular and is the result of

  • Caries of the cervical spine
  • Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervical nodes.

Complications of a retropharyngeal abscess include:

  • Airway obstruction
  • Bronchial erosion
  • Mediastinitis
  • Sepsis
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cranial nerve palsies
  • Esophageal perforation
  • Erosion into carotid artery or jugular vein
  • Meningoencephalitis

Treatment:

  • Incision and drainage
  • Antibiotics
  • Tracheostomy if respiration is compromised.
  • ATT if tubercular etiology is noted.

The image below depicts a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed by an x-ray (lateral view) of the soft tissues of the neck by the following findings:

  • Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow
  • Loss of cervical lordosis
  • In an acute abscess, air-fluid levels can be seen.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A college student has repeated episodes of intense fear and a sense of impending doom every semester before his exams. He suffers from palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating during these episodes. Which of these is the drug of choice for the long-term management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient suffering from repeated episodes of intense fear, and sense of impending doom accompanied by palpitations, sweating, and dyspnea is suggestive of panic disorder. The drug of choice for long-term management of panic disorder is paroxetine, which is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort lasting from minutes to hours. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks, at least one of which is associated with 1 month of either persistent concern or worry about additional attacks, or a change in behavior related to the attacks.

An attack often begins with 10 minutes of rapid worsening of symptoms. This includes an extreme fear and a sense of impending doom and death along with tachycardia, palpitations, dyspnea, and sweating. The attack generally lasts for up to half an hour but in some cases may last for more than an hour. Between attacks, the patient may suffer from anticipatory anxiety about the next attack. 

DSM-5 criteria for panic disorder:

A. Recurrent unexpected panic attacks which include ≥4 of the following 

  • Palpitations
  • Trembling
  • Sweating
  • Dyspnea
  • Choking
  • Chest pain
  • Nausea, abdominal distress
  • Chills, heat sensation
  • Dizziness, light-headedness
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization or depersonalization
  • Fear of losing control
  • Fear of death

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following for >1 month:

  • Anticipatory anxiety - Continuous concern about additional panic attacks
  • Changes in behavior related to attacks (e.g. avoidance of unfamiliar situations)

3. The attack is not attributable to substance abuse or any other medical condition.

4. The attack cannot be explained by any other mental disorder. 

Treatment

Presently, SSRIs are considered the first-line drugs for the treatment of panic disorder. Paroxetine is preferred due to its sedative effects which calm down patients immediately leading to better compliance. Citalopram or sertraline are viable alternatives as well. However, for an acute episode with severe symptoms, benzodiazepines like alprazolam should be started concurrently with SSRIs and slowly tapered off. This is because benzodiazepines have the most rapid onset of action. Pharmacotherapy should generally continue for 8-12 months when it is found to be effective.

Other than pharmacotherapy, cognitive and behavior therapies are also very effective treatments for panic disorder. These work especially well when used in combination with pharmacotherapy. These help in producing long-lasting remissions of symptoms.

Option B - Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine with a high risk of psychological and physical dependence if used in the long term. Therefore it is used as an adjunct to SSRIs or psychotherapy and not used as a primary treatment.

Option C - Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. MAOIs may require certain dietary restrictions and hence are used less often.

Option D - Imipramine is a tricyclic anti-depressant that can be used for panic disorder as a second-line drug. TCAs are used less often than SSRIs because they are associated with more adverse effects at the dosages required for the treatment of panic disorder. 

 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
1. Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman developed fever, malaise and a polymorphic rash during the 3rd month of gestation. The characteristic lesions are shown in the image below. Which of following features will not be seen in the infant born to this infected mother?
questions.solution:
The rash with vesicular lesions on an erythematous base is suggestive of varicella infection (Chickenpox) in the pregnant woman, and blueberry muffin rash is not a feature of congenital varicella syndrome.

Congenital varicella syndrome: Fetal varicella infection occurs if the mother gets infected during the first half of pregnancy. Clinical features include:

  • Cicatrix, a zigzag scarring in a dermatomal distribution
  • Microphthalmia
  • Cataracts
  • Cortical atrophy
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Microcephaly
  • Limb hypoplasia
  • Neurogenic bladder, swallowing dysfunction, and aspiration pneumonia
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis

Chickenpox or varicella is caused by the Varicella–zoster virus. Its incubation period is 10 to 21 days. Fever, malaise, anorexia, headache, and occasionally mild abdominal pain may occur 24-48 hr before the rash appears. The rash starts as intensely pruritic, erythematous macules that become papules and finally clear, fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions are polymorphic - simultaneous presence of rashes in various stages of evolution.

It is treated with acyclovir 20 mg/kg/dose for 5 days.

Complications:

  • Cutaneous: Secondary bacterial superinfection of the skin
  • Systemic: Acute cerebella ataxia, encephalitis, pneumonia etc.

Note:

Blueberry muffin rash is seen in congenital rubella syndrome. The rash is shown in the image below. 

 

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A child presents with low-grade fever along with lesions as depicted in the image below. These lesions are non-pruritic and are present over the palms of the hand, soles of the feet, and around the mouth. The child has been refusing to eat or drink for the past few days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a low-grade fever, reduced appetite, and multiple vesicles on the palms, soles, and the perioral area is likely to have hand foot mouth disease. 

The image shows multiple vesicles surrounded by a halo of erythema. These vesicles usually rupture leading to superficial ulcers with a grey-yellow base and an erythematous rim. The lesions can be macular, papular, or vesicular. They are generally non-pruritic and non-painful, involving the dorsum of the hand, feet, buttocks, legs, and arms. 

It is caused by the Coxsackievirus and enterovirus. The serotypes commonly involved are Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It spreads by droplets or fecal contamination. 

It can also lead to aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, polio-like syndrome, acute transverse myelitis, and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 

Treatment for hand foot mouth disease is supportive. Pain and fever can be treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents. The patient should be adequately hydrated. 

Other options: 

Option A- Herpangina is characterized by sudden onset fever, sore throat, and dysphagia. There will be multiple vesicles present on the pharynx, tonsils, uvula, and soft palate. It is caused by Coxsackie A. The following image shows the lesions of herpangina in the oral cavity. 

 

Option C - Herpetic gingivostomatitis is characterized by high fever, malaise, restlessness, and excessive dribbling. There are vesicles presenting as white plaques on the tongue, pharynx, palate, and buccal mucous membranes leading to the development of ulcers with yellowish pseudomembranes.  The following image shows white plaques on the gums. 

 

Option D - Kawasaki disease is characterized by high-grade fever for at least 5 days, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea, runny nose, weakness, abdominal and joint pain. Acral and perianal erythema, edema, conjunctivitis with a strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy will be present. The following image shows the acral erythema and strawberry tongue of Kawasaki's disease.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman came to you with complaints of swelling and itching on the vulva for a few months. A tissue biopsy shows cellular atypia limited to the basal layer, involving the lower one-third of the vulval epithelium.  What degree of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) is this?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding of cellular atypia limited to the basal layer, involving the lower one-third of the vulval epithelium is suggestive of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) 1.

Degrees of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN): 

Degree Cellular atypia Other features
VIN 1 Limited to the basal layer Lower 1/3rd of the vulval epithelium is involved
VIN 2

Basal and intermediate layers involved

Lower 2/3rd of vulval epithelium is involved

Commonly associated with HPV
VIN 3

Entire thickness of the vulval epithelium is involved

No vascular/ lymphatic invasion

 2 types:

  • Young patients - HPV +ve, multiple lesions, 90% regress
  • Elderly patients - HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progresses to invasive cancer

 

VIN is defined as cellular atypia limited to the epithelium of the vulval skin, excluding the keratinized layer. Other characteristics of VIN are the presence of acanthosis, intraepithelial pearl formation at the rete pegs, and inflammation at the dermis.

VIN is limited to the basement membrane and does not spread to the dermis. They are frequently seen in the age group of 20-40 years of age. 

They are often related to sexually transmitted diseases such as:

  • Condyloma accuminata
  • Herpes simplex virus II
  • Gonorrhea
  • Syphilis
  • Gardnerella vaginalis

HPV types associated with VIN are 16, 18, 31, and 35. 

Patients with VIN mainly complain of pruritus vulvae, lump, or bleeding from a vulval ulcer. Lesions are multifocal and look rough, raised from the surface. On applying 5% acetic acid to VIN lesions turn it to white with punctuation and mosaic pattern. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy. It has got low malignant potential. Less than 10 % of them progress to invasive carcinoma.

Topical fluorinated steroid ointment can be used for symptomatic management. Local application chemotherapic agents like 5-fluorouracil cream can be used in recurrent lesions.

Surgical methods for treatment are:

  • Wide local excision
  • Laser therapy
  • Simple vulvectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of a lesion in hemiballismus?
questions.solution:
The most common site of a lesion in hemiballismus is the subthalamus.

Hemiballismus refers to violent choreiform movement with wild, flinging, movements of large amplitude that can either be confined to one limb or affect both upper and lower limbs. It mostly affects the proximal muscles of the limbs.

Other options:

Option A: A lesion in the putamen can give rise to chorea. This is described as flicking movements of the hands, face, or any other part of the body.

Option B: A lesion in the globus pallidus can give rise to athetosis. This involves spontaneous and continuous writhing movements of the hand, arm, neck, or face.

Option D: A lesion in the caudate nucleus would hamper cognitive control of motor activity, that is, voluntary movements generated as a consequence of the thoughts in a person's mind.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with fever and productive cough. She has had a history of multiple respiratory tract infections since birth.  Laboratory investigations show elevated IgM antibody levels. IgG levels are found to be low, while IgA and IgE are absent. Mutation in which of the following genes is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Elevated IgM with low to absent levels of IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies suggest hyper-IgM syndrome. Mutation in the gene encoding for the CD40 ligand is responsible for this condition.

CD40 ligand is normally responsible for class switching. Class switching refers to the genetic recombination event in which the heavy-chain constant segment of the IgM gene is replaced with a different constant segment that leads to a different type of antibody being produced (e.g. IgG, IgA, IgE, etc.).

Mutation in the gene that codes for CD40 ligand will impair class switching of the IgM antibodies to any other antibody type, and this results in relatively higher levels of IgM. Frequent infections of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract result from lower levels of other antibodies. Elevated IgM antibodies can sometimes react with blood cells, causing autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In others, IgM-producing plasma cells may proliferate and infiltrate the gastrointestinal mucosa.

Other options:

Option A: The adenosine deaminase (ADA) gene is deficient in the autosomal recessive variant of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). This results in the production of toxic metabolites that destroy the rapidly dividing T-cell lineage (affects T-cells more than B-cells). These children are susceptible to recurrent infections, and without a bone marrow transplant, they usually die within the first year of life. 

Option B: Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) gene is mutated in X-linked agammaglobulinemia. It occurs because the B-cells fail to undergo maturation. All lines of immunoglobulins are found to be low in this disease. Since it is an X-linked disorder, it is most commonly seen in young males. They present after the age of 6 months with recurrent respiratory tract infections.

Option D: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP) gene is mutated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. This is also an X-linked disorder that presents with eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. They usually show low IgM levels, normal IgG, and elevated IgE and IgA levels.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: INTERPOL reports an increase in organized crime groups behind organ trafficking and transplant tourism in past few years.  Which of the following declaration aims to combat these crimes?
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Istanbul combats organ trafficking, transplant tourism, and transplant commercialism. They aim to encourage the adoption of effective and ethical transplantation practices around the world.

Other options:

Option A- The declaration of Geneva also known as the modern Hippocratic oath. It is a declaration of a physician's dedication to the service of humanity.

Option B- The declaration of Sydney describes the determination of death and recovery of organs. Death determination can be made on the basis of the irreversible cessation of all functions of the entire brain, or the irreversible cessation of circulatory and respiratory functions. This determination will be made by a physician based on clinical judgment according to accepted criteria, supplemented, and by standard diagnostic procedures.

Option C- The declaration of Helsinki gives a set of ethical principles directed to the medical community in research involving human subjects. 

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient suffers from diabetes and hypertension. He regularly takes metformin, glimepiride, amlodipine, and losartan. He now presents to the clinic with ankle swelling and gingival hyperplasia. Which of the following drug is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Gingival hyperplasia and ankle swelling are side-effects of calcium channel blockers like amlodipine. 

Ankle edema occurs due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the capillaries present in the dependent parts of the body. This is due to reflex constriction of postcapillary vessels. Other common side effects of amlodipine include headache, dizziness and abdominal pain.

Option A - Metformin usually has side effects like bloating, abdominal pain, anorexia, and mild diarrhea. It does not cause hypoglycemia except in cases of an overdose.

Option B - Glimepiride tends to cause weight gain in most diabetics. Symptoms like nausea, vomiting, flatulence, and headache are mild and infrequent. Dangerously low blood glucose is a common but sometimes fatal problem. Due to this, patients taking glimepride should check their blood glucose levels regularly. 

Option C - Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that can cause orthostatic hypotension, oliguria and even hyperkalemia. These symptoms are generally rare as ARBs are well tolerated.

questions.text:
Match the given images with the likely complications they are associated with-
  1. Subinvolution of the uterus, PPH, and retained products of conception 
  2. Antepartum hemorrhage and hydrorrhea gravidarum 
  3. Vasa previa and fetal hemorrhage 
  4. Marginal attachment of cord leading to cord compression, fetal anoxia, and death
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a.

  • Image 1- Battledore placenta
  • Image 2- Circumvallate placenta
  • Image 3- Velamentous insertion of cord
  • Image 4- Succenturiate placenta

Image 1 is a Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a previa or a low-lying placenta, it can lead to cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

 

Image 2 is a circumvallate placenta. It is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring that is reflected centrally. This leaves a rim of placental tissue exposed extrachorially. There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum, antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes. 

 

Image 3 shows a velamentous placenta in which the cord is attached to the membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If these vessels are present over the internal os in front of the presenting part, it is called vasa previa. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination.

 

Image 4 shows a succenturiate placenta. It is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation.

questions.text: The CT abdomen of a patient with Budd-Chiari syndrome shows enlargement of the structure marked X in the image. Identify the structure.
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is the caudate lobe of the liver. Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in Budd-Chiari syndrome.

This segment is unique in that it receives blood supply from both the right and left portal veins and hepatic arteries. It directly drains into the inferior vena cava.

It also forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen.

The image given below shows the posterior surface of the liver.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presented 3 months ago with mild behavioral changes. He developed startle myoclonus and progressively worsening dementia. His condition deteriorated rapidly and he passed away 2 days ago. On autopsy, spongiform degeneration of the brain was noted. Which of the following histopathological findings would be seen in his brain?
questions.solution:
This elderly man, with startle myoclonus, a rapidly progressive dementia that lead to death within 3 months, and spongiform degeneration of the brain on autopsy most likely had a diagnosis of prion disease (likely Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is associated with misfolded prion protein inclusions called PrPsc.

Prion disease is a rapidly progressing neurodegenerative disorder that occurs due to abnormal protein folding of prion proteins. These proteins can undergo a structural change from an alpha helix to beta-pleated sheets (PrPC to PrPSC). These proteins then become resistant to breakdown by normal proteases in the body and can rapidly spread, invading the central nervous system and inducing neuronal cell death. Prion diseases can be sporadic, but more often they have a familial mode of spread due to mutations in the PRNP gene that codes for PrP.

The brain classically undergoes spongiform degeneration due to vacuole formation and rapid death of the neurons. Histopathological examination during post-mortem can reveal inclusion such as PrPsc deposits and Kuru plaques. 

Other options-

Option (B): Alpha-synuclein is commonly seen in Parkinson's disease, which presents with an abnormal shuffling gait, resting tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. It can also be seen in multiple system atrophy which is predominantly a disease of autonomic dysfunction. It can progress rapidly but is not associated with startle myoclonus or progressive dementia.

Option (C): Pick bodies are seen in frontotemporal lobe degeneration. Frontotemporal lobe degeneration would result in gradual behavioral changes and features of aphasia and not rapidly progressive symptoms.

Option (D): Cerebral amyloid angiopathy is often seen in Alzheimer's disease characterized by Amyloid deposition in cortical arterioles. However, Alzheimer's would present with slowly progressive symptoms.

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains that he feels dejected and depressed for the past 3 years. His wife says that he has frequent mood fluctuations.  A few days a week, he appears very depressed, and on other days he is irritable and short-tempered leading to regular arguments with his wife. This causes him stress and he has recently started to consume alcohol to help himself feel better. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of depression, irritability, sudden mood fluctuations, and alcohol abuse for the past 3 years is suggestive of cyclothymic disorder.

Cyclothymia presents as a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by symptoms of hypomania and mild depression. Hypomania mainly includes symptoms like persistently elevated or irritable mood and abnormally increased energy lasting for at least 4 consecutive days. The depression seen in cyclothymia does not qualify the criteria for a major depressive episode.

Around half of the patients complain of depression as their major symptom but some may have primarily hypomanic symptoms. Most of these patients have problems in their social and professional lives due to this disorder. The mood changes are abrupt and occur within hours leading to a great amount of stress. This makes patients feel that they are out of control. 

Substances like alcohol, benzodiazepines, or marijuana are often used to self-medicate. In some cases during the hypomanic state patients may take cocaine, amphetamines, or hallucinogens to further stimulate themselves.

The DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of cyclothymia:

A. For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been many periods with hypomanic symptoms not meeting the criteria for a manic episode and many periods with depressive symptoms not meeting the criteria for a major depressive episode.

B. During the above 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not had a symptom-free interval of more than 2 months.

C. Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode have never been met.

D. The symptoms in criterion A are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

E. The symptoms cannot be explained by the physiological effects of a substance or any other medical condition.

F. The symptoms cause significant difficulties in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.

Mood stabilizers like lithium and antimanic drugs like sodium valproate are the first lines of treatment. Psychotherapy is a great way for patients to develop coping mechanisms to help with their mood swings. Patients often require life-long treatment.

Option A: Major depressive disorder usually presents with depressed mood, anhedonia, significant change in weight or appetite, insomnia or hypersomnia, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness nearly every day. These symptoms are present for a minimum of 2 weeks. 

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Dysthymic disorder is the presence of a persistently depressed mood that lasts most of the day and is continuous. There are also feelings of guilt, irritability, and anger associated with it. These symptoms are present for at least 2 years. It is distinguished from major depressive disorder by the fact that patients mention that they have always been depressed. There will never be an episode of mania/hypomania in this condition.

Related Pearl: Timeline in psychiatry

Condition Duration
Manic episode At least 1 week
Hypomania At least 4 consecutive days
Major depressive disorder

Lasts 6 to12 months with episodes for 2 or more weeks
Cyclothymia At least 2 years
Dysthymia At least 2 years
Maternal blues Starts 2–3 days after delivery and usually resolves within 10 days
Postpartum mood disturbances Onset within 4 weeks of delivery
Brief psychotic disorder Lasts < 1 month, usually stress-related
Schizophreniform disorder Lasts 1-6 months
Schizophrenia Lasts > 6 months
Schizoaffective disorder Lasts > 2 weeks
Delusional disorder Lasts > 1 month
Panic disorder An episode followed by 1 month of concern of additional attacks 
Specific phobia Lasts > 6 months
Generalized anxiety disorder Lasts > 6 months 
Acute stress disorder Lasts between 3 days and 1 month 
PTSD Lasts > 1 month 
Adjustment disorder

Symptoms occur within 3 months of the stressor and last < 6 months

May last > 6 months in presence of chronic stressor
Bulimia nervosa At least 3 months
Somatic symptom disorder Lasts > 6 months
Separation anxiety disorder Common onset at 7–9 years 
Tourette syndrome

Onset < age 18 years

Tics that persist for > 1 year 
ADHD Symptoms for > 6 months

questions.text: The physician explains the complications of diabetes and the need for compliance in simple terms to his illiterate patient. This is an example of which level of communication?
questions.solution:
This is an example of communication on an intellectual plane.

Communication on an intellectual plane involves giving empathetic, easy-to-understand explanations of their conditions and helping the patients develop insight into their ailments and their treatment plans. The doctor should take into account the fact that the patient's intellectual understanding may not be at the same level and, hence, put it in simple easy-to-understand terms.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: Listening with empathy, building rapport, and ensuring openness and trust from the patient is part of this.
    • Example- Dr. X lending a sympathetic ear to the complaints made by the 84-year-old geriatric patient on his lingering backache is the emotional plane.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs and his/her cultural and lifestyle factors that may influence health and disease and to advise in terms that the patient would understand. 
    • Example- Dr. A, the hypertension clinic physician, making his dietary advice in terms that fit the already existing lifestyle pattern in that area is an example of understanding the cultural plane.

There is no such plane as the scientific plane in communication.

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma has been planned for radical nephrectomy by the surgical team. The tumor is 4 cms in size, situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes determined through CT. Which of the following will be removed in this patient?
  1. Kidney
  2. Adrenal gland
  3. Perirenal fat
  4. Regional lymph nodes
questions.solution:
While performing radical nephrectomy in the above patient only kidney and perirenal fat will be removed, as the tumor size is less than 5cm and situated at the lower pole of the kidney with negative regional lymph nodes.

Radical Nephrectomy :

Classically radical nephrectomy consists of removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. In patients with a tumor <5 cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared. Regional lymph node dissection is done for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during the surgery. As in this scenario the tumour size is <5cm and regional lymph nodes detection was negative, both the adrenal glands and lymph nodes are spared. 

Partial nephrectomy :

  • For tumors less than or equal to 4 cm in size and limited to the kidney (T1a), partial nephrectomy is performed.
  • Partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed in tumors >4cm in size but less than or equal to 7 cms, and limited to the kidney (T1b). If partial nephrectomy is not feasible in T1b tumors, then a radical nephrectomy is done.
  • Other indications for partial nephrectomy are bilateral renal cell carcinoma and carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney.

Radical nephrectomy is performed in patients with large tumors and for patients in whom a partial nephrectomy is not technically feasible.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient presents with fever, chills, cough, sputum production, and chest pain for two weeks. Sputum was negative for acid-fast bacilli. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever, chills, cough, sputum production, and chest pain for two weeks and an X-ray depicting a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level and surrounding consolidation is consistent with a lung abscess. 

A lung abscess is a localized necrotic cavity containing pus. The most common area that is affected is the posterior segment of the upper lobe or the superior segment of the lower lobe. 

Clinical features, as seen in this patient include fever, cough, sputum production, and chest pain. Chronic and indolent presentations can include night sweats, fatigue, anemia (seen in anaerobic infections), and discolored sputum that is foul-tasting or smelling. 

Organisms implicated are anaerobic bacteria like Fusobacterium nucleatum and Bacteroides sp. Other bacteria include S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, and K. pneumoniae. 

It occurs as a complication of pneumonia. Other complications of pneumonia include: 

  • Pulmonary gangrene
  • Pneumatocoele
  • Septic emboli
  • Empyema
  • Bronchopleural fistula

 

Other options: 

Option A - Tuberculosis (TB) would present as homogenous lobar consolidation in any lobe. Chest radiography can also be normal in a few cases. The following image shows a homogenous dense opacity in the right lung consistent with pulmonary tuberculosis. Clinical features of TB include chronic cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, low-grade fever, and night sweats. 

 

Option B - Lung neoplasm would be seen on chest radiographs as pulmonary nodules. They may be incidentally detected or symptomatic. The following image shows a peripheral nodule. Lung neoplasms are generally advanced when they present. Clinical features depend on the specific neoplasm like cough, malignant pleural effusion, superior vena cava syndrome, and metastatic effects. 

 

Option D - Foreign body aspiration can be diagnosed by a radio-opaque foreign body, lobar collapse, or air trapping. The foreign body might also be radio-lucent so it may not be visible on the radiograph. Patients may be asymptomatic or present with sudden onset cough, choking, or dyspnea. The following image shows a radio-opaque foreign body (safety-pin).

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of passing reddish-brown colored urine and episodic abdominal pain for the past few months. Reports reveal anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia. Flow cytometry shows CD55/CD59-negative RBCs. What is the drug of choice for her condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of intravascular hemolysis due to paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The drug of choice for treating PNH is Eculizumab. 

Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that has greatly improved the outcome for many patients with PNH from around the world. It works by inhibiting complement C5 which then prevents the activation of the complement cascade, thus preventing intra-vascular hemolysis. 

Supportive management of PNH includes folic acid and iron supplementation. Bone marrow transplantation is another option for the treatment of this condition. 

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria is characterized by recurrent intravascular hemolysis that can also be associated with pancytopenia and venous thrombosis. Patients present with complaints of passing blood in urine or anemia. In the case of venous thrombosis, they can present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain.  

The diagnosis of PNH is made by flow cytometry which can be carried out on red blood cells or granulocytes. The cells are CD55 or CD59 negative.

Other options:

Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal murine antibody that targets VEGF-A and thereby inhibits vascular proliferation and tumor growth. It is used in colorectal cancer.

Option B: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 receptor antagonist, used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Option D: Abciximab is the Fab fragment of a humanized monoclonal antibody directed against glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. It is administered to patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention. It prevents recurrent myocardial infarction and death when used in conjunction with aspirin and heparin.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient comes to the clinic for follow-up 3 weeks after a traumatic fracture in his right upper limb. On examination, he was found to have a hard palpable mass near the fracture site. X-ray of the area shows the findings below. A histological section shows central fibrous tissue and mature bone at the periphery. Which of the following is true about this patient's diagnosis?

choices.text: It is a type of connective tissue metaplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hyperplasia
It is a type of connective tissue hypertrophy
It is a type of malignant transformation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of traumatic heterotopic ossification. Myositis ossificans is a type of heterotopic ossification which occurs as a result of pathological connective tissue metaplasia.

Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one differentiated cell type (epithelial or mesenchymal) is replaced by another cell type. It usually represents an adaptive response in which one cell type is replaced by another more capable of handling the stressor. Although, in the case of myositis ossificans, it is not clearly seen as an adaptive response.

Common examples of metaplasia include- Barrett's esophagus (squamous epithelium replaced by intestinal-like columnar cells due to chronic gastric reflux), columnar to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of chronic smokers.

Connective tissue metaplasia is the formation of cartilage, bone, or adipose tissue (mesenchymal tissues) in tissues that normally do not contain these elements. Myositis ossificans is characterized by heterotopic bone formation within muscle tissue following traumatic injury to the area with hemorrhage into it. Heterotopia refers to the presence of normal cells in abnormal places.

There are three types of heterotopic ossification known

  • Myositis ossificans progressiva: A rare genetic condition with the autosomal dominant transmission with variable penetrance. This leads to recurrent painful soft-tissue swellings. Patients usually die from restrictive lung disease
  • Traumatic myositis ossificans: This case develops after a single blow to the area, a muscle tear, or repeated minor trauma. The painful area gradually develops masses with a cartilaginous consistency and within 4-7 weeks, a solid mass of bone can be felt
  • Neurogenic heterotopic ossification: Heterotopic bone formation around joints, limiting mobility. Seen in patients with traumatic brain or spinal cord injury.

Other options-

Option (B): Hyperplasia is increased cell number in response to hormones and growth factors that occur in tissues whose cells are able to divide and have abundant stem cell reserve. Common examples- female breast during puberty and pregnancy, benign prostatic hyperplasia, etc.

Option (C): Hypertrophy is an increase in cell size and organ size which occurs in response to increased workload in tissues incapable of cell division. Common examples- uterus during pregnancy, cardiac muscle in response to chronic hypertension (due to overload), skeletal muscles in bodybuilders, etc.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: While examining a patient in the dermatology OPD, the senior resident elicits the following finding. What condition does this patient likely have?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dermographism, which is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

It is an urticarial reaction in response to pressure or trauma to the skin. It is the most common type of inducible urticaria.

Simple dermographism or factitious urticaria refers to the triple response of local erythema due to: 

  1. Capillary vasodilatation
  2. Edema
  3. Surrounding flare 

The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the wheals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

In <5% of cases, symptomatic dermographism can occur. It is characterized by severe, disproportionate itching that is worse at night. 

Other rare forms of dermographism associated with urticaria are cholinergic dermographism, red dermographism, and delayed dermographism.

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction did not respond to PDE-5 inhibitor drugs. A second-line treatment involves the injection of prostaglandin into the part of the penis marked as X in the image below. Which is the prostaglandin used?
questions.solution:
The part marked as X in the image is the corpus cavernosum and prostaglandin indicated for direct intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction is PGE1- Alprostadil.

It is a natural PGE1 preparation available as an intraurethral suppository and intracavernosal injection. It is usually used in patients who are not responding to PDE-5 inhibitors such as those with neurogenic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

Alprostadil is also used for temporarily maintaining the patency of a patent ductus arteriosus in neonates.

Management of Erectile dysfunction:

  • Lifestyle modifications
  • First-line pharmacological therapy consists of PDE-5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil.
    • Common side effects include headache, flushing, dyspepsia, nasal congestion, dizziness, and back pain. Blue green-tinted vision and blurred vision may be experienced with sildenafil and vardenafil. Priapism leading to ischemia may also occur.
    • PDE5 inhibitors potentiate the hypotensive effects of nitrates, leading to hypotension. It is contraindicated in patients receiving organic nitrates.
    • CYP3A inhibitors (e.g., protease inhibitors, erythromycin, and cimetidine) inhibit the metabolism of PDE5 inhibitors and elevate their blood levels.
  • Vacuum erection devices: A cylindrical device placed over the penis and then pumped. It creates a negative pressure vacuum to draw blood into the penis. Side effects include petechiae, hematomas, grey-blue color to the penis.
  • Second-line therapy:
    • Intracavernosal injection (ICI) of vasoactive substances like prostaglandin E1, papaverine, and phentolamine. They work alone or in combination to elicit an erection. Prostaglandin PGE1 has been approved by the FDA as a single-agent ICI for erectile dysfunction to increase cAMP levels.
    • Intraurethral suppository of a prostaglandin E1: Can be inserted into the urethra before intercourse. 
  • Surgical methods: Penile implants and penile revascularization. 

Other Prostaglandins/ Prosatglandin analogs:

  • PGE1 analog: Misoprostol is approved for termination of pregnancy, and the prevention of NSAID induced gastric ulcers.
  • PGE2: Dinoprostone is used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and as abortifacients in the second trimester of pregnancy.
  • PGI2: Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in Pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • PGI2 analogs: Iloprost and Treprostinil used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • PGF2α: Carboprost is used to induce second-trimester abortions and to control postpartum hemorrhage. Latanoprost is a long-acting PGF2α derivative, used for glaucoma. Similar prostanoids with ocular hypotensive effects include bimatoprost, tafluprost, and travoprost.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient who has worked in the mining and smelting industry for more than 15 years presented with pigmentation on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and the neck as in the given image. On further examination, a transverse white line was seen on his fingernails. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. We reach this diagnosis by considering the occupational history, raindrop pattern of skin pigmentation, and the Aldrich-Mees lines on the fingernails of the patient.

Arsenic poisoning

In its metallic form, arsenic is not poisonous, but when it unites with oxygen, it forms poisonous vapors of arsenic trioxide. These interfere with cellular respiration, damaging mitochondrial enzymes. It is present in fruit sprays, copper and gold mineral deposits, weed-killers, insecticides, rat poisons, wallpapers, and artificial flowers.

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1–3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the most common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called the Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urinary excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy
  • Marsh and Reinsch tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide, which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer), British anti-Lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine can also be used. 

Other options:

Option A - Phosphorus is an inorganic irritant poison that exists in two forms—highly toxic white phosphorus and non-toxic red phosphorus. The white form is used in fertilizers, insecticides, fireworks, etc., whereas the red form is seen on the sides of a matchbox.

Phosphorus poisoning presents with clinical features like severe abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, hematemesis, jaundice, and hemorrhages. In chronic poisoning, phossy jaw may occur. It is the osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw with multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates making it harmless. Activated charcoal helps in the adsorption of the poison.

Option B - Acute copper poisoning is due to inhalation of a large amount of copper dust or fumes, which leads to upper respiratory tract irritation, conjunctivitis, and sinus irritation. Contact with the skin may lead to irritant contact dermatitis and a greenish-blue discoloration of the skin. 

In chronic poisoning, symptoms mostly resemble those of Wilson's disease, mainly including gradual anemia, peripheral neuritis, and muscle atrophy.

Option C - Acute mercury poisoning presents with corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea, which may progress to pulmonary edema and fibrosis. The symptom profile in children is similar to that of Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome).

Chronic exposure to elemental mercury leads to a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes. 

The characteristic Danbury tremors occur first in the hands and later progress to the lips and tongue, eventually involving the arms and legs. Over time, these become more severe, and the patient is unable to dress, walk properly, or write legibly. These are also known as hatter's shakes or glassblower's shakes. The most severe form is concussion mercurialis in which all activity is lost.

Acrodynia or pink disease - It is an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction to chronic mercury exposure, seen particularly in children. The hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, painful, and paresthetic, with peeling of the skin.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Mees' lines

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

questions.text: A young animal rescue worker complained of an itchy rash on his abdomen. On examination, multiple creeping lesions are seen as shown in the image below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with an image showing red, raised serpiginous lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans. The drug of choice for this condition is ivermectin.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they cannot penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry. This is followed by the appearance of erythematous serpiginous tracks of lesions on skin. This is due to the migration of larva through the dermo-epidermal junction. The lesion shifts correspond to the movement of the larva. Hence these lesions are also called creeping eruptions.

Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.

The treatment includes topical application of thiabendazole and oral albendazole or ivermectin.

The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:

  Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans
Tissue involved Skin Liver, lungs, and eyes
Infecting Organism Mostly by non-human nematodes Mostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dogs and cats)
Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs
Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high
Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole/ Albendazole/ Ivermectin

Albendazole/ Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and Prednisolone. 

DEC has greater side effects than Albendazole so it is rarely used 


Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals.

Other options:

Option B: Praziquantel is used for the treatment of all human tapeworms, neurocysticercosis, schistosomes, and Fasciola hepatica infection.

Option C: Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of filariasis, visceral larva migrans, and tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Option D: Prednisolone is used as an immunosuppressant for the treatment of a variety of infections like neurocysticercosis, visceral larva migrans, etc.

questions.text: An 8-month-old child comes in contact with an active tuberculosis case. His parents take him to a pulmonologist. The child undergoes investigations and active TB is ruled out. The doctor recommends tuberculosis preventive treatment (TPT). Which of the following regimens does the child take as TPT?
questions.solution:
The regimen for tuberculosis preventive treatment (TPT) for the 8-month-old child in the given scenario is 6 months of daily isoniazid.

The following TPT treatment options are recommended under National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) once active TB has been ruled out:

Target Population Treatment options
  • People living with HIV (adults and children >12 months)
  • Infants <12 months in contact with active TB
  • HHC (Household contact) (below 5 years) of pulmonary tuberculosis patients.
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)
  • 3-month weekly isoniazid and rifapentine(3HP) in persons older than 2 years.
HHC(5 years and above) of pulmonary TB patients (testing would be offered whenever available)
  • 3-month weekly isoniazid and rifapentine (3HP)
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)
Children/adults on immunosuppressive
therapy, silicosis, anti-TNF treatment, dialysis,
transplantation
  • 3-month weekly isoniazid and rifapentine (3HP)
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H)

Dose of isoniazid : 

  • Age 10 years & older: 5 mg/kg/day
  • Age <10 years: 10 mg/kg/day (range, 7–15 mg)

The choice of regimen will be guided by the availability of the drugs and the tolerability profile of the patients.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

questions.text: A woman with papillary thyroid cancer of the right lobe comes with a swelling on the right side of the neck as shown below (between the red arrows). Biopsy reveals metastatic tissue from the ipsilateral tumor. What is this metastatic lesion also known as?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes papillary thyroid carcinoma metastasis to the ipsilateral neck nodes. This is also known as a lateral aberrant thyroid.

Papillary thyroid carcinomas are the most common forms of thyroid carcinoma and present in younger individuals. They are commonly spread by the lymphatic system.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who:

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (< 5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure
  • Familial syndromes (Cowden syndrome, Werner syndrome, Carney syndrome, etc)

The patient may present with thyroid swelling, lateral aberrant thyroid(cervical node invasion my metastasis), dysphagia, and hoarseness.

Management of differentiated thyroid cancers (DTC)

Differentiated thyroid cancers include papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer, and hurtle cell cancer.
Hemithyroidectomy is performed for DTCs between 1-4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or evidence of metastatic disease.
However, total thyroidectomy is performed in the following scenarios

  • Tumor at least 4 cm
  • Gross extrathyroidal extension
  • Evidence of metastatic disease
  • Radiation-induced DTC
  • Familial nonmedullary thyroid cancer
  • Multifocal bilateral DTC.

Central neck dissection is done only in case of involvement of level VI nodes.
If level VI plus other lymph nodes are enlarged - then total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection + modified radical neck dissection is done.
In case of tumor size >4cm (T3 &T4), prophylactic central neck dissection is done.

Other options-

Option A: Hashimoto's thyroiditis is also called struma lymphomatosa. It is not a malignant condition.

Option B: Lingual thyroid refers to thyroid tissue that remains attached to the tongue, at its site of origin within the oral cavity. The patient may present with obstructive symptoms such as choking, dysphagia, airway obstruction, or hemorrhage. Some patients develop hypothyroidism. Medical management includes the administration of exogenous thyroid hormone to suppress thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation followed by hormone replacement. Surgical excision is rarely needed.

Option D: Thyroglossal duct cyst refers to a cyst that forms when the descending thyroid remains attached to the cecum of the tongue by a stalk and fails to separate. It is found in the midline, and not laterally like in this patient. It is not malignant in nature.

The below image shows a thyroglossal duct cyst as a midline neck swelling-

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following statements about medulloblastomas is incorrect?

choices.text: Most common childhood embryonal CNS tumor
Homer Wright rosettes are seen in this condition
It is a tumor arising from the posterior fossa
Rosenthal fibers are seen in this condition

questions.solution:
The statement in option D is incorrect. Rosenthal fibers are seen in pilocytic astrocytomas. They are astrocytic cytoplasmic inclusions that appear as elongated corkscrew-like structures that stain bright pink (eosinophilic).  

Medulloblastomas are embryonal tumors, also known as primitive neuroectodermal tumors (PNET). This group is the most common group of malignant CNS tumors in childhood. Medulloblastomas consist of 90% of the embryonal CNS tumors (Option A). Other tumors belonging to this group include supratentorial PNET, ependymoblastoma, medulloepithelioblastima, and atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors. This group is graded as World Health Organization grade IV tumors. 

Medulloblastoma predominantly occurs in males, presenting at a median age between 5-7 years of age. 

Clinical features include increased intracranial pressure manifesting as headache, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, hypertension. There is also cerebellar dysfunction which manifests as ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. 

Histologically, there is the presence of Homer Wright rosettes (Option B) and synaptophysin immunopositivity. There are multiple histological patterns, but the most common is a monomorphic sheet of undifferentiated cells noted as small, blue, round cells. 

CT and MRI will reveal a solid, homogenous, contrast medium enhancing mass in the posterior fossa (Option C). It can lead to obstruction of the 4th ventricle and hydrocephalus.

It is staged according to the Chang staging system and is treated with a multimodality approach, incorporating surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. 

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

Related Pearl: Most commons of Brain tumours

Most common tumor of the brain - Metastasis secondary to lungs > breast

Most common primary CNS tumor - glioma > meningioma
