questions.text: A mother of five, brings her youngest child, an 18-month-old girl, for evaluation. The child appears very thin with minimal fat distribution. There is severe wasting of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs as shown in the below image. The middle-upper arm circumference is less than 11.5 cm. The child is alert and irritable. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The alert and irritable child with severe fat wasting in the areas of the shoulders, arms, buttocks, and thighs is likely to have marasmus. 

Marasmus is a type of severe protein-energy malnutrition which occurs due to insufficient calorie intake. It is characterized by severe wasting of fat and muscles. The child appears to be very thin, having a 'skin and bones' appearance with no fat. 

The loss of buccal fat leads to the 'monkey facies' or 'old man face' due to its aged and wrinkled appearance. 'Baggy pants appearance' is due to the presence of loose skin in the buttocks that hangs low. 

Other features that may be present are hypotension, hypothermia, and bradycardia as well as micronutrient deficiencies. 

Diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition is made with the help of anthropometry.

  • Weight for height is below -3 standard deviations for the mean on the World Health Organization (WHO) chart or,
  • Presence of bipedal edema or,
  • Middle-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is less than 115 mm (in the red zone of the tape as shown below). 

 

The children should be assessed for the following: 

  • Severe edema 
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test) 
  • Medical complications 
  • One or more danger sign

If any of the above are present, the child should be treated as a case of complicated severe acute malnutrition and should have inpatient management. Uncomplicated cases can have supervised home management. 

The WHO recommends testing hemoglobin, total blood count, peripheral blood smear, blood glucose, serum albumin, electrolytes, stool microscopy with culture, parasitic evaluation, retroviral testing, and urine microscopy with culture. 

Other options: 

Option A - Kwashiorkor is another type of protein-energy malnutrition that is characterized mainly by pitting edema starting in the legs and feet that spread to the hands and face. They also show skin changes characterized by increased pigmentation and desquamation. They do not show signs of hunger and are difficult to feed. The weight for height may be normal. The following image shows the edema and the skin changes seen in Kwashiorkor.

 

Option C - Chronic pancreatitis can mimic protein-energy malnutrition. It can occur due to cystic fibrosis and obstruction of the pancreatic ducts due to roundworms. This would present with prolonged abdominal pain, weight loss, and steatorrhea. 

Option D - Marasmic kwashiorkor is a mixed form of malnutrition that presents with features of both marasmus and kwashiorkor. There will be edema, and growth stunting with less severe hair and skin changes of kwashiorkor.

Related Pearl: Differences between Marasmus and Kwashiorkar

Marasmus Kwashiorkor
Seen in infants less than 1 year of age

Seen in older children

(6 months to 3 years of age)
Total calorie deficit Protein deficit
No edema Edema is prominent

Voracious appetite

No apathy

Loss of appetite

Apathy
Severe muscle wasting Muscle wasting mild or absent
Prominent ribs Protuberant abdomen

No Fatty liver

No subcutaneous fat

Fatty liver

Subcutaneous fat preserved

Special features:

  1. Alert
  2. Loose wrinkled skin 
  3. Baggy pant appearance

Special features:

  1. Moon face
  2. Flaky paint dermatosis
  3. Flag sign

The image below shows Flag sign characterised by alternating bands of hypopigmented and normal pigmented areas on the hair strand.

 

The image below shows a child with an old wrinkled old man appearance.

 

The image highlights the differentiating clinical features between marasmus and kwashiorkor

questions.text:
A patient presents with complaints of colicky pain radiating from the loin to the groin and USG shows the presence of renal calculi. You have been asked to look for tenderness at the renal angle. Which of the following forms the boundaries of this angle?

USG - Ultrasound

choices.text: Lower border of 11th rib and medial border of psoas major
Lower border of 12th rib and medial border of psoas major
Lower border of 11th rib and lateral border of erector spinae
Lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of erector spinae

questions.solution:
The boundaries of renal angle are formed by the lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of the erector spinae muscle.

The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.text: Deriving sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon the partner, and producing cuts and cigarette burns on the partner's arms is best described as?
questions.solution:
Deriving sexual gratification by inflicting pain upon the partner, and producing cuts and cigarette burns on the partner's arms is best described as sexual sadism. It is seen more commonly in men. It develops due to early experiences of brutality in sex.

The sadist may bite, beat, whip, produce cuts or cigarette burns, etc on their sexual partner. In extreme cases, the victim's nipples may be bitten off, items such as a bottle or sticks are inserted into the vagina. Blunt trauma causing fractures and rupture of internal organs may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A - Voyeurism is the act of obtaining sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing, or engaging in sexual activity.

Option B - Fetichism is a form of sexual behavior in which gratification is associated with an abnormal stimulus which may be an object, activity, or part of the body.

Option D - Masochism is opposite to sadism. Sexual gratification is obtained by suffering the pain.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions may have the following ascitic fluid findings - Serum ascites albumin gradient  (SAAG) > 1.1g/dL and ascitic protein <2.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
Cirrhosis is characterized by SAAG >1.1 and ascitic protein < 2.5 g/dL.

Serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG):

  • Calculated by subtracting the ascitic albumin concentration from the serum albumin level.
  • Reflects the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids
  • SAAG ≥1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is due to increased pressure in the hepatic sinusoids. It reflects the presence of portal hypertension.
  • SAAG <1.1 g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension. It may be due to infection or malignancy.

Ascitic protein level analysis further helps in identifying the etiology, in cases with high SAAG (≥1.1):

  • ≥2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids are normal and are allowing the passage of protein into the ascites. eg. cardiac ascites
  • <2.5 g/dL indicates that the hepatic sinusoids have been damaged and scarred and no longer allow passage of protein. Eg. cirrhosis

The serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is the most reli­able method to differentiate causes of ascites due to portal hyper­tension from those not due to portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady is diagnosed with a femoral hernia. Which of the following structures lie immediately lateral to the ring through which the hernia is passing?
questions.solution:
A femoral hernia passes through a widened femoral ring. The structure lying immediately lateral to this ring is the femoral vein.

The femoral sheath is a distal prolongation of the extraperitoneal fascia. It is composed of transversalis fascia anteriorly and iliac fascia posteriorly. It encloses three compartments:

  • Medial compartment ie., the femoral canal containing lymphatics
  • Intermediate compartment containing the femoral vein
  • Lateral compartment containing the femoral artery

The femoral ring represents the widened, proximal end of the femoral canal. A femoral hernia protrudes through this femoral ring. Hence, immediately lateral to the femoral ring is the femoral vein. 

The boundaries of the femoral ring are:

  • Anteriorly: Inguinal ligament 
  • Posteriorly: Pectineal ligament, pectineus muscle, and its fascia 
  • Medially: Lateral edge of the lacunar ligament
  • Laterally: Femoral vein

Related Pearl: Anatomy of Femoral Canal

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. Which of the following imaging studies is the diagnostic procedure of choice to look for a  tumor that can lead to her condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic imaging procedure of choice to look for a possible tumor that can lead to myasthenia gravis is a chest CT to look for thymoma in the mediastinum.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction caused primarily by anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies (AChR). The thymus is thought to play a major role in this process. 75% of patients with AChR are found to have an abnormal thymus. A majority of them have thymic hyperplasia, while some have a thymic tumor called a thymoma. 

Thymoma is the most common mass found in the anterior mediastinum. It arises from the thymus gland and is usually seen in adults greater than 40 years of age. It can be identified by performing a chest X-ray, but this has now been replaced by CT as the diagnostic procedure of choice. A chest CT is also able to differentiate between thymoma and lymphoma.

Anti-AChR antibodies seen in myasthenia gravis block acetylcholine receptors at the post-synaptic membrane. Thus there are fewer ACh receptors available for the acetylcholine neurotransmitters to act on. This progressively decreases the force of muscle contraction. 

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Weakness and fatigability increase on repeated muscle contraction
  • Diplopia, ptosis - due to intraocular muscle weakness
  • Weakness while chewing and swallowing- due to facial, palatal, and pharyngeal muscle weakness
  • Proximal muscle weakness (eg. difficulty raising an arm to comb hair) 
  • Deep tendon reflexes are preserved

Some of the tests used for diagnosis are-

  • Ice-pack test - Improves ptosis (low temperature slows down ACh metabolism, making more available for action at the post-synaptic membrane)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test - reduction in action potential supports the diagnosis
  • Edrophonium chloride test - It is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor with rapid onset and short duration of action. Improvement in muscle strength with this drug supports the diagnosis.

The anti-AChR antibodies can be found in most patients, and it is considered the gold standard in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. Other auto-antibodies that can be found are anti-MuSK antibodies and anti-LRP4 antibodies.

The initial drug of choice is pyridostigmine, which is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor in the synaptic cleft.

After medical management, the patient should undergo chest CT to look for a thymic mass. Removal of this mass can reduce symptoms and decrease the need for steroids or second-line drugs. It has also been found to decrease the risk of exacerbations and hospitalization.

Other treatment options include immunosuppressive therapy (glucocorticoids, azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, etc.), plasmapheresis, and intravenous immunoglobulin therapy.

Important differential diagnoses to consider are Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (anti-voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies) and botulism (blocks presynaptic acetylcholine release), which are also disorders that affect the neuromuscular junction.

  • Lambert-Eaton is also a neuromuscular disorder in which the deep tendon reflexes are diminished and the muscle weakness improves with repeated contraction. It is a paraneoplastic syndrome seen in small cell lung cancer.
  • Botulism begins with abdominal pain and vomiting. It progresses to descending flaccid paralysis from the head down, and also shows cranial nerve palsies. However, there is no change in the strength of muscle contraction with repeated use.

Related Pearl: Locations of the Common Mediastinal Masses

  • Pericardial (most common)

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view that is not possible with FAST but is possible with eFAST?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography, used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. The following regions are scanned:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view (also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the mechanisms involved in the pathogenesis of edema?
questions.solution:
Increased plasma colloid osmotic pressure is not one of the mechanisms in the pathogenesis of edema. 

Edema is the accumulation of tissue fluid in the extracellular space, resulting from hemodynamic changes in the body. Normally, the outward hydrostatic pressure in the blood vessels is balanced by the inward pull of the colloid osmotic pressure exerted by plasma proteins. Any remaining fluid in the interstitial space is usually drained by the lymphatics into the thoracic duct, and thereby, back into the bloodstream. 

Edema results when there is an abnormality in any of these balancing forces. In heart failure, there is increased hydrostatic pressure in the venous system due to the inability of the heart to pump blood. This can result in edema which usually begins in the lower extremities.

In liver disease, there is a failure to synthesize adequate amounts of plasma proteins. On the other hand, in nephrotic disease of the kidney, there is excessive excretion of plasma proteins. Both of these conditions can result in decreased plasma colloid osmotic pressure. This normally acts as an inward pull on fluid from the interstitial spaces into the blood vessels.

Another mechanism of edema is in the setting of acute inflammation when there is increased vessel permeability, leading to fluid leaks into the interstitium.

Lymphatic obstruction due to infection or malignant infiltration can stop the normal tissue fluid drainage which results in fluid accumulation.

Renal failure is another cause of edema, which occurs due to the retention of sodium and water in large amounts, which ultimately increase the hydrostatic pressure within the vessels as mentioned above. 

Related Pearl: Edema: Key Points

Edema: Key Points

Edema is the result of the movement of fluid from the vasculature into the interstitial spaces; the fluid may be protein-poor (transudate) or protein-rich (exudate).

Causes:

  • Increased hydrostatic pressure (e.g., heart failure)
  • Decreased colloid osmotic pressure caused by reduced plasma albumin, either due to decreased synthesis (e.g., liver disease, protein malnutrition) or to increased loss (e.g., nephrotic syndrome)
  • Increased vascular permeability (e.g., inflammation), which is usually localized but may occur throughout the body in severe systemic inflammatory states such as sepsis
  • Lymphatic obstruction (e.g., infection or neoplasia)
  • Sodium and water retention (e.g., renal failure)

Related Pearl: Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Summary of Pathogenesis of Major Findings in Congestive Heart Failure

Abnormality

Cause

Weakness, exercise intolerance, fatigue

Left ventricle output inadequate to perfuse muscles; especially, failure of output to rise with exercise

Ankle, sacral edema

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased fluid transudation.

Hepatomegaly

Increased peripheral venous pressure →increased resistance to portal flow.

Pulmonary congestion

Increased pulmonary venous pressure →pulmonary venous distention and transudation of fluid into air spaces

Dyspnea on exertion

Failure of left ventricular output to rise during exercise → increased pulmonary venous pressure

Paroxysmal dyspnea, pulmonary edema

Probably a sudden failure of left heart output to keep up with the right heart output →acute rise in pulmonary venous and capillary pressure →transudation of fluid into air spaces.

Orthopnea

Normal pooling of blood in lungs in supine position added to the already congested pulmonary vascular system; increased venous return not put out by the left ventricle. (Relieved by sitting up, raising the head of the bed, lying on extra pillows.)

Cardiac dilation

Greater ventricular end-diastolic volume.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Marfan's syndrome are true?
  1. COL5A1 is the gene associated with Marfan's syndrome.
  2. It is associated with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  3. Aortic root aneurysm is associated with this condition
  4. It is associated with ectopia lentis in the downward and nasal direction.
  5. It is associated with scoliosis.
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are correct about Marfan's syndrome.

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens, myopia, flat cornea, retinal detachments, early cataracts, and glaucoma.

Other systemic manifestations include thoracic scoliosis, spontaneous pneumothorax, striae atrophicae in the skin. 

Diagnosis is based on criteria depending on the family history, aortic root X score, ectopia lentis, mitral valve prolapse, and presence of FBN1 mutation. 

Other statements: 

Statement 1: COL5A1 mutation affects type 5 collagen. This mutation is seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Statement 4: Downward and nasal dislocation of the lens (ectopia lentis) is seen in homocystinuria. 

 

Related Pearl: Genetic Syndromes associated with the Aortic Aneurysmal Disease

Syndrome

Gene mutated

Aneurysm

Marfan syndrome (MFS)

Dilatation and aneurysm of the aortic root, dilatation of the pulmonary artery, and dilatation or dissection of the descending thoracic or abdominal aorta

Arterial mid-sized rupture, specially involving thoracic or abdominal vessels. Frequently descending and abdominal aorta

Premature and aggressive aneurysms and dissections. Aneurysms distal to the aortic root

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with painful lesions as shown below. On examination, he has multiple deep ulcers over the shaft of the penis, which are non-indurated with soft ragged margins, as shown in the image given below. He also had unilateral tender lymphadenopathy. He has no history of fever or allergy to any medication. Which kit will you use to treat him?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of unilateral tender lymphadenopathy along with the image showing multiple non-indurated soft painful ulcers with ragged edges are suggestive of chancroid due to Hemophilus ducreyi. It is treated with a white kit.

The white kit or kit number 3 is for non-herpetic genital ulcers. It contains:

  • 1 vial of injection benzathine penicillin (2.4 MU) and
  • A tablet of azithromycin 1 gm single dose 

If the patient is allergic to penicillin, we have to give him a blue kit or kit number 4 which contains a tab. doxycycline 100 mg bid for 15 days and azithromycin 1 gm single dose. 

All sexual partners should be treated. Abstinence during treatment is preferred, or condoms should be used. 

Chancroid is predominantly seen in sexually active young individuals in the age group of 21–30 years. Its incubation period is 4–10 days.

Initially, erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation. It will suddenly become a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins. This is termed a soft chancre. 

Due to the direct contact between adjacent areas, multiple ulcers occur and are termed kissing ulcers. These ulcers have a size of 1–2 cm and have a friable base with yellow-grey exudate that bleeds when abraded. The lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months if left untreated.

Unilateral tender regional lymphadenopathy develops in most patients with chancroid. Within 1 to 2 weeks of the presenting papules will progress to manifest suppurative buboes that rupture spontaneously.

Note: Herpetic genital ulcers are often severe. They are multiple grouped vesicles that rupture easily leaving painful erosions and ulcers. They are associated with systemic symptoms such as fever and myalgia. A red kit containing 400 mg acyclovir tablets given 3 times daily for 7 days is provided for herpetic genital ulcers.

Other options: 

Option A: Green kit is used when there is abnormal vaginal discharge, burning while passing urine, increased frequency of micturition, or lower backache. 

Option C: Blue kit is also used for non-herpetic genital ulcers but is for those who are allergic to penicillin. It has doxycycline 100 mg instead. 

Option D: Black kit is used for inguinal bubo which presents as swelling in the inguinal region with preceding history of genital ulcer or discharge, fever, and malaise.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred for morning sickness along with pyridoxine?
questions.solution:
Doxylamine with pyridoxine is preferred in morning sickness. 

Doxylamine is a sedative H1 antihistamine with prominent anticholinergic activity. Its efficacy is improved when combined with pyridoxine (vitamin B6).

A bedtime administration of doxylamine 20 mg and pyridoxine 20 mg is given for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy. Major adverse effects are drowsiness, dry mouth, light-headedness, and constipation. 

Other options:

Option A- Promethazine is an H1 antihistaminic drug used for motion sickness. These drugs produce protection of 4- 6 hours but produce sedation and dryness of the mouth.

Option C- Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used for mountain sickness. It should be started 1-2 days before ascending to high altitude. Acetazolamide alters carbon dioxide transport in the lungs, tissues, and brain. It also decreases cerebrospinal fluid formation and lowers its pH.

Option D- Meclizine is a less sedative, less anticholinergic, and long-acting H1 antihistaminic drug. It is used for seasickness and protects nearly for a day.

questions.text: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary hypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of oligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequence

Potter's sequence is characterized by the triad of:

  • Renal agenesis
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis.

Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but other features like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen.

Option D: CHARGE syndrome: Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia, Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.text: An elderly man came to the hospital with a painful and swollen right hand as shown below. There is a laceration on the palmar surface. He says that he cut his hand while prying open some oyster shells last night. Medical history is significant for hemochromatosis. Which among the following media would be most suitable for the culture of the organisms belonging to this genus?

choices.text: Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium

questions.solution:
This patient developed rapidly progressive cellulitis with hemorrhagic bullae after an accidental injury from oyster shells. This clinical vignette and the image showing swelling, and hemorrhagic bulla strongly suggest an infection with Vibrio vulnificus. Among the given options, the most suitable plating medium for culturing this species would be TCBS or thiosulfate-citrate-bile salt-sucrose agar. 

Vibrio vulnificus is gram-negative, non-sporing, non-capsulated, and curved bacilli. They are motile by virtue of a polar flagellum. They are commonly found in marine environments and brackish waters.

Infection with Vibrio vulnificus occurs by two mechanisms-

  • Wound infection in marine environments or accidental injury while handling contaminated seafood (as in this patient).
  • Consumption of raw or undercooked oysters, mussels, shellfish, and other contaminated seafood. 

Clinically, severe and fatal infections due to V. vulnificus were found to occur more commonly in older patients and patients with underlying liver disease. Injuries will rapidly progress into hemorrhagic cellulitis. Ingestion of V. vulnificus will lead to penetration of the gastrointestinal mucosa and subsequent septicemia. 

Diagnosis can be established by culturing blood and wound swabs. Culture and isolation require special selective and enrichment media. They grow in aerobic environments at 16-40°C. They prefer higher pH (alkaline environments) and are halophilic. They are VP negative, ferment lactose, but not sucrose.

  • Widely preferred and used enrichment media include alkaline peptone water.
  • Routinely employed solid/plating media is thiosulphate citrate bile salts sucrose. In this medium, thiosulphate, citrate, bile and an alkaline pH suppress the growth of other bacteria. Sucrose fermentation by the vibrio turns the bromothymol blue indicator from green to yellow. Vibrio cholerae will form yellow colonies. Vibrio vulnificus may form colorless colonies. Vibrio parahemolyticus will form transparent colonies with a green center. 
  • PNC medium (containing peptone, 1.0% NaCl, cellobiose) inhibits the growth of V. parahaemolyticus and V. alginolyticus while promoting the growth of V. vulnificus strains.

Vibrio cholerae on TCBS agar-

questions.text: A soldier underwent a left above-knee amputation after a  terrorist attack with explosives. He was brought to your department for fixing a leg prosthesis. Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to reduce impairment with prostheses fall under the tertiary level of prevention. 

Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burn patients, and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Other options:

Option B- Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific intervention used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.

Option C- Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by specific protective measures, as well as measures promoting general health, well-being, and the quality of life of people.

Option D- Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken in this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education. Examples include discouraging harmful modes of lifestyle like smoking from early childhood, as it can lead to adult health problems.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child presents with a history of high fever unresponsive to antipyretics for the past five days. On examination, there is a congestion of the bulbar conjunctiva. A picture of his tongue and hands are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The images given show a strawberry tongue and erythema and edema of the palms. The clinical scenario and the images point to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease(KD).

Kawasaki's disease also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome is a vasculitis of unknown etiology. 

Clinical features include a high spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics. The fever can last between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. 

Diagnosis requires fever for at least 4 days and at least four of the five principal criteria. 

  1. Changes in extremities
    • Acute: erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
    • Subacute: periungual peeling of fingers, and toes in weeks 2 and 3.
  2. Polymorphous exanthematous rash.
  3. Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
  4. Erythema and cracking of lips, strawberry tongue, and/or erythema of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral.

Exclusion of other diseases with similar findings.

Myocarditis develops frequently in acute Kawasaki disease. It presents as tachycardia and reduced ventricular systolic function. The tachycardia will be disproportionate to the fever. Patients may develop coronary artery aneurysms in the 2nd to 3rd week of illness. They are generally asymptomatic and diagnosed on echocardiography. However, if large it can lead to death. Thus, echocardiography should be performed at diagnosis and after 1-2 weeks. 

Laboratory evaluation will reveal elevated leukocytes, platelets, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels. 

Treatment involves 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin as an infusion over 10-12 hours within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should be administered until the patient is afebrile. 

Option A: Pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus (GAS) primarily affects children between the ages of 5 and 15. The common symptoms reported by individuals with GAS pharyngitis include sudden onset of fever and a sore throat. Additional complaints may include headache, nausea/vomiting, and abdominal pain. During a physical examination, doctors may observe inflammation of the tonsils and pharynx with varying levels of exudate. Tender cervical lymph nodes (lymphadenitis), a red and swollen uvula, palatal petechiae, and occasionally a rash resembling scarlet fever may also be present. Treatment for GAS infections is highly effective with penicillin-based antibiotics such as ampicillin and amoxicillin

Option C: Measles infection is caused by the RNA virus belonging to the paramyxovirus family. It is characterized by fever, maculopapular rash, cough, coryza, and exudative conjunctivitis. Examination of the oral cavity would reveal Koplik spots, that are pathognomonic for measles. Typically, on the fourth day, a rash emerges accompanied by an increase in body temperature. The rash initially manifests as pale reddish spots located behind the ears, along the hairline, and on the back of the cheeks. It quickly develops into a rash characterized by both flat and raised reddish spots, extending to the face, neck, chest, arms, torso, thighs, and legs within the subsequent 2-3 days.

Option D - Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is characterized by fever, hypotension, sunburn-like rash, and end-organ damage. Features like renal insufficiency, coagulopathy, pancytopenia, and myositis may be present in TSS, which will not be seen in Kawasaki's disease. TSS occurs due to colonization by toxigenic strains like Staphylococcus aureus or group A streptococcus.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of the drugs given for post-operative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonia, not postoperative nausea and vomiting.

The drugs given for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) act by 

  • 5-HT3 antagonism
  • NK-1 antagonism
  • D2 antagonism

The 5- HT3 receptor mediates vomiting and is found in the gastrointestinal tract and the brain (area postrema). 5-HT3 antagonists like ondansetron and granisetron selectively block the serotonin 5-HT3 receptors, with little or no effect on dopamine receptors.

Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, an NK1 antagonist, has been found to reduce PONV perioperatively and is additive with ondansetron for this indication. 

Dopamine receptors, particularly D2 and D3 receptors when activated cause nausea and vomiting. Dopamine antagonists like metoclopramide and droperidol block the dopamine receptors at the chemo-receptor trigger zone, thereby reducing PONV.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient-specific: Female gender, non-smoking status, history of motion sickness/PONV
  • Anesthetic-specific: Nitrous oxide, volatile anesthetics, opioids
  • Surgery-specific: Increased duration of surgery, type of surgery

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine
  • Aprepitant

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

questions.text: A lady at 14 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain and persistent browny vaginal discharge for a few days. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than the period of gestation with a closed cervical os. Doppler ultrasound reveals non-audibility of the fetal heart sound which was audible before. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with 14 weeks of gestation presenting with abdominal pain, persistent browny vaginal discharge, smaller uterus for gestation, closed cervical os, non-audibility of the fetal heart sound in ultrasound is suggestive of missed miscarriage.

Missed miscarriage or early fetal demise is termed when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period.

Patients usually present with features of threatened miscarriage like dull pain or bleeding per vaginum followed by:

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • The uterus appears smaller in size (cessation of uterine growth)
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Closed cervical os
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac in real-time ultrasonography

Beyond 12 weeks, the retained fetus in the uterus becomes macerated and mummified. 

The expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival is termed abortion.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A- Inevitable miscarriage is the type of abortion where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option C- Threatened miscarriage is the type of abortion where the process of miscarriage has started but in a state from which recovery is possible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • On ultrasound:
    • Well-formed gestation ring
    • Presence of fetal cardiac motion 

Option D- Complete miscarriage is termed when products of conception are expelled en masse.

Features:

  • Abdominal pain subsides
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • The uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • Ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity

Note:

In incomplete miscarriage, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity.

  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Uterus smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • Patulous cervical os
  • Echogenic material (products of conception) within the cavity

In septic abortion, there will be clinical evidence of infection of the uterus and its contents.

Features:

  • Rise of the temperature of at least 100.4 F for >24 hours
  • Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge
  • Lower abdominal pain and tenderness

questions.text: To record a radial pulse, you apply sustained gentle pressure with the pads of the fingers just enough to palpate the pulse against the radius. Which of the following mechanoreceptors, that is present in the epidermis, responds to sustained pressure and touch?
questions.solution:
The mechanoreceptor that responds to sustained pressure and touch is the Merkel disc. It is a slow-adapting receptor made of expanded dendritic endings present in the epidermis. 

Other options-

Option B- Meissner's corpuscles respond to low-frequency vibration. They are rapidly adapting dendrites encapsulated in connective tissue present below the epidermis.  

Option C- Ruffini corpuscles respond to stretch and vibration. They are slow-adapting enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules that are present in the dermis of the skin.

Option D- Pacinian corpuscles respond to high-frequency vibration and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors. They are large encapsulated nerve endings with concentric layers of connective tissue that have an onion-skin appearance and are present in the dermis. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A young butcher presents with headache, vomiting, dizziness, visual impairment, and altered mental status. On performing a CT scan, ring-enhancing lesions are found, along with some nodular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a butcher with the given symptoms, along with the CT scan showing ring-enhancing lesions with some nodular calcifications, is suggestive of neurocysticercosis. This condition is caused by Taenia solium.

T. solium is also known as the pork tapeworm. Humans are the only definitive hosts for T. solium, whereas pigs are the usual intermediate host. When humans consume undercooked pork containing cysticerci, they acquire the infection leading to intestinal tapeworms.

Cysticerci can be found anywhere in the body but are most commonly detected in the brain, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), skeletal muscle, subcutaneous tissue, or the eye. Neurocysticercosis usually presents with neurological manifestations like seizures and hydrocephalus. Symptoms of increased intracranial pressure are often seen.

Diagnosis is made by the detection of eggs or proglottids in the stool. More sensitive methods like ELISA and PCR may also be used. Clinical diagnosis can only be made with the help of neuroimaging findings and exposure history.

Major neuroimaging findings include cystic lesions with or without enhancement, nodular calcifications, focal enhancing lesions, or multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Brain parenchymal cysticerci are treated with a combination of praziquantel and albendazole. These drugs cause inflammatory responses around the deadly parasite, and therefore glucocorticoids should also be started along with antihelminthic.

The image given below shows an MRI of the brain that shows multiple cysts containing scolices in a patient with neurocysticercosis.

Other options:

Option B: Only the adult forms of T. saginata develop in humans and not the cysticerci. Therefore, it cannot cause cysticercosis in humans.

Option C: Bacteroides spp. is a causative organism for brain abscesses which are seen on a contrast-enhanced CT as ring-enhancing lesions. However, such a brain abscess is usually secondary to otitis media, mastoiditis, or paranasal sinusitis. This patient does not have any other disease, which makes brain abscess less likely.

The image given below shows a brain abscess.

Option D: Toxoplasma gondi causes toxoplasmosis. It is one of the most common causes of secondary CNS infection in AIDS patients. It usually occurs as a late complication when CD4+ T-cell counts <200/μL. It presents with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI shows ring enhancement lesions in the brain due to inflammation and central necrosis in the lesions.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Differential diagnoses for ring-enhancing lesions include:

  • Brain abscess
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Central nervous system lymphoma
  • Tuberculoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not among the leading causes of death in the 1-4 years age group in countries with the below population pyramid?
questions.solution:
The given population pyramid shows a bulge in the middle and has a narrower base and is suggestive of developed countries. Diarrheal disease is not a leading cause of death in the 1-4 years age group in developed countries. All the other options are the leading causes of death in this group. 

Accidental deaths are the leading cause of death from the age of one year in developed countries, while deaths from infectious diseases are quite rare. Identified groups of home accidents are:

  • Fall from unprotected stairs and balconies
  • Suffocation
  • Burns and scalds
  • Poisoning

Most accidents are preventable. Other leading causes are congenital anomalies and malignant neoplasms. These are not easy to prevent or cure.

A population pyramid with a broad base and a tapering top is typical of developing countries. Diarrheal disease, respiratory infection followed by communicable diseases like whooping cough and measles are the leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age children in developing countries. When these diseases are combined with malnutrition, they have high case fatality rates.

Leading cause of death in 1-4 years of age group
Developing countries Developed countries
Diarrhea Accidents
Respiratory infection Congenital anomalies
Malnutrition Malignant neoplasm
Infectious diseases Influenza
Febrile disease Pneumonia
Accidents and injuries  

 

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?

choices.text: B  fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.solution:
The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve. It leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact. A-fibers (includes the motor fibers) are affected.

The susceptibility of the nerve fibers to pressure is A>B>C.

This is responsible for Saturday night or Sunday morning paralysis.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child suffered a cut on his hand while playing. An anxious mother brought him to the hospital when she noticed that the bleeding from the wound did not stop even after half an hour. Lab investigation reports are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Platelet count- normal
Fibrinogen levels- normal
Prothrombin time- normal
Activated partial thromboplastin time- prolonged
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of profuse bleeding from minor wounds, prolonged APTT, with normal PT and platelet count suggests Von Willebrand disease as the most probable diagnosis.

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder which occurs due to deficiency of or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is stored in endothelial cells and in platelet Weibel-Palade bodies. It has two important functions:

  • Adhesion of the platelets to injured subendothelium
  • Carrier protein for factor VIII and preventing its degradation

Clinical features include spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia, after dental extractions and surgeries including tonsillectomies. Most individuals are asymptomatic otherwise. Type 3 VWD is the most severe form and presents with symptoms like joint bleeds, similar to those seen in mild hemophilia.

Diagnosis

  • Normal platelet count
  • Prolonged BT
  • Normal PT
  • Prolonged aPTT

Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF) in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

Classification

Three types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. 

Type 3 disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.

Treatment: Desmopressin for type 1 vWD stimulates the release of vWF and Factor VIII from the endothelial stores. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) concentrates in cases of type 2 and type 3 von Willebrand disease.

Other options-

Options A and B: Bernard–Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia are caused due to deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor and deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor respectively. In both these conditions, PTT is normal, with only an increase in bleeding time.

Option C: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is characterized by the pentad of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, abnormal renal function, and central nervous system (CNS). Occurs due to deficiency of ADAMTS13.
