questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with tingling and weakness in his right hand and left foot for the past 4 days. He is also a known case of asthma and is on treatment.  On examination, you notice that the patient has a purpura over his body. Laboratory investigations reveal marked eosinophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia in an asthmatic patient is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and is characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, granuloma formation, and vasculitis.

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are

  • Initial non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss
  • Severe attacks of asthma, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis
  • Mononeuritis multiplex- It is a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerve areas. Patients complain of pain, tingling, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas.
  • Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules

Laboratory investigations will show eosinophilia. They also show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, or α2-globulins. Some patients may be positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Histopathology shows the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Daily cyclophosphamide and prednisolone, followed by azathioprine or methotrexate, can be used for the treatment. Mepolizumab, a monoclonal antibody against IL-5, is the drug recently approved by the FDA for Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Note: A rare side effect following the use of montelukast and zafirlukast is the development of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with microscopic polyangiitis can have symptoms of mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous purpura. However, features of asthma and eosinophilia make microscopic polyangiitis less likely as the diagnosis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but patients do not have eosinophilia. In addition to this, it does not affect bronchial or pulmonary arteries.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) also has symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (sinusitis, septal perforation, otitis media), lower respiratory tract involvement (hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest discomfort), and glomerulonephritis. However, eosinophilia is not a feature of this disease.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
Vessels affected Small and medium vessel vasculitis Small vessel vasculitis
Principal organs involved

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

GIT

Skin (cutaneous vasculitis)

Nerves (Mononeuritis multiplex)

Upper respiratory tract

Lungs (hemoptysis)

Kidney

Eye

Skin

Upper airway involvement

 Less common

More common

(Sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, septal perforation)
Nodular cavities in the lungs Absent Present
ANCA pANCA (mainly) cANCA(mainly)
Granuloma Absent Present
Necrosis Present Present
Kidney Glomerulonephritis Glomerulonephritis

questions.text:
The actions of the muscle attached to the area marked by the red arrow are:

1. Depression of mandible
2. Protrusion of mandible
3. Side to side movement of the jaw
4. Elevation of mandible
5. Retraction of mandible
questions.solution:
The pterygoid fovea of the mandible is indicated by the red arrow. The parts of the mandible are shown in the image below.

The marked area on the given image of the mandible is the pterygoid fovea, where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of the jaw.

The lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted into the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

The muscles of mastication are:

  • Lateral pterygoid muscle:

    • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate
    • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, capsule, and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint
    • Nerve supply - Nerve to lateral pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve

  • Medial pterygoid muscle:

    • Origin - Deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. Superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and pyramidal process of palatine bone
    • Insertion- It is inserted into the medial surface of the ramus, near the angle of the mandible
    • Nerve supply - Nerve to medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve


Masseter muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from a thick aponeurosis from the maxillary process of the zygomatic bone and zygomatic arch.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible and coronoid process
  • Nerve supply - Masseteric nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve


Temporalis muscle:

  • Origin - It arises from the temporal fossa and deep surface of the temporal fascia.
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the coronoid process and to the anterior border of the ramus of the mandible up to the third molar tooth
  • Nerve supply - Anterior, middle, and posterior deep temporal nerves, branches of the mandibular nerve

Related Pearl: Muscles of mastication

Muscles Origin Insertion Action
Lateral pterygoid

Upper head - Infratemporal surface, sphenoid bone

Lower head - Lateral pterygoid plate

Upper head - Pterygoid fovea 

Lower head - TMJ capsule and articular disc

Depresses mandible (with suprahyoid muscles)

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(Side to side) movements
Medial pterygoid

Superficial head - Maxilla

Deep head - Lateral pterygoid plate, Palatine bone

Angle of mandible

Ramus of mandible behind mandibular foramen

Elevates mandible  

Jaw protrusion

Grinding(side to side) movements
Temporalis

Temporal fossa

Temporal fascia

Ramus of mandible

Coronoid process

Elevates mandible

Side-to-side movements

Jaw retraction
Masseter Zygomatic arch Ramus of mandible

Elevates mandible

Jaw protrusion

questions.text: A woman was diagnosed with Stage 3 gestational trophoblastic neoplasia as per the classification by the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO). Which of the following images represents her stage?
questions.solution:
According to the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO), metastases to lungs are considered stage III gestational trophoblastic neoplasia(GTN), represented by image 3.

FIGO Stage  Extent
Stage I   GTN confined to the uterus

Stage II 

 GTN extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structures (adnexa, vagina, broad ligament)
Stage III  GTN extends to the lungs, with or without known genital tract involvement
Stage IV  All other metastatic sites

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) refers to the aggressive invasion of the endometrium and myometrium by trophoblast cells. It includes invasive mole, gestational choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumors, and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors. GTN is diagnosed based on elevated β-hCG levels. FIGO criteria for diagnosis of GTN:

  • Persistence of β-hCG level plateau in 4 measurements for 3 weeks or longer
  • Rise in β-hCG levels in 3 or more consecutive measurements done weekly, over a period of 2 weeks or longer
  • Elevated β-hCG level for 6 months or more
  • Histologic diagnosis of choriocarcinoma 

A modified prognostic scoring system by the WHO distinguishes patients at low risk for therapeutic failure from those at high risk. Treatment for the low-risk disease is chemotherapy with methotrexate, while those with high-risk disease are treated with etoposide, methotrexate, and dactinomycin alternating with cyclophosphamide and vincristine (EMA/CO) chemotherapy.

questions.text: A child with blunt trauma to the abdomen is brought to the emergency department and found to have a splenic injury. He requires a total splenectomy. Which of the following organisms is not a cause of serious infection that can occur after splenectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Moraxella catarrhalis is not a cause of serious infection that can occur after total splenectomy in the above patient.

The most dreaded complication of a total splenectomy is overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). The spleen normally protects against infections by encapsulated bacteria. When patients undergo total splenectomy, they are at risk for postsplenectomy septicemia.

The microorganisms that can cause OPSI are as follows:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Escherichia coli

Management of splenic injury is aimed at conserving the spleen as far as possible due to the rare but fatal nature of OPSI. However, sometimes a splenectomy is unavoidable and it becomes important to protect such patients from this complication.

The current standard of care in asplenic patients involves immunization with the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) 8 weeks later. They should also be administered the H. influenzae type b conjugate and the quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate ACWY vaccine series. In the case of elective splenectomy, these vaccinations should be completed 10-12 weeks prior to surgery or at least 14 days before. In the case of emergency splenectomy, vaccination should be carried out 14 days after surgery to improve compliance.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

questions.text: An 8-week-old child presents with watering and discharge of the eye. On performing the fluorescein dye disappearance test, the dye that is placed into the inferior cul-de-sac does not drain into the nose within 5 minutes. Which of the following is the next step of management that can be done in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The next step that can be done in this child is massaging over the lacrimal sac, also known as Criggler's massage.

The initial treatment involves performing nasolacrimal massage, typically 2-3 times daily, along with cleansing the eyelids using warm water and applying topical antibiotics. To initiate nasolacrimal massage, the index finger is placed over the common canaliculus to prevent reflux, and then gently rolled over the lacrimal sac in a downward direction.

Nasolacrimal duct obstruction is the most common disease of the lacrimal system. It usually presents in the first few weeks or months of life as excessive tearing and ocular discharge. It mostly occurs due to incomplete canalization of the duct.

Typically, diagnosis is established through a combination of patient history and physical examination. In cases where symptoms are intermittent, the presence of an obstruction can be confirmed using the fluorescein dye disappearance test. During this test, one drop of fluorescein-stained saline is placed in the inferior cul-de-sac of patient's eye, and any excess tears are carefully removed. Under normal conditions, the dye should fully drain into the nose within 5 minutes, indicating an unobstructed passage. However, in the presence of an obstruction, the dye fails to completely clear, suggesting a blockage.

If a case does not resolve after massaging by the age of 6 to 10 months, lacrimal duct probing is done and the probe is pushed through the obstruction. The patency of the duct is then checked using fluorescein-stained saline. In cases where symptoms are mild to moderate, the probing procedure may be postponed until the child reaches the age of 12 to 18 months, or possibly even 24 months.

If probing fails, other treatment options include intubation with silastic tubing with or without balloon dilatation of the nasolacrimal duct and dacryocystorhinostomy.

questions.text: A study on mood stabilizers shows that a new drug X works faster to stabilize mood than the standard drug Y. The results are statistically significant. The study is carried out 100 different times and shows such significant differences 95 times. What is the likelihood of a type II error?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of a type II error here is 5%.

A type II error is the probability of rejecting the alternate hypothesis when it is true. It is also known as a beta error.

In this case, it is the chance of saying the experimental drug does not work better than the standard drug, while it actually does. This happened in 5/100 studies, hence the likelihood of a type II error (beta) is 5%.

Note: Power = 1- beta. Here, the power of the study is 95%.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with sudden onset chest pain, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. His heart rate is 122/min, jugular venous pressure is elevated, and lung fields are clear. He underwent surgery three weeks ago and is on complete rest. He was treated for deep vein thrombosis 6 months ago. His ECG shows S1Q3T3 changes. Which of the following statements are correct regarding the diagnosis.
  1. Pericardial friction rub present on auscultation.
  2. Modified Well's score is 8.5 in this patient.
  3. Chest CT is the principal imaging test for diagnosis.
  4. Pulmonary angiography is the principal imaging test for diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The statements 2 and 3 are correct.

This patient is most likely suffering from acute pulmonary embolism (PE) as evidenced by his clinical symptoms of acute cor pulmonale (right heart dysfunction), ECG showing S1Q3T3 changes, and modified Well's score of >4.

This patient has a modified Well's score of 8.5 (Pulmonary embolism is likely, if the score is more than 4):

  • Heart rate >100 beats/min- score 1.5
  • Hemoptysis- score 1
  • Recent history of immobilization due to surgery- score 1.5
  • Past history of deep vein thrombosis- score 1.5
  • Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely- score 3

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, representative of a prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow), Q wave in lead III (red arrow), and an inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow) 

 

CT of the chest with intravenous contrast is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of PE. It also helps to visualize the chambers of the heart. It can also help in identifying alternative diagnoses like emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, pulmonary mass, etc.

Lung scanning is the second-line diagnostic test for PE, used in patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. Perfusion scan defect indicates absent or decreased blood flow.

MR pulmonary angiography is a reliable test to identify deep vein thrombosis. It may detect large proximal PE, but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE.

Pulmonary angiography- Because of the invasive nature of the test and availability of the chest CT scans, it is not commonly used in the diagnosis of PE. It is reserved for patients with technically unsatisfactory chest CTs.

Echocardiography- Most patients with PE have a normal echocardiogram, therefore, it is not a reliable test. However, it can be used to detect other conditions that commonly mimic PE like acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

 

Differentials: 

Pleural effusion is a collection of fluid within the pleural space because of various etiologies (infectious, malignant, cardiopulmonary). It is characterized by pleuritic chest pain, progressive dyspnea, and cough. Respiratory system examination reveals:

  • stony dullness on percussion, decreased tactile fremitus, and diminished breath sounds on the side of the effusion
  • pleural friction rub may be heard on auscultation
  • ECG: normal or non-specific findings such as low voltage QRS, axis deviation, and/or electrical alternans

Acute pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardial sac and is characterized by pleuritic chest pain as seen in this patient with PE. However, examination findings reveal a pericardial friction rub, and ECG shows diffuse ST-segment elevation and PR-segment depression.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old primigravida at 24 weeks presents with decreased fetal movements. During the consultation, she collapses because of low blood pressure. An ultrasound showed fetal demise. Investigations revealed low platelets, increased fibrin degradation products, and prolonged bleeding and clotting time. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
  1. It occurs due to tissue factor release and endothelial injury.
  2. It is associated with Waterhouse-Friderichson syndrome.
  3. During septic shock, this condition occurs due to TNF and interleukin 1.
  4. It is also known as consumptive coagulopathy.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a primigravida presenting with fetal demise, hypotension, thrombocytopenia, and deranged bleeding and clotting times is highly suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation. All the given statements (1, 2, 3, and 4) are true regarding DIC.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a thrombo-hemorrhagic disorder in which there is widespread clotting in the body. The most common causes of DIC are obstetric complications like amniotic fluid embolisms and retained products of conception. Major trauma, sepsis, and certain malignancies are also common causes.

DIC results due to endothelial injury or release of tissue factor and other procoagulants. TNF (tissue necrosis factor) is an important mediator of endothelial injury. It can promote the expression of tissue factor on endothelial cells and also stimulate the adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium, causing further damage and clotting (statement 1). In septic shock, TNF and interleukin-1 (IL-1) are important causative factors of DIC (statement 3).

These factors result in the occlusion of the microvasculature by thrombi. Large-scale clotting leads to the consumption of platelets and clotting factors. Hence, it is also called consumptive coagulopathy (statement 4). 

The clinical diagnosis is supported by the following laboratory findings:

  • low platelet count
  • prolonged bleeding time
  • prolonged PT/aPTT
  • elevated fibrin degradation products
  • elevated D-dimer

Two common named syndromes associated with DIC:

  • Waterhouse-Friderichson syndrome caused by meningococcal septicemia. It can result in microthrombi that block the adrenal vasculature and ultimately result in adrenal hemorrhage due to DIC (statement 2).
  • Kasabach-Merritt syndrome is a type of DIC that is seen with giant hemangiomas. Recurrent bleeding and clotting in these fragile vessels results in DIC.

Related Pearl: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with right-sided facial weakness and ear pain. On examination, she has vesicles over her skin and auricle as shown in the image below. She has no other symptoms or comorbidities. Which of the following cranial nerves is predominantly involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
The cranial nerve predominantly involved in this patient is the facial nerve.

The given clinical scenario with right-sided facial weakness, ear pain, and vesicles in the external auditory canal are suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome. 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also called herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

The causative agent, the varicella-zoster virus, is a double-stranded DNA virus. Initial infection with the virus causes chickenpox, associated with disseminated vesicular rash and fever. The virus remains latent in a cranial nerve or dorsal root ganglia and subsequently gets reactivated in times of physiological stress or immunocompromised states. This is known as herpes zoster or Ramsay Hunt syndrome when facial paralysis occurs.

It is characterized by a classic triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle. Pain is the most common presenting symptom.

Hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo can occur due to vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) involvement, as a result of its proximity to the facial nerve. Involvement of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) results in hoarseness and aspiration. Vesicles develop after the onset of neurological symptoms and are seen over the auricle and along the affected side of the face, scalp, palate, and tongue.

The trigeminal, glossopharyngeal, and hypoglossal nerves can also be involved, in immunocompromised patients.

A Tzanck smear performed on fluid obtained from the vesicles shows multinucleated giant cells using a Giemsa stain, methylene blue, or Wright's stain. MRI can demonstrate inflammation near the geniculate ganglion of the affected facial nerve.

Management includes the administration of antivirals like acyclovir or valacyclovir, to help prevent long-term complications and treatment of pain with NSAIDs or opioid analgesics.

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache. Examination reveals localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, and bladder incontinence. On x-ray, paradiscal destruction of vertebrae is present.  Which of the following is the best management for the above patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache, localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, incontinence of his bladder, and paradiscal destruction of vertebrae seen on X-ray is likely to have Pott's paraplegia. Anterolateral decompression and antitubercular treatment are the best management for the above patient with Pott's paraplegia.

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The other patterns include central, posterior, and non-osseous involvement. 

Management of Pott’s paraplegia includes conservative management or surgery. 

Anti-tubercular chemotherapy forms the mainstay of treatment. The spine is put to absolute rest by a sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso- lumbar spine. If paraplegia improves, conservative treatment is continued. Bracing is continued for a period of about 6 to 12 months.

Surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Recurrence of the disease after treatment
  • Rapid onset paraplegia

Surgeries for Pott’s paraplegia include:

  • Antero-lateral decompression- surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris
  • Costotransversectomy- surgery indicated for paravertebral abscess
  • Laminectomy- indicated when the posterior parts of vertebrae are involved
  • Radical debridement and arthrodesis (Hongkong operation)

questions.text: The image below shows the most commonly used surgical incisions in abdominal surgery. “Mercedes-Benz” extension refers to an extension of which of the following incisions?
questions.solution:
Mercedes-Benz extension refers to an extension of the incision labeled 1 in the above image, which is the chevron incision. It is shown below as a red dotted line extending upward from the chevron incision.

 

The chevron incision is also known as the bilateral subcostal incision/ rooftop incision. It is used to provide surgical access to the organs of the upper abdomen such as the liver and pancreas as well as the diaphragm. An upward extension of this incision (shown in the figure above) is known as the Mercedes-Benz extension, mimicking the logo of the car manufacturer of the same name. This extension provides even further access to the upper abdomen and lower part of the mediastinum, and is used primarily in liver transplant surgery or in case there is an epigastric pathology that has to be accessed.

Other options-

Option (A): The incision labeled 4 is the Pfannenstiel incision. It is a transverse incision made above the pubic symphysis and is used for pelvic procedures - most commonly during cesarean sections. 

Option (B): The incision labeled 2 is the paramedian incision. This is used for abdominal procedures. However, it is being replaced by transverse incisions, to reduce injury to vessels and nerves that also run transversely. The paramedian incision also restricts access to the opposite side of the abdomen, and so it is used very rarely in modern surgery.

Option (D): The incision labeled 3 is the McBurney incision/Gridiron incision. It is an oblique incision that is made one-third of the way from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. It is the classical incision used during open appendicectomy.

The image below shows all the important incisions used in abdominal surgery-

Other incicions:

Midline incision is the most common incision used for laparotomy. It is a vertical incision that follows the linea alba which is particularly favored in diagnostic laparotomy. It allows wide access to most of the abdominal cavity.

Battle incision is a lower right paramedian incision but placed more laterally than the standard paramedian incision. It is suitable for dealing with acute appendicitis and pathologies in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen.

Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid-inguinal line. 

Transverse incision is a supraumbilical transverse incision offers excellent exposure of the upper abdomen. A transverse incision may be superior to a midline incision in terms of recovery and complications postoperatively.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The shown forceps have no catch and have fenestrated blades suggestive of ovum forceps.

Ovum forceps are used to remove the products of conception in dilation and evacuation without crushing the conceptus. Other uses are:

  • Removal of molar tissue from hydatidiform mole
  • Removal of small uterine polyp

Uterine wall injuries are minimal due to the absence of a catch. It is introduced with the blades closed and then opened inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement facilitates the detachment of the products from the uterine wall and minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

The following image shows the ovum forceps. 

Other options:

Option A- Sponge holding forceps are used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during any abdominal or vaginal operations
  • Toilet vulva, vagina, and perineum before and following delivery
  • Hold the membranes if it threatens to tear during delivery of the placenta
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage procedures

The following image shows the sponge holding forceps. 

Option C- Lane's tissue forceps are used to:

  • Hold parietal wall for retraction during abdominal operations with transverse incision (hysterectomy)
  • Hold the polyp or fibroid in polypectomy or myomectomy surgery
  • Hold towel during draping

The following image shows Lane's tissue forceps. 

Option D- Allis tissue forceps are used to:

  • Catch the anterior lip of the cervix in a dilation and evacuation procedure
  • Hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during repair
  • Catch hold margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, and vaginal mucosa during repair
  • Catch hold the torn ends of the external sphincter ani before suture repair of complete perineal tear

The following image shows Allis tissue forceps. 

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colorful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Other options:

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely.

Option D: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behavior. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

questions.text:
Identify the correct sequence of doffing the PPE kit.
  1. Remove outer gloves and perform hand hygiene.
  2. Remove shoe covers only by touching the other surface and perform hand hygiene.
  3. Remove eyepiece by holding the straps and perform hand hygiene.
  4. Remove gown slowly by holding the gown at the waist and pulling, without touching the outer surface.
  5. Remove inner gloves and perform hand hygiene.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of doffing (removing) the PPE kit is 2, 1, 3, 4, 5.

Preparation for doffing the PPE:

  • To be performed only in the designated area
  • Check for any leak or soiling
  • The doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean
  • All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin
  • Hand hygiene must be performed after every step

Steps of doffing the PPE:

  • Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes.
  • Disinfect the gloves
  • Remove and discard shoe covers
  • Disinfect and remove the outer pair of gloves
  • Disinfect inner gloves
  • Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from the back handle. Discard it.
  • Remove hood and cover all (gown)
    • Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side of the waist
    • Roll the arms out one by one
  • Disinfect and remove inner gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves
  • Remove and discard N-95 mask
  • Disinfect gloves
  • Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes
  • Disinfect and remove gloves
  • Perform hand hygiene
  • Wipe the shoes on the sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at the exit
  • Exit the doffing area and take a shower

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for severe upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago.  CT scan shows a 7cm lesion near the pancreas. The diagnosis of a pancreatic pseudocyst in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects is made.  What is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach.

Interventions in pseudocyst are required when:

  • Complicated by infection
  • Presence of a mass effect 
  • Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm
  • Recurrence following the previous resection

Pancreatic pseudocysts are fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging during follow-up. The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst.

They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction. They can present with an epigastric mass, pain abdomen, early satiety, nausea, and vomiting. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

Characteristic features of pancreatic pseudo­cysts include high amylase levels associated with the absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.

Observation is the preferred treatment in:

  • Asymptomatic patients
  • Pseudocysts smaller than 4 cm in diameter (6 cm according to Bailey)
  • Located on the tail
  • No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct

Endoscopic drainage is usually curative and surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or if:

  • In close contact with the stomach: Cystogastrostomy
  • In close contact with the duodenum: Cystoduodenostomy

In cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.

The image below shows the procedure involved in a cystogastrostomy-


Other options:

Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy (Option-B) is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach nor to the duodenum.

Observation and symptomatic management (Option-D) cannot be the line of management for a case of pancreatic pseudocyst of size more than 6cm and especially when the patient has symptoms secondary to gastric obstruction.  

Percutaneous drainage (Option-C) to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is done only in septic patients with infected pseudocyst fluid.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient comes with swelling of face and lips after he heard the passing of his dog as shown in the image. He was administered icatibant. What is the likely mechanism of action of the drug prescribed to the boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hereditary angioedema.

Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema.

The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. 

Both icatibant and ecallantide are administered subcutaneously.

A common side effect is a local reaction at the injection site (redness, bruising, swelling, burning, itching, etc.). Other side effects include fever, elevated transaminase, dizziness, nausea, headache, or rash. 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is due to an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitors. Patients with HAE usually present with episodic attacks that begin during childhood that became more severe during adolescence.

There may be symptoms before the episodes occur, such as sudden mood changes, anxiety, sensory changes, or exhaustion may also occur for several hours. In one-third of patients, attacks are precipitated by trauma-like pressure. 

Symptoms are referable to 3 prominent sites:

  • Subcutaneous tissues like face, hands, arms, legs, genitals, and buttocks
  • Abdominal organs like the stomach, intestines, bladder, and kidneys. This manifests as vomiting, diarrhea, or paroxysmal colicky pain
  • The upper airway (larynx) and tongue, which results in laryngeal edema and upper airway obstruction

The swelling is usually unresponsive to antihistamines.

Recent Update: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently approved another plasma kallikrein inhibitor, berotralstat, as the first oral drug for the prevention and treatment of hereditary angioedema.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of various types of Angioedema

questions.text:
A male patient with a history of hepatitis B infection for a year presents with worsening confusion for 2 days and yellowing of the eyes for the past 5 days. Examination reveals flapping tremors and ascites. The lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the best step in the management of this patient?

Prothrombin time: 30 sec

HBsAg: Positive

HDV RNA: Positive

Serum bilirubin: 10 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ascites, encephalopathy, jaundice and prolonged prothrombin time (PT) in the setting of superinfection with hepatitis D virus is suggestive of fulminant hepatic failure. A liver transplant is the best step in the management of this patient.

Fulminant hepatitis /massive hepatic necrosis is a rare complication of viral hepatitis. It is seen primarily in hepatitis B, D, and E. Hepatitis B accounts for more than half of fulminant cases of viral hepatitis and can be associated with HDV infection and underlying chronic hepatitis C. Hepatitis E causes fulminant hepatitis in pregnant women.

This patient's history with clinical signs of confusion along with jaundice and ascites suggests hepatic failure with encephalopathy. The liver is usually shrunken. Cerebral edema is commonly seen. Brainstem compression, gastrointestinal bleeding, sepsis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse, and renal failure are complications that can be fatal. 

The mortality rate is extremely high but patients who survive may have a complete recovery. Liver transplantation is lifesaving in affected patients.

Other Options:

Option A: N-acetylcysteine therapy is indicated in acetaminophen overdose. 

Option B: Glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay of management in autoimmune hepatitis. 

Option C: Parenteral administration of vitamin K will not correct prolonged prothrombin time in cases of severe hepatocellular injury,

questions.text: A 26-year-old nursing mother presents with pain in her left breast. On examination of the breast, a tender, non-fluctuant swelling was present. The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed as shown in the image below. Her WBC count is 13000/mm3. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a nursing mother presenting with a tender, non-fluctuant swelling in the breast, along with elevated total leukocyte count, and the image shown above are suggestive of acute mastitis. The drug of choice for acute mastitis is dicloxacillin.

Dicloxaciilin is a penicillinase resistant penicillin. 500 mg is administered every 6 hours for 7 days. For patients who are allergic to penicillin, erythromycin can be used.

Acute mastitis is caused by infection with Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans commonly. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum. Poor nursing, maternal fatigue, and crackled nipple are some of the risk factors.

Clinical features of acute mastitis include generalized malaise, nausea, vomiting, headache, high fever with chills, severe pain, and tender swelling in the breast. On examination, the skin overlying the swelling will be red, hot, and flushed, and will feel tense. 

Microscopic examination of breast milk will show a leukocyte count of more than 106/mL and a bacterial count of more than 103/mL. An abscess can form if there is variable destruction of breast tissues.

Other steps in management include:

  • Breast support
  • Plenty of oral fluids
  • Breastfeeding is continued with good attachment
  • Nursing initiated on the unaffected side
  • The infected site is emptied manually with each feed
  • Analgesics like Ibuprofen
  • Maintained milk flow by breastfeeding

The incidence of acute mastitis can be reduced by washing hands before breastfeeding and cleaning the nipples before and after each feed to keep them dry.

questions.text:
A young lady who regularly takes oral contraceptive pills came with a positive urine pregnancy test. Which of the following drugs might be implicated in contraception failure?
  1. Rifampin
  2. Ketoconazole
  3. Erythromycin
  4. Phenytoin
  5. Nevirapine
questions.solution:
1, 4, and 5 can be implicated in contraceptive failures.

Rifampin, phenytoin, and nevirapine are microsomal enzyme inducers. They significantly increase the metabolism of oral contraceptives which decreases their pharmacological action. This may result in contraceptive failure. 

Some drugs interact with DNA and increase the synthesis of microsomal enzyme protein, especially cytochrome P-450. As a result, the rate of metabolism of the inducing drug itself (autoinduction) and/or some other coadministered drugs is accelerated.

Different inducers are relatively selective for certain cytochrome P-450 isoenzyme families, e.g.:

  • Anticonvulsants (phenobarbitone, phenytoin, carbamazepine), rifampin, and glucocorticoids induce CYP3A isoenzymes.
  • Phenobarbitone and rifampin also induce CYP2D6 and CYP2C8/9.
  • Carbamazepine and rifampin, in addition, induce CYP2C19 and CYP1A1/2.
  • Isoniazid and chronic alcohol consumption induce CYP2E1.
  • Other enzyme inducers are chronic alcoholism, nevirapine, griseofulvin, and DDT.

While azole antifungals like ketoconazole, macrolides like erythromycin bind to heme iron in CYP450 and inhibit the metabolism of many drugs.

questions.text:
Match the following X-rays and their diagnoses.

A. Monteggia fracture
B. Torus fracture
C. Greenstick fracture
D. Galeazzi fracture
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C. 

Torus fractures occur due to 'buckling' of the metaphyseal cortex as a result of compression. Due to the presence of malleable bone and a thick protective periosteum, long bone injuries result in deformation without a break in the cortex. 

The X-ray will appear as bulging of the cortex. 

The following image shows a torus fracture. 

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation involves a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. 

The following image shows a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation involves a fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. 

The following image shows a Monteggia fracture-dislocation

 

Greenstick fractures are partial-thickness fractures. They mostly occur in the pediatric population. Here, the cortex and periosteum are interrupted only on one side, but are intact on the other side. This is because children's bones are not yet ossified and mostly consist of pliable cartilage that is able to bow and bend under stress that would normally cause fractures in adult bones. In addition, the periosteum is thicker and more active which reduces the chances of open fractures. 

They usually occur in long bones, particularly the upper limb due to falling on an outstretched hand.

The below image depicts both forearm bone (radius and ulna) fractures. The cortex and periosteum are interrupted on one side but are uninterrupted on the other side.  

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.  

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location

Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: A 38-year-old businessman came with a complaint of difficulty in falling asleep for a few weeks.  He recently closed his business due to large unexpected debt in the company. He says even though he is exhausted at night, it takes him hours to fall asleep. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to him which has the least effect on REM sleep?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of sleep-onset insomnia. Among the given drugs, the one which can be prescribed for sleep-onset insomnia with the least effect on REM sleep is zolpidem. 

Zolpidem is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic. It acts as a selective agonist in benzodiazepine receptors and produces hypnotic-amnesic action. It shortens the sleep latency and prolongs sleep duration in insomniacs. It doesn't prolong total sleep time or alter NREM-REM sleep cycles. The effect on the sleep stages and REM sleep is less than that of benzodiazepines. 

Zolpidem doesn't show a rebound phenomenon on discontinuation and it has low abuse potential. Other non-benzodiazepine hypnotics are:

  • Zopiclone
  • Eszopiclone
  • Zaleplon

Other options:

Option A- Phenobarbitone can be used as a sedative and hypnotic. But they reduce REM and stage 3,4 sleep and disrupt the NREM-REM sleep cycle. 

Options B and D- Both diazepam and alprazolam are benzodiazepines that can be used for sleep-onset difficulty. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone. But they also affect the REM sleep pattern more than nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics.

Note:

Ramelteon is a hypnotic given for sleep-onset insomnia that acts as a melatonin receptor agonist. It hastens the sleep onset and increases the sleep duration.

questions.text:
Which of the following are correct regarding clofazimine?
  1. Used in multidrug therapy of leprosy
  2. It is avoided during early pregnancy
  3. It is not an orphan drug
  4. It has an additional anti-inflammatory action
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 4 are correct.

Clofazimine is one of the drugs in the multidrug therapy of leprosy. It is useful in lepra reactions due to its additional anti-inflammatory actions. 

Clofazimine acts on Mycobacterium leprae by:

  • Interfering with template function of DNA
  • Altering the membrane structure and transport function
  • Disrupting the mitochondrial electron transport chain

It is occasionally used as a component in multidrug therapy for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB). 

A major adverse effect of clofazimine is reddish-black discoloration of the skin, especially in exposed areas. It should be avoided in early pregnancy and in patients with liver or kidney damage. Clofazimine is an orphan drug.

Note:

Orphan drugs are drugs or biological products are used for diagnosis, treatment, or the prevention of a disease for which the cost of developing and marketing the drug will not be recovered from sales. Some of the orphan drugs are:

  • Clofazimine
  • Carboprost
  • Rifaximin
  • Rituximab
  • Busulfan

questions.text: According to Salter-Harris classification of physeal injuries, type 5 is:

choices.text: Splitting of the physis and epiphysis
Fracture passing through physis and metaphysis

questions.solution:
According to Salter-Harris classification of physeal injuries, type 5 is crushing of epiphysis.

Salter and Harris created a classification of physeal injuries for risk stratification. The following table depicts the Salter-Harris classification. 

Salter-Harris type Features
Type 1 Separation of epiphysis
Type 2 Through physis and metaphysis
Type 3 Intra-articular fracture of epiphysis
Type 4 Splitting of the physis and epiphysis
Type 5 Crushing of physis 

Type 1: The fracture line passes through the hypertrophic or calcified part of the plate. The growth plate is not affected. 

Type 2: It is similar to type 1. However, towards the end of the fracture line, it deviates and separates a triangular piece of the metaphysis. This fragment is known as the Thurston-Holland fragment. Type 2 is the most common type. 

Type 3: Here, the fracture splits the epiphysis and then goes transversely in either direction into the hypertrophic layer of the physis. This leads to damage of the growth plate leading to growth disturbance. 

Type 4: The fracture splits the epiphysis and extends into the metaphysis. Displacement can occur in these types leading to asymmetrical growth.

Type 5: There is longitudinal compression of the physis leading to crushing of the growth plate and growth arrest. 

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound. The wound shows typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and a closer examination shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound.

In a lacerated wound, the margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate the direction in which the blow or force was applied. The depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibres. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width. The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is higher at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

Option C- A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc, into the depth of the body. 

The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface. The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc. The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt. The blunt side may show small splits at each corner, called fishtailing. 

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

questions.text:
Which of the following imaging modalities are used in a virtual autopsy?
  1. X-Ray
  2. CT-Scan
  3. MRI
questions.solution:
CT and MRI are the imaging modalities of choice for a virtual autopsy.

Virtual autopsy

It is a non-invasive method to investigate the cause of death of a person. The CT Scan gives information about the anatomical findings whereas the MRI helps demonstrate soft tissue injury and organ trauma. MR Spectroscopy can also be done to measure the metabolites formed due to decomposition. These help in determining the time since death.

Advantages of a virtual autopsy:

  • Conditions like emphysema, air embolism, and pneumothorax can be better appreciated.
  • In injuries caused by weapons, a computer software can create a virtual model of the injury by using a simulation of a similar weapon.
  • In firearm injuries, entrance and exit wounds can be identified by the fracture pattern and bevelling of the bone.
  • It avoids destruction of some important evidence which maybe destroyed in a usual autopsy.

questions.text:
A new-born child was rushed to the neonatal ICU after he had been diagnosed with pentalogy of Cantrell. This condition includes all of the following midline defects except:
  1. Midline abdominal wall defect
  2. Microcephaly  
  3. Bronchial cyst
  4. Pericardial defect
  5. Intracardiac defects
questions.solution:
The pentalogy of Cantrell does not include bronchial cyst and microcephaly.

The pentalogy of Cantrell (POC) is a collection of five congenital midline birth defects. It involves defects of the heart, pericardium, diaphragm, sternum, and abdominal wall.

It can be complete or partial. Complete manifests as the presence of all five defects, while others may present with only partial defects. It is also called thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis, a condition where the heart is covered by an omphalocele-like membrane. 

The various components of the pentalogy are:

  • Midline abdominal wall defect
  • Anterior diaphragmatic hernia
  • Cleft sternum
  • Pericardial defect
  • Intracardiac defects such as ventricular septal defect, Tetrology of Fallot

The pentalogy of Cantrell can be diagnosed at the first-trimester ultrasound. It may be associated with trisomy 13, 18, 21, and Turner syndrome.

Treatment is directed at the repair and reconstruction of the defects.

A fetal MRI is seen below seen in the picture below, showing the heart in an ectopic position (indicated by *). Eventration of a part of the liver at the midline (indicated by arrow) is also seen with a small thoracic cavity (t).

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding wound healing by primary intention?
  1. These wounds usually involve injury of only the epithelial layer.
  2. Neutrophils usually arrive at the site at 48 hours.
  3. By the third day, neutrophils have been replaced by macrophages.
  4. There is a peak in neovascularization by day 7.
questions.solution:
Regarding healing by primary intention, only statements 1 and 3 are true. 

The sequence of events in wound healing is as follows:

Time after injury Events
Within 24 hours

Neutrophils:

  • Migrate from the incision margin towards the fibrin clot
  • Release proteolytic enzymes that begin to clear the debris

Basal cells: 

  • Located at the cut edge of the epidermis
  • Show increased mitotic activity
24 to 48 hours

Epithelial cells:

  • Migrate and proliferate from the wound edges towards the center 
  • Deposit basement membrane components 
  • Form a continuous epithelial layer that closes the wound
Day 3
  • Macrophages become predominant, with very few neutrophils 
  • Granulation tissue progressively invades the incision space
  • Collagen fibers at the incision margins
  • Increased thickness of the epithelial layer through continued epithelial proliferation 
Day 5
  • Neovascularization reaches its peak as granulation tissue fills the incisional space
  • As new vessels are leaky, new granulation tissue is often edematous
2nd week
  • Continued collagen accumulation
  • Fibroblast proliferation.
End of the 1st month
  • Scar contains cellular connective tissue
  • Largely devoid of inflammatory cells
  • Covered by an essentially normal epidermis

 

Incorrect option:

Statement (2): Neutrophils arrive at the incision/ injury site within 24 hours.

Statement (4): There is a peak in neovascularization on day 5, not day 7.

Healing of a wound can occur in three ways:

Healing by primary intention: Also called healing by first intention. This occurs when there is an apposition of the wound edges and minimal surrounding tissue trauma that causes the least inflammation and leaves the best scar. Eg: clean surgical incision.

Healing by secondary intention: Wounds are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction, and epithelialization.

Healing by tertiary intention (also called delayed primary intention): Wound initially left open and edges later opposed when healing conditions are favorable.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Mental Healthcare Act 2017?

choices.text: Right to access mental health care and treatment
Advance directive by mentally ill persons
Prohibition of electroconvulsive therapy for minors

questions.solution:
Mental Healthcare Act 2017 decriminalized suicide attempts.

The Act states that a person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be suffering from mental illness at that time and will not be punished under the Indian Penal Code. 

Other important features of Mental Healthcare Act 2017 are as follows:

  • Every person has the right to access mental health care and treatment from services run by the government. These services should be affordable, easily accessible, and of good quality.
  • A mentally ill person has the right to make an advance directive. It states how the person wants to be treated for the illness during a mental health situation and who shall be their nominated representative.
  • Central and State mental health authorities are the administrative bodies to register, supervise, and maintain all mental health establishments.
  • The Mental Health Review Commission and Board will be a quasi-judicial body that reviews the advance directives and advise the government on the protection of the rights of the mentally ill person.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) can be done only with the use of muscle relaxants and anesthesia. ECT is prohibited for minors. 

 

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.
