questions.text: While filling the preoperative diet recommendations on the chart of a 22-year-old patient scheduled to undergo elective surgery, you would recommend fasting of at least

choices.text: 4 hours for solids, 2 hours for clear liquids
2 hours for solids, 4 hours for clear liquids
8 hours for solids, 2 hours for clear liquids
2 hours for solids, 8 hours for clear liquids

questions.solution:
Recommended preoperative fasting periods for all above 1 year of age are

  • 2 hours for clear liquids
  • 6 hours for light meal/milk
  • 8 hours for fried, fatty food

Recommended preoperative fasting period for neonates and infants are

  • 4 hours for breast milk
  • 6 hours for solids/formula feeds/cow's milk

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

Note: Clear liquids include, but are not limited to - water, tea & coffee without milk, fruit juices without pulp, carbonated drinks & carbohydrate-rich nutritional drinks.

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for circumcision under daycare surgery. Which of the following is not a requirement for a successful daycare surgery?

choices.text: Patient's age is more important than physiological status

questions.solution:
The physiological status of a patient is a more important determinant than their chronological age during daycare surgery. Thus, the opposite, as mentioned in option (B) is not an essential requirement for a successful daycare surgery. 

A surgical procedure can be considered as daycare surgery when the patient's admission, procedure, and discharge all take place within the span of 12 working hours. In these procedures, the patient does not have to stay overnight at the hospital. 

Minimal tissue handling during the procedure (Option D), achieving good hemostasis (Option B), and using minimally invasive techniques (Option A) are all factors that can help to achieve a successful daycare surgery. 

Physical fitness for the procedure, short duration, and a home environment that can support recovery and postoperative care are all important factors when choosing daycare surgery for a patient.

When selecting a patient it is important to consider the following-

  • Medically, the physiological health of the patient is of greater importance than their chronological age. For short procedures, the current health status will help us decide if the patient will tolerate the procedure or not. Chronological age becomes more important for longer, more invasive surgeries. 
  • Surgically, the procedure should ideally last less than 2 hours, and the patient should be able to consume liquids and possibly some solid food by the time they get discharged on the same day. 
  • Socially, it is important to identify a designated caregiver for the patient at least for the first 24 hours after surgery. Their home should also have the facilities to support their recovery and they should be sent home with all the sites required for their post-operative care. 

Some procedures that qualify for daycare surgery are listed below-

  • Arthroscopies
  • Biopsy (temporal, lymph node)
  • Reducing a strangulated hernia
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess 
  • K-wiring of a finger or wrist bone fracture
  • Laparoscopic appendicectomy

Patient's having daycare surgery can usually be discharged when they have stable vitals, have adequately controlled pain with a prescription for further pain management at home, can perform basic activities on their own, have no evidence of incision site bleeding, have a designated caregiver, and have all the instructions required for further management at home and instructions in case of an emergency.

questions.text:
Match the following mucopolysaccharidoses with the defective enzyme in each case:
Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
2. Morquio syndrome B B. Iduronate sulfatase
3. Hurler syndrome C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A D. β-galactosidase
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-D 3-A, 4-C  is correctly matched.

Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome B. Iduronate sulfatase
2. Morquio syndrome B D. β-galactosidase
3. Hurler syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

 

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. When they are attached to a protein they are referred to as proteoglycans. These proteoglycans make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue.

Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in the mucopolysaccharidoses mentioned above. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B has high levels of serum HBeAg. Which of the following viral genes is involved in coding the same?
questions.solution:
HBeAg is coded by the C gene. The presence of high levels of HBeAg (and HBV DNA) suggests high infectivity. 

HBV Genome has four overlapping genes. They code for: 

  • S gene-It codes for surface antigen. 
  • C gene-
    • When the C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed.
    • When translation begins from Pre C region, HBeAg is formed.
  • P gene- Codes for DNA polymerase.
  • X gene- Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg.

questions.text: A middle-aged obese woman had elevated liver enzymes on routine follow-up. A USG showed grade 2 fatty liver. She is non-diabetic, non-hypertensive and has never consumed alcohol. Which of the following can be considered as a first-line pharmacological treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
An obese woman with grade 2 fatty liver in the absence of alcohol consumption is suggestive of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Vitamin E is considered as a first-line pharmacological treatment option for NASH in non-diabetics when diet and lifestyle changes have failed. 

Vitamin E is well tolerated and shows modest improvements in aminotransferase levels, radiographic features of hepatic steatosis, and/or histologic features of NASH. It is important to note that vitamin E must be considered only for non-diabetic patients due to cardiovascular risks with chronic vitamin E therapy.

Note: The FDA in 2024 has approved Resmetirom, a thyroid hormone receptor-beta (THR-beta) agonist for noncirrhotic NASH with moderate to advanced fibrosis.

questions.text: The reaction below summarises the formation of an end product of arginine. Identify the enzyme X.
questions.solution:
The enzyme X is nitric oxide synthase (NO synthase). Nitric oxide is synthesised from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalysed by NO synthase. 

Arginine, O2, and NADPH are substrates for cytosolic NO synthase. The co-enzymes of NO synthase include flavin mononucleotide (FMN), flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

There are three types of NO synthases. Two are Ca2+-calmodulin-dependent enzymes found in vascular endothelium and neural tissue, and one is a Ca2+-independent enzyme that is expressed in cells such as hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, and activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby decreases smooth muscle contraction.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and γ-interferon released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitters in the brain

Other options:

Option B: Arginase catalyzes the cleavage of L-arginine, forming urea and L-ornithine. Defective arginase leads to the inherited metabolic defect hyperargininemia.

Option C: Arginine-glycine amidinotransferase acts on glycine and arginine producing guanidinoacetate, which is a step in the biosynthesis of creatine and creatinine.

Option D: Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase I is involved in the synthesis of citrulline from Carbamoyl Phosphate in the urea cycle.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: What percentage of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel should be occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque to call it a stage of critical stenosis?
questions.solution:
70 - 75% of the luminal cross-sectional area of a blood vessel is occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque in the stage of critical stenosis.

In atherosclerotic stenosis, critical stenosis is the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This typically occurs when the occlusion produces a 70% to 75% decrease in luminal cross-sectional area. With this degree of stenosis in the coronary circulation, the patient may experience chest pain on exertion i.e, stable angina.

Critical stenosis also leads to bowel ischemia, intermittent claudication, mesenteric occlusion, sudden cardiac death, chronic ischemic heart disease and ischemic encephalopathy.

An increased level of LDL is directly associated with the development of coronary heart disease. This promotes the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, undergoing the following process.


An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as rupture, ulceration, erosion which lead to thrombus formation, or hemorrhage into the plaque which increases the plaque size. Both of these consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Atherosclerosis

Nonmodifiable (constitutional):

  • Genetic abnormalities
  • Family history
  • Increasing age
  • Male gender

Modifiable:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypertension
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Diabetes

Additional risk factors:

  • Inflammation 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] 
  • Elevated plasminogen activator inhibitor 1
  • Type A personality

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of embryonal development during the second to the fourth week in the sequence in which they occur:
  1. Formation of the neural plate
  2. Formation of the notochordal process
  3. Formation of the primitive streak 
  4. Notochordal plate separates from endoderm to form true notochord
  5. Formation of the notochordal plate
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in which the above events occur is 3, 2, 1, 5, 4: Formation of the primitive streak, notochordal process, neural plate, notochordal plate, and finally, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form the true notochord.

The primitive streak is formed around day 15. This is followed by the formation of definitive endoderm and the formation of mesoderm.

This mesoderm extends cranially to form the notochordal process around day 17. Meanwhile, the mesoderm present lateral to midline gets divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral plate mesoderm. The lateral plate mesoderm splits into two layers- somatic mesoderm and splanchnic mesoderm, separated by the intraembryonic coelom.

Formation of the neural plate begins between days 19 and 20. The cranial and caudal parts of the neural plate represent the future brain and spinal cord, respectively.

The notochordal process fuses transiently with the endoderm to form a notochordal plate after day 20. Finally, around day 22, the notochordal plate separates from the endoderm to form a solid, definitive notochord.

questions.text: Emptying of the stomach is inhibited by all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
Emptying of the stomach is not inhibited, but rather increased by the secretion of gastrin. Gastrin promotes emptying of the stomach by stimulating the motor functions of the stomach, especially the pyloric pump.

After food enters the duodenum, the duodenal entero-gastric nerve reflexes ensure the inhibition of emptying of the stomach. This mainly includes 3 pathways. They are, via the enteric nervous system directly from the duodenum, via extrinsic nerves that go to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia and then back through the sympathetic fibres to the stomach and finally via the vagus nerve that inhibits the excitatory signals to the stomach at the level of the brainstem. These reflexes inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and also increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

Gastrin is a hormone secreted by G cells located in the pyloric glands of the stomach. It is released into the blood, following which it is transported to the enterochromaffin-like cells of the stomach, resulting in the release of histamine, which stimulates gastric hydrochloric acid secretion.

Other options:

Option A: Increased acidity of chyme inhibits the emptying of the stomach by irritating the entero-gastric inhibitory reflexes of the duodenum. It prevents the subsequent release of stomach contents into the duodenum until the acidic chyme that is already present is neutralised.

Option B: Distension of the duodenum inhibits the emptying of the stomach via the enteric nervous system.

Option C: Cholecystokinin secretion decreases the motility of the stomach as a result of its inhibitory effect on gastrin. It is a hormone that is released from the mucosa of the jejunum and is sensitive to the presence of fats in the duodenum.

questions.text:
Match the following mutated proteins with the disease that they can be associated with:
Mutated protein Disease
1. RB A.Familial gastric cancer
2. Menin B. Retinoblastoma
3. p53 C. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
4. E-cadherin D. Li Fraumeni syndrome 
5. STK 11 E. Multiple endocrine neoplasia-I
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-B, 2-E, 3-D, 4-A, 5-C. The table below depicts the mutated proteins correctly paired with the diseases they can cause-

Mutated protein Disease
1. RB B. Retinoblastoma
2. Menin E. Multiple endocrine neoplasia- I
3. p53 D. Li Fraumeni syndrome
4. E-cadherin A. Familial gastric cancer 
5. STK 11 C. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome 

1. RB protein is derived from the RB gene. The main function of this protein is to inhibit G1 to S transition during the cell cycle progression. Hence, it controls proliferation by regulating an important step in cell division. Both the RB genes must undergo mutation in order for a child to develop retinoblastoma (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis). These mutations can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion or may be sporadic. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular tumor seen in children.

2. Menin is a protein that normally functions as a transcription factor. It is derived from the MEN I gene. Mutations in this gene result in the MEN I syndrome (multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome I) which presents with tumors of the pituitary, pancreas, and parathyroid.

3. p53 is a protein that is involved in cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. A mutated p53 results in the proliferation of damaged cells that can ultimately lead to cancerous cell lines. This mutation is seen very commonly in Li Fraumeni syndrome, which can present with a broad spectrum of tumors such as breast cancer, adrenocortical tumors, leukemias, etc. 

4. E-cadherin is a protein derived from the gene CDH 1. This protein is responsible for cell adhesion and inhibiting cell motility. Its mutation can result in familial gastric cancer. Mutations in E-cadherin are also thought to be responsible for metastasis in breast cancer.

5. STK11 is normally a cell growth suppressor. In the mutated form it can lead to Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which can present with gastrointestinal polyps, pancreatic cancer, and other gastrointestinal tumors.

questions.text: There has been a recent outbreak of malaria in the locality as a consequence of improper sewage disposal. The district council decides to promote the construction of septic tanks under your guidance. What is the minimum recommended capacity of a septic tank for household purposes?
questions.solution:
The minimum recommended capacity of septic tanks used for household purposes is at least 500 gallons.

The septic tank is a water-tight masonry tank where household sewage is admitted for treatment. From individual dwellings, small groups of houses and institutions which have adequate water supplies but do not have access to a public sewerage system using this system for disposing of excreta and liquid wastes.

Other specifications: 

  • Length: The length is usually twice the breadth
  • Depth: The depth of a septic tank is from 1.5 to 2 m
  • Liquid depth: The recommended liquid depth is only 1.2 m
  • Air space: There should be a minimum air space of 30 cm between the level of liquid in the tank and the undersurface of the cover
  • Bottom: The bottom is sloping towards the inlet end which facilitates the retention of solids
  • Inlet and outlet: There are submerged inlet and outlet pipe
  • Cover: The septic tank is covered by a concrete slab and provided with a manhole
  • Retention Period: Septic tanks are designed to allow a retention period of 24 hours. This is because too long a retention period will result in undue septicity of the effluent whereas too short a period gives insufficient treatment

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with jaundice. He has clay-colored stools and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound is performed, and the obtained image is shown below. What is the name of the ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
The 3-week-old neonate with persistent jaundice, clay-colored stool, and hepatomegaly is likely to have biliary atresia. The ultrasound confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the triangular cord sign. 

The triangular cord sign represents the cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein. This density is echogenic and represents the fibrous remains of the porta hepatis. 

Biliary atresia may also be termed as noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology.

The classification of biliary atresia with the regions involved is as follows:

  • Type I - Common bile duct
  • Type IIa - Common hepatic duct
  • Type IIb - Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct.
  • Type III (most common type)-Common bile duct, hepatic duct, cystic duct; no anastomosable ducts at porta hepatis 

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). 

Laboratory evaluation will show elevated levels of direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and the triangular cord sign. 

Treatment is surgery via Kasai procedure or liver transplantation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Falciform ligament sign is seen in the case of pneumoperitoneum. Here, the air outlines the appearance of the falciform ligament, as seen in the x-ray below. 


Option C - Double bubble sign occurs due to dilated stomach and duodenum in duodenal atresia. It is seen in x-rays and ultrasound. The following image depicts the double bubble sign. 


Option D - Target sign is seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and intussusception. The following ultrasound image shows the target sign seen in intussusception.

questions.text:
The ionic currents involved in the action potential of the ventricular cardiac muscle are given below. Arrange them in the correct sequence.
  1. Opening of calcium channels and closure of fast potassium channels
  2. Closure of fast sodium channels and opening of fast potassium channels
  3. Opening of slow potassium channels and closure of calcium channels
  4. Opening of fast sodium channels
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps in the action potential of the ventricular muscle is as depicted in option A ( 4, 2, 1, 3).

The sequence of different phases of action potential in the ventricle, with the ionic currents involved, is as follows:

  • Phase 0→ Depolarisation
    • Due to the opening of fast voltage-gated sodium channels
  • Phase 1→ Initial repolarization
    • Closure of fast sodium channels and opening of fast potassium channels
  • Phase 2→ Plateau phase
    • Opening of calcium channels and closure of fast potassium channels
  • Phase 3→ Late rapid repolarization 
    • Opening of slow potassium channels and closure of calcium channels

Phase 3 is followed by phase 4, which corresponds to a return to resting membrane potential.

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome has severe proteinuria and low levels of serum albumin. What would be the most likely change in the anion gap of this patient?
questions.solution:
Serum albumin is an unmeasured anion. Therefore, proteinuria in nephrotic syndrome leads to a decrease in unmeasured anions.

Albumin is negatively charged at physiological pH and responsible for approximately 75% of the unmeasured anions of the normal anion gap. A drop in albumin therefore will cause the anion gap to fall. Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap.

Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen when there is

  • An increase in unmeasured cations
  • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as
    • Lithium (lithium intoxication)
    • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • A reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
Methanol Fistula pancreatic
Uremia (Renal failure - Acute or Chronic) Ureterosigmoidostomy
Diabetic ketoacidosis Small bowel fistula
Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: A middle-aged man with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image is given below. These inclusions are periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. Which type of emphysema does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
The presence of PAS-positive and diastase-resistant inclusion bodies in the hepatocytes is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. This condition is associated with panacinar type of emphysema.

α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of α1 antitrypsin (α1AT) into the serum. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema.

It also causes liver disease as a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in some cases. Liver biopsy round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes that are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant. 

Emphysema is a condition in which the air spaces distal to the terminal bronchiole are abnormally enlarged due to irreversible damage to their walls. This results in poor gaseous exchange and progressive air trapping.

Emphysema can be of four major types depending on the areas affected: (1) centriacinar, (2) panacinar, (3) paraseptal, and (4) irregular.

Out of these, only the pan-acinar type is associated with α1-antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency and liver damage. In this type of emphysema, the acini from the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged.

Related Pearl: Types of emphysema

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule.

Type Area involved Other features

Centriacinar (most common)
  • Central part of acinus (respiratory bronchiole)
  • Upper lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in smokers
Panacinar
  • Entire acinus (respiratory bronchiole + alveoli)
  • Lower lobes of lung
  • Commonly seen in young non-smokers
  • Associated with α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Paraseptal
  • Distal part of acinus (alveoli)
  • Subpleural region
  • Commonly seen in young adults 
  • Increased risk for spontaneous pneumothorax 
Irregular
  • Focal and irregular involvement of acinus
  • Areas of the lung near scar tissue 
  • Not usually seen in COPD

questions.text: All the following are events in the first stage of labor except?

choices.text: Descent of fetus to vaginal canal

questions.solution:
The descent of the fetus to the vaginal canal occurs in the second stage of labor. All other options are the events occurring in the first stage of labor. 

The first stage of labor is a phase of preparation of the birth canal. It is the time period between labor starts and ends with full cervical dilation of 10 centimeters. It facilitates the expulsion of the fetus in the second stage. The main events that occur in the first stage of labor are:

  • Dilatation of the cervix
  • Effacement of the cervix 
  • Full formation of lower uterine segment

From complete cervical dilatation of 10 centimeters until the expulsion of the fetus comprises the second stage of labor. The main event that occurs in this stage is the descent and delivery of the fetus through the birth canal.

The third stage of labor starts after the delivery of the fetus. It includes placental separation and expulsion. 

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Three weeks following a parotidectomy,  there is an aberrant regeneration of postganglionic parasympathetic fibers of the nerve marked in the image below.  All the following methods are suitable in order to prevent such occurrence except

choices.text: Artificial membrane between skin and parotid bed

questions.solution:
After parotidectomy, the aberrent regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (marked in the image) leads to Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). All the above-mentioned methods are suitable to prevent its occurrence except tympanic neurectomy because it is not a preventive method but is a method of treatment.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with a starch-iodine test. This test involves painting the patient’s surgical site with iodine and dry starch, and a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue or brown.

It is an inevitable consequence of parotidectomy unless preventive measures are taken. These measures replace the barrier between the skin and the parotid bed and minimize the abnormal regeneration of autonomic nerve fibers. The preventive measures are:

  • Sternomastoid muscle flap
  • Temporalis fascial flap
  • Insertion of artificial membranes between the skin and the parotid bed.
Treatment of Frey's syndrome is with antiperspirants, tympanic neurectomy, or botulinum toxin injection into the affected area (most effective).

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text:
Match the following autoantibodies with their associated disease.
Auto-antibodies Disease
1. Anti-histone A. Scleroderma
2. c-ANCA B. Dermatomyositis
3. Anti-Scl-70 C. Drug-induced lupus
4. Anti-Ro/SSA,
    Anti-La/SSB		 D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  E. Sjogren’s syndrome
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Auto-antibodies Disease
1. Anti-histone Drug-induced lupus  
2. c-ANCA Granulomatosis with polyangiitis  
3. Anti-Scl-70 Scleroderma  
4. Anti-Ro/SSA,
    Anti-La/SSB		 Sjogren’s syndrome

Drug-induced lupus is commonly associated with antibodies to histones. It is positive for antinuclear antibody (ANA) and is rarely associated with anti-dsDNA. It can be differentiated from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) as the symptoms appear during therapy with certain medications or biologicals. It usually resolves over several weeks after discontinuation of the offending medication. The most frequent medications implicated are procainamide, hydralazine, propylthiouracil, chlorpromazine, and lithium. 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) is associated with c-ANCA positivity. It is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (diffuse cutaneous) is strongly associated with the anti-Scl 70 antibodies. It is an autoimmune rheumatic disease with female predominance. Cutaneous features include Raynaud's phenomenon, ulcerations that heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, and loss of sweat glands. Facial features include mask-like facies and diffuse hyperpigmentation. Systemic features include dysphagia, pulmonary fibrosis, heart failure, uremia, and carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Sjogren’s syndrome is associated with anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies. It is an autoimmune disease with lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands and hyperactive B-lymphocytes. The disease commonly involves the lacrimal and salivary glands. This results in the characteristic presentation of sicca syndrome (decreased tears and saliva). Parotid gland enlargement is present in half of the patients.

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease

SLE (non-specific)

Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma

Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome
c-ANCA Wegener (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

Predominantly positive in

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Large vessel vasculitis)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site to develop avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
The head of the femur is the most common site to develop avascular necrosis. 

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a degenerative bone condition caused by interruption of the blood supply. It commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones that make up weight-bearing joints. 

The common areas that are affected by avascular necrosis are: 

  • Head of the femur after a fracture of the neck of the femur or hip dislocation
  • Proximal scaphoid after a scaphoid waist fracture
  • Lunate bone after a dislocation
  • Body of the talus after a fracture of the neck of the talus

It is considered to be an early complication of injury, however, it is not clinically evident until weeks to months after the inciting event. There are generally no symptoms associated with avascular necrosis. However, if the fracture does not unite, then there will be pain. 

An X-ray will reveal increased density. This occurs due to disuse osteoporosis in the surrounding areas and the collapse of trabeculae compacts the bone. There may also be deformity due to collapse of necrotic bone and osteoarthritis. 

In osteonecrosis of the femur, an X-ray will reveal a crescent sign which is pathognomonic. The sign refers to the subchondral fracture that overlies the necrotic segment of the femoral head. 

A bone scan may reveal a 'cold area' before radiological features are evident. 

MRI is the imaging modality of choice in avascular necrosis as it allows for staging and determination of extent of involvement. 

It is treated depending on the joint involved. Weight-bearing should be delayed until it is revascularized, a process that may take 6-8 months. Revascularization can be done by using vascularized bone grafts taken from the greater trochanter in the case of a fracture of the femur neck. The avascular segment should be excised followed by a total joint replacement. 

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A 32-year-old obese woman who recently joined a weight loss program presents with pain along the anterior and medial aspects of her tibia. The pain increases while doing jogging and walking on the treadmill for long periods. On examination, there is diffuse tenderness along the tibial shaft. A plain X-ray radiograph of her leg is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient with diffuse tibial pain and a normal x-ray is the shin splint or medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS). 

MTSS is a stress injury of the tibia which occurs due to the frequent overuse of lower limbs. It is commonly seen in athletes and military personnel.

Risk factors for MTSS

  • High body mass index (BMI)
  • An increase in training volume or intensity
  • Female gender
  • Previous history of MTSS

Exercise-induced diffuse pain along the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border is typical. Since it is a stress injury, the radiograph of the leg appears normal.

MTSS often leads to stress fractures of the tibia. When this occurs, the pain increases in intensity becomes localized and is associated with swelling.

It is treated conservatively. The patient should take physical rest and modify daily activities to avoid repetitive and load-bearing exercises. Other modalities being studied include ice massage and ultrasound therapy. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation
March fracture Fracture of the neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal
Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: The absence of the SRY gene results in which of the following?

choices.text: Development of ovaries and Mullerian system

questions.solution:
The absence of the SRY gene results in the development of the ovaries and the Mullerian system.

In this situation, the gonads will develop into ovaries and the Mullerian duct will differentiate into the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. The master gene responsible for this is the WNT4 gene.

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome, which has a sex-determining region called the SRY gene.

If the Y chromosome is present, the protein called testis determining factor produced by the SRY gene will lead to the development of testis as the gonads. The Sertoli cells of the testis will then produce Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS; also known as Anti-Müllerian hormone, AMH) that will cause the Müllerian ducts to regress.

Functions of SRY and WNT4:

SRY gene WNT4 gene

Development of the medullary/testes cords

The disappearance of medullary/testes cords

Formation of the tunica albuginea

Failure of formation of tunica albuginea

Failure of development of cortical/ovarian cords 

 Development of ovaries with typical cortical cords

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with symptoms of foul-smelling, purulent nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. On examination, there is crusting and atrophy of nasal mucosa. Identify the stage of clinical presentation of this granulomatous gram-negative bacterial infection.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a young adult in the third decade of life presenting with symptoms of foul-smelling nasal discharge and nasal obstruction with crusting and atrophy of the nasal mucosa on examination is indicative of Rhinoscleroma, in its atrophic stage. It is also called the catarrhal stage

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by the gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It usually affects young adults in the third to fourth decade of life and risk factors include malnutrition, poor hygiene, and overcrowding. It is an airborne disease that can be classified into three stages, clinically and histologically.

The first stage is the catarrhal or atrophic stage characterised by initial non-specific rhinitis followed by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. Crusting and atrophy of nasal mucosa is also seen during this stage.

The second stage is the granulomatous stage, also called the proliferative or hypertrophic stage. It manifests as epistaxis, anosmia, destruction of the cartilaginous part of the nasal septum and soft palate. Granulomatous nodules are present in the mucosa which are painless and nonulcerative. 

The third stage is called the cicatricial or fibrotic stage. It is characterised by fibrosis and scarring resulting in stenosis of nares, distortion of upper lip and adhesions in the nose, nasopharynx and oropharynx. Subglottic stenosis may be seen. 

Histology shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Image below shows

  • Mikulicz cells - large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli
  • Russell bodies - homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells. (noted by arrows in the image)

Russell bodies are shown in the image below.

 

A CT scan shows the nasal lesions appearing as homogenous non-enhancing masses with a distinct edge. 

Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity.

questions.text: You are a first-year student who has been asked to identify the hybrid muscle during dissection of the femoral triangle. Which of the following muscles could it be?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as 1 in the given image is the pectineus, which is a hybrid muscle. 

Muscles marked in the image:

1- Pectineus

2- Adductor longus

3- Vastus lateralis

4- Sartorius 

Muscles supplied by two different motor nerves with different root values are called hybrid or composite muscles.

The pectineus muscle is a hybrid or composite muscle because of its dual nerve supply. Its anterior fibers are innervated by the femoral nerve while posterior fibers are innervated by the anterior division of the obturator nerve. Other features of this nerve are:

  • Origin: Pecten pubis, the upper half of the pectineal surface of the superior ramus of the pubis and fascia covering the pectineus
  • Insertion: Line extending from lesser trochanter to linea Aspera
  • Function: It is a flexor and adductor of the thigh

Other hybrid muscles are:

  • Adductor Magnus: Supplied by the obturator nerve and tibial part of the sciatic nerve
  • Flexor digitorum profundus: Supplied by the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve and the ulnar nerve
  • Pectoralis major: Supplied by the medial and lateral pectoral nerves
  • Flexor pollicis brevis: Supplied by the recurrent motor branch of median nerve and the deep branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Brachialis: Supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve and the radial nerve
  • Biceps femoris: The long head is supplied by the tibial part of the sciatic nerve, and the short head by the common fibular nerve
  • Digastric: The anterior belly is supplied by the mylohyoid branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and the posterior belly is supplied by the facial nerve

Other options:

Option B: Adductor longus is supplied by anterior division of the obturator nerve

Option C: Vastus lateralis is supplied by the femoral nerve

Option D: Sartorius is supplied by the femoral nerve

 

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: An elderly woman with strangulated femoral hernia has abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and resection of intestines with an end- to-end anastomosis. After that, she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate as it is the disease/condition directly leading to death.

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Peritonitis
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: Perforation of small intestine
  • I(c) - Condition which gave rise to the antecedent cause: Strangulated femoral hernia

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are only signs of death and provide no useful information regarding the underlying disease process.

Refer the last line in the death certificate with an asterisk (*).

Related Pearl: WHO Format for International Death Certificate

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anomaly of the umbilical cord?
questions.solution:
The normal umbilical cord contains one large vein with two umbilical arteries and is not an anomaly.

Counting the number of cord vessels is a standard component of evaluation during the fetal sonographic examination and immediately after delivery. Hyrtl anastomosis is a connection between the two umbilical arteries seen in most normal cords. It lies near the cord insertion into the placenta. The anastomosis acts as a pressure­ equalizing system between the two umbilical arteries, improving placental perfusion during uterine contrac­tions or during compression of one umbilical artery.

Other options:

Option B- The presence of 1 artery and 1 vein or single umbilical artery (SUA) is the most common aberration seen in fetuses with major malformations. The most frequent anomalies associated are cardiovascular and genitourinary anomalies. SUA is also associated with an increased risk of aneuploidy and intrauterine growth retardation.

Option C- The presence of four-vessel cords is often associated with congenital anomalies.

Option D- Absence of Hyrtl anastomosis is usually seen in fetuses with a single umbilical artery.

questions.text: The results of a meta-analysis of various studies on the relationship between rabies infection and mortality rates are plotted as shown in the image below. What is this graphical representation known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a funnel plot, which is a means to assess the extent to which a systematic review is influenced by publication and other biases.

In general, there will be more variability in the results of smaller studies than larger studies, so, this plot should look like an inverted funnel. The larger study results cluster around the overall mean effect more closely than the results of the smaller studies. A funnel plot displays the effect size plotted against the sample size.

If the distribution of results of smaller studies is asymmetrical, it suggests that some smaller studies that showed unfavorable results may be missing from the analysis because of various biases. An asymmetrical funnel plot shows the apparent presence of publication bias. 

Other options :

Option B: Forest plots are commonly used to present the results of meta-analyses. It allows the results to be seen at a glance, with ready identification of outliers.

The following image shows a generic forest plot showing the odds ratios of various studies, their confidence intervals, and the summary measure arrived at through meta-analysis.

Option C: Scattergram is a graphical representation of the bivariate distribution relationship between two correlated variables. Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables. This is expressed in terms of a correlation coefficient, signified by r.

Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation). Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak. The strength of the relationship is indicated by the size of the coefficient and its direction is indicated by the sign. 

The image below shows a scattergram.

Option D- An ogive is a cumulative frequency polygon that forms a typical S-shaped curve.

The following image shows an example of an ogive.

Related Pearl: Funnel Plots

  • A funnel plot is basically a scatter plot of individual studies which are used in systematic reviews and meta-analysis. It plots their precisions and results.
  • In a funnel plot, each dot represents an individual study.
  • The y-axis is usually the standard error or another estimate of precision and the x-axis is the outcome, usually the odds ratio.
  • Higher powered studies are placed towards the top and the lower powered ones towards the bottom such that the plot resembles an inverted funnel or a pyramid.
  • This shape is expected as different studies have different standard errors and other estimates.
  • A symmetrical funnel plot is shown in Fig. A. in the image below.
  • These funnel plots are used in meta-analysis to check for bias like publication bias or other reporting bias.
  • In the case of bias being present, an asymmetrical funnel plot results, as shown in Fig. B. of the image below.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for a routine examination.  On examination, a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard along the left sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. Lungs are clear and the abdomen is soft and non-tender.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents typically with fixed wide split S2, a classic finding of atrial septal defect (ASD), a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease.

Atrial septal defects are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria. The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of inspiration/expiration. Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. 

A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard. Echocardiography will show characteristic right ventricular volume overload, including an increased right ventricular end-diastolic dimension and flattening and abnormal motion of the ventricular septum.

ASDs are classified according to location of the defect listed as follows:

  • Patent foramen ovale
  • Ostium secundum
  • Ostium primum
  • Sinus venosus
  • Coronary sinus

Murmurs are described based on intensity, frequency or pitch, quality, duration, configuration, primary location, and site of radiation. The intensity of a murmur is graded from 1-6 as follows: 

  • Grade 1 - Faint, can only be heard with special effort
  • Grade 2 - Faint but immediately audible
  • Grade 3 - Moderately loud
  • Grade 4 - Very loud
  • Grade 5 - Extremely loud and is audible with one edge of the stethoscope touching the chest wall
  • Grade 6 - Loud, audible with stethoscope removed from contact with the chest wall

Murmurs of intensity grade 4 and higher are generally accompanied by a thrill. 

Other options:

Option A: Eisenmeger syndrome occurs when an existing left to right shunt results in severe pulmonary hypertension and increased vascular resistance which reverses the shunt to form a right to left shunt. Patients with known congenital heart disease would present with worsening exertional dyspnea, swelling, volume retention, syncope, cyanosis, palpitations, or hemoptysis. 

Option B: In Ventricular septal defect are generally asymptomatic and have a loud, harsh, or blowing holosystolic murmur heard over the lower left sternal border. 

Option D: Pulmonary stenosis – It has a systolic ejection murmur best heard along the left upper sternal border minimally radiating to the lung fields. Other features seen in this condition include a sharp pulmonic ejection click after S1, heard during expiration, a split S2, elevated venous pressure, prominent a wave in jugulovenous pulse, right ventricular lift, and mild to moderate cyanosis. 

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication

Ebstein anomaly

Eisenmenger's syndrome

VSD with pulmonic stenosis

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

 

Related Pearl: Locations of Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with dull pain over the right lower abdomen. CT scan revealed a multiloculated adnexal mass. Exploratory laparotomy showed the following mass, which on microscopy showed multiloculated cysts lined by a single layer of mucin-containing epithelium. CA-125 levels were not elevated. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, gross image, and microscopy findings are suggestive of mucinous cystadenoma. Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common epithelial ovarian cancer (option B is incorrect). 

Mucinous cystadenomas are mostly benign. They are usually present during the third to sixth decade of life and the majority of them are unilateral.

They are usually multilocular, thick-walled, and have a smooth surface. Histology shows multiple cysts and glands liner by simple non-stratified mucinous epithelium. The epithelium may resemble gastric foveolar type or intestinal epithelium containing goblet cells. 

Complications of mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary include torsion, spontaneous rupture, pseudomyxoma peritonei, and secondary malignancies. Secondary malignancy occurs in 5-10% of mucinous cystadenomas. 

In pseudomyxoma peritonei, the peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous martial adherent to the omentum and intestines. During laparotomy, the lesions resemble boiled sago pudding. It is frequently associated with mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary but are also seen with mucocele of the appendix and carcinoma of the large intestine in men. 

Cystectomy is the adequate treatment for ovarian cystadenoma but recurrence may be seen in patients treated with cystectomy.

Note- Serous cystadenocarcinomas account for 40-50% of malignant epithelial ovarian tumors. Microscopically, tumor cells show severe nuclear atypia and anaplasia. Malignant ovarian tumors are associated with elevated CA-125 levels.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

 

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with numbness in her hands, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability. She had undergone a gastrectomy recently and she looks very pale. Her peripheral smear findings are shown below. If the condition is left untreated, which of the following will be seen?

choices.text: Large-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of proprioception
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of temperature sense
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of vibration sense

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of numbness, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability suggest anemia. The history of gastrectomy and the peripheral smear showing large hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes depicting macrocytic anemia is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient is at risk of developing large-fiber neuropathy causing loss of proprioception.

Vitamin B12 deficiency typically leads to large-fiber neuropathy, which presents with loss of vibration and loss of proprioception. Small nerve fibers are spared in B12 deficiency.

Pernicious anemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. The other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency are gastrectomy, gastric bypass surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption of cobalamin from food, and so on.

The clinical features include easy fatiguability, numbness of hands, loss of vibration and proprioception, hyperreflexia, and loss of ankle reflexes. 

Investigations reveal anemia, macrocytosis, and reduced cobalamin levels. Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated. Antibodies to the intrinsic factor may be seen in pernicious anemia.

Peripheral smear shows marked variation in red cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis). The presence of red cells that are macrocytic and oval (macro-ovalocytes) is highly characteristic. Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules, instead of the normal three to four.

Treatment can vary according to the regimen. One regimen consists of intramuscular injections of 1000 micrograms of cyanocobalamin weekly for a month, and then monthly thereafter.  

Note: Small-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small-fiber neuropathies present with temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

Related Pearl: Nerve Fiber Types And Sensory Neuropathies

Depending on the nerve fibers involved (Large or Small), the sensory neuropathies are classified as follows:

A. Small fiber (Painful neuropathies: dissociated sensory loss)

  • Lepromatous leprosy
  • Amyloidosis
  • Diabetic small fiber neuropathy
  • HIV and antiretroviral therapy neuropathy

B. Large fiber (Ataxic neuropathies)

  • Sjogren’s syndrome
  • Vitamin B12 neuropathy
  • Pyridoxine toxicity
  • Cisplatin neuropathy

C. Mixed (small & large fiber) (Global sensory loss)

  • Diabetic sensory neuropathy
  • Hereditary sensory neuropathies
  • Carcinomatous sensory neuropathy

questions.text:
A 20-year-old race car champion is brought by his manager to the ENT surgeon for the correction of the condition shown below, which occurred after sustaining a blow to the face by the runner-up two months prior. The driver is asymptomatic and is scheduled to undergo an SMR operation. Identify the false statement about this procedure.

SMR - Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum

choices.text: Re-operating is easier compared to septoplasty
Not done before the age of 17 years
Periosteal flaps raised on both sides of septum
Greater chance of complications compared to septoplasty

questions.solution:
The false statement about the SMR (Submucous Resection of Nasal Septum) is option 1. Re-operating following an SMR is difficult compared to a septoplasty, which involves fewer complications and an easier re-operation.

The given clinical vignette with an image showing the midline of the dorsum of the nose deviated to one side is indicative of a deviated nasal septum.

Deviated nasal septum (DNS) is an important cause of nasal obstruction. It is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Headache
  • Epistaxis
  • Anosmia
  • External deformity. 

The indications for an SMR are:

  • DNS causing symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches.
  • DNS causing obstruction of paranasal sinuses and middle ear, resulting in recurrent sinusitis and otitis media.
  • Recurrent epistaxis from a septal spur.
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty, for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities.
  • As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy or vidian neurectomy.

It is contraindicated in children below 17 years of age, during acute respiratory infection, bleeding diathesis, untreated diabetes, or hypertension.

In this procedure, mucoperichondrial and mucoperiosteal flaps are raised on both sides of the septum. Bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum are excised. This is followed by extensive dissection of the septum removing all deformed bony and cartilaginous parts of the septum and preserving only a caudal and a dorsal strut of cartilage.

There is a greater chance of complications associated with SMR that include bleeding, septal hematoma, septal abscess, perforation, depression of nasal bridge, retraction of columella and persistence of the deviation. Flapping of nasal septum and toxic shock syndrome following SMR can also occur.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a 2-month history of cough and shortness of breath is found to have bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on a chest X-ray. She also complains of dry eyes and nodules in the skin over her arms. Her lymph node biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following findings can be seen in the biopsy of her lesions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a woman with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, a history of cough, dry eyes, nodules in the skin over her arms, and non-caseating granulomas on lymph node biopsy points to a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. In this condition, Schaumann bodies can be seen on biopsy.

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Other options:

Option (A): Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

 

Option (B): Asbestos bodies are seen in asbestosis, which is an occupational disease that causes diffuse fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. These bodies are asbestos fibers covered by iron-containing substances during phagocytosis. Initially, patients will have irregular densities in the lower lobes. The advanced disease will show a honeycomb pattern on a chest x-ray. 

Option (C): Ferruginous bodies are also seen in asbestosis. They are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

An asbestos body can be seen in the image below:
