questions.text: You are a physiologist, studying the microstructure of a skeletal muscle. In the area marked 'x' in the image given below, you are likely to find all of the following, except ______.
questions.solution:
The marked region 'x' is depicting the I-band of the myofibril. It does not contain myosin.

The portion of myofibril that lies between two Z lines is known as the sarcomere. One sarcomere comprises  1 entire A band and 2 half-I bands. 

A band consists of Myosin (thick filaments) surrounded by Actin filaments. I-band comprises thin filaments that contain actin, troponin, and tropomyosin. H zone is the middlemost part of the A band which comprises only myosin heads. During skeletal muscle contraction, A band remains constant. Z lines come closer to each other. H and I bands reduce in their lengths. 

Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.

Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:

  • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that help to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing:
  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the procedure involved in the collection of a sample for a pap smear is 1, 2, 3, 4. 

The Pap/Papanicolaou smear is used for screening cervical neoplasia.

Procedure:

  • The patient is put in a dorsal position & the labia are separated.
  • Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced/posterior vaginal wall retractor is used
  • The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula.
  • Endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  • Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  • The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol.
  • Stained with Pap stain or Short stain.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about psoriasis are correct?
  1. Koebner phenomenon is seen.
  2. It is not exacerbated by lithium.
  3. Guttate psoriasis is the most common type.
  4. Auspitz sign is seen.
  5. Psoriatic arthritis is a complication.
questions.solution:
Among the given options, statements 1, 4, and 5 are correct about psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region.

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause the proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring termed Koebner's phenomenon (statement 1). It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. 

Psoriasis can be exacerbated by medications (statement 2) like lithium, synthetic antimalarials, interferon-alpha, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha. 

The clinical variants of psoriasis include plaque, guttate, pustular, erythrodermic, unstable, and atypical forms. It can also be classified based on the site involved. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis (statement 3). Plaque psoriasis accounts for 80-90% of all cases. 

Scalp psoriasis does not frequently cause alopecia. The scalp is one of the more common areas to be affected by psoriasis and is often affected first. The involvement of the scalp is very variable with widespread plaques or multiple discrete patches. Hair growth is generally unaffected but it can occur.

Removing the psoriatic scales leads to pinpoint bleeding, termed the Auspitz sign (statement 4). 

Psoriasis is treated with PUVA, which is psoralen with ultraviolet light - A (UVA) and NBUVB (narrow band UVB). Systemic drugs can be used in severe cases like methotrexate, retinoids, cyclosporine, and fumarate. 

Complications of psoriasis include secondary infection, poor cosmetic appearance, risk of lymphoma, and psoriatic arthritis (statement 5).

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: A multigravida woman who has an Rh-negative blood group delivered a baby with an Rh-positive blood group. The baby developed mild hemolytic anemia during 1st week of life. This reaction is an example of a___
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic anemia due to Rh incompatibility which is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In type II hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies (rarely IgM) combine with the antigenic determinants on the cell surface activating the complement system. This leads to complement-mediated lysis as seen in the above scenario.

Direct Coombs test is used to detect antibodies (from the mother) that are coated to RBCs. (Indirect Coombs also detects antibodies, but the serum is used as the sample)

Examples of type II hypersensitivity reactions: 

  • Transfusion reactions( ABO and Rh incompatibility)
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Goodpasture Syndrome
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Graves disease
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Pernicious anemia

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with their features:
Disease Feature
1. Spinomuscular atrophy A. Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease
2. Duchenne muscular dystrophy B. Commonly presents in adulthood
3. Becker muscular dystrophy C. Inherited in an autosomal recessive manner
4. Myotonic dystrophy type 2 D. Onset is after 5-7 years of age
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B. 

Disease Feature
Spinomuscular atrophy Inherited in an autosomal recessive manner
Duchenne muscular dystrophy Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease
Becker muscular dystrophy Onset is after 5-7 years of age
Myotonic dystrophy type 2 Commonly presents in adulthood

 

Spinomuscular atrophy is an autosomal recessive disease that results in the degeneration of anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. It presents with proximal muscle weakness and atrophy. There are different clinical variants of this disease with different ages of onset. 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is characterized by progressive weakness, intellectual impairment, calf hypertrophy, connective tissue proliferation, and progressive muscular fibrosis. It is an X-linked recessive disease. It usually presents between the ages of 2-5 years with hypotonia, mildly delayed milestones, pelvic girdle weakness, and Gower's sign (using arms to lift themselves from a seated position). 

Becker muscular dystrophy is also an X-linked recessive condition affecting the same chromosome locus as Duchenne muscular dystrophy. It has similar clinical features, except that it is of a milder and more protracted course. It presents later, after the ages of 5-7 and up to early adulthood. 

Muscular dystrophy type 2 typically manifests in adulthood with a median age of 48 years. It has a variable presentation. It is associated with early-onset cataracts, varying grip myotonia, proximal muscle weakness, hearing loss, and myofascial pain. Childhood myotonic dystrophy (Myotonic dystrophy type 1) presents around age 10. It may be undiagnosed unless there's a known positive family history.

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presents with mild diarrhea for the past 3 days. Today, he developed severe lethargy and an episode of seizures.  Laboratory testing reveals hypoketotic hypoglycemia. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes could produce this kind of test result?
questions.solution:
This child, with lethargy, seizures and hypoketotic hypoglycemia is likely to have medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency. Among the given options, hypoketotic hypoglycemia can be caused only by medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency.

Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency is the most common disorder associated with mitochondrial fatty acid beta-oxidation. It is also one of the most common inborn errors of metabolism. MCAD is an important enzyme involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation. This process is important in the production of ketone bodies as an energy source when blood glucose levels are low.

It is usually diagnosed at birth during routine screening for disorders of the newborn. However, sometimes, it can be detected within the first two years of life. 

These babies present with vomiting that progresses to lethargy and seizures, triggered by mild illness. The common laboratory results seen in these patients result from a failure to synthesize ketone bodies during episodes of hypoglycemia. Hence, the child will present with hypoketotic hypoglycemia. The diagnosis can be confirmed with a combination of biochemical and genetic testing. This illness, once diagnosed can be easily managed with small frequent meals, to avoid a state of hypoglycemia. 

Other options:

Option (B)- Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency can result in phenylketonuria. This is an inborn error of metabolism in which phenylalanine is unable to convert to tyrosine, resulting in the accumulation of phenylalanine. This results in the characteristic 'musty' odor of the urine and body fluids. These children can also present with seizures and hyperactivity. In fact, many of the symptoms result from increased phenylpyruvate (a ketoacid) derived from the buildup of phenylalanine in this condition.

Option (C)- UMP synthase is an enzyme deficiency that results in orotic aciduria. This disorder is an inborn error of pyrimidine metabolism that presents with developmental delay, failure to thrive, and possibly epilepsy. Laboratory testing reveals pancytopenia.  

Option (D)- HMG CoA reductase is an important enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol. This enzyme is targeted by statins, which are prescribed in hypercholesterolemia, and in patients at risk for cardiovascular events. 

Related Pearl: Rothera's Test Procedure

Rothera's test, positive for ketone bodies.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: In a presentation, you are explaining a cycle that depicts the management sequence of sudden disasters. Which step does number 5 in the image represent?
questions.solution:
The number 5 in the image represents preparedness in the disaster management cycle.

The correct sequence is:

1 - Response
2 - Rehabilitation
3 - Reconstruction
4 - Mitigation
5 - Preparedness


Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities. It includes the development of policies or programs for disaster management prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is capable to manage of all future emergencies efficiently.

Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. These measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Disaster mitigation measures are taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures are:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system and complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

The disaster management cycle is given below:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with lethargy, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. A  hematological malignancy was suspected. A peripheral smear showed cells positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase. On flow cytometry, these cells were found to express CD 11c and CD 103. What is the cell of origin of his condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with massive splenomegaly, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase positive cells on his blood smear, and tumor cells with CD11c and CD 103 positive most likely has a diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia. The cell of origin of hairy cell leukemia is the post germinal memory B cell. 


Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. These cells are called so because of the fine hair-like projections on their surface as shown below. On peripheral blood smear, hairy cells have round or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread or bleb like an extension. In the bone marrow, these cells are usually trapped in a mesh of reticulin fibers and so it is difficult to aspirate and hence termed a dry tap. 

The classic hairy cells can be seen in the slide is shown below:

 

The cells in hairy cell leukemia express the usual B-cell markers- CD-19 and 20, but they also express certain more specific markers such as CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1

Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. There can be an atypical monocytopenia due to which these patients experience an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Other options:

Option A: Naive B cell is the cell of origin of mantle cell lymphoma.

Option C: Germinal center B cell is the cell of origin in follicular lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and diffuse large B- cell lymphoma.

Option D: Precursor B cell is the cell of origin of B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding false labor pain.
questions.solution:
Bag of water formation occurs in true labor pain. All others are characteristic changes in false labor pain. 

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema or sedatives No Yes

False labor pain is more in primigravidae than in parous women. Generally, it appears 1 or 2 weeks prior to the onset of true labor pain in primigravidae and by a few days in multiparae.

It occurs due to stretching of the cervix and the lower uterine segment with consequent irritation of the neighboring ganglia.

Note:

Painless Braxton Hicks contractions with simultaneous hardening of the uterus occur throughout pregnancy. These contractions become more powerful, intermittent and are associated with pain terms as labor pain. They are most often felt in front of the abdomen or radiating towards the thighs.

questions.text: An open myomectomy is being performed on a patient. All of the following measures can be used to control bleeding during this surgery except:
questions.solution:
Trendelenburg position (not reverse Trendelenberg) is used to reduce blood loss and improve venous return. 

Measures to control bleeding in Myomectomy:

  • Preoperative treatment with GnRH analogs reduces the vascularity of the tumor and thereby reduces operative blood loss. 
  • Synthetic vasopressin- 20 units diluted in 20 mL of NS is injected into the myometrium overlying the myoma.
  • Victor Bonney’s specially designed clamp is placed at the uterine vessels and the round ligament to reduce uterine artery blood flow.
  • Tourniquets may be used to occlude the uterine and ovarian vessels at the infundibulopelvic ligament. It is tightened just before making the incision for myomectomy.
  • Controlled hypotensive anesthesia (sodium nitroprusside) to reduce venous tone. 
  • A moderate degree of Trendelenburg position enhances venous return and reduces operative blood loss

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for fibroid

Risk factors:

  • Nulliparity
  • Obesity
  • Hyper estrogenic state
  • Black race

Protective factors:

  • Multiparity
  • Smoking

 

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding this class of antibody?
  1. It is most effective in agglutination reactions.
  2. It has a half-life of 5 days.
  3. It is the only heat labile antibody.
  4. Increased levels are seen in a defect of the CD40 ligand.
  5. Involved in vertical transmission from mother to fetus in Rubella.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pentameric immunoglobulin, hence it is an IgM antibody.

IgM antibody is the first antibody released in response to any antigen. It is released in the form of a pentamer and has 10 antigen-binding sites. The half-life of IgM is 5- 7 days. It is a heat-stable antibody. It is the most efficient immunoglobulin in agglutination, complement fixation, and defense against bacteria and viruses. However, it is less effective in the neutralization of toxins and viruses compared to IgG. It does not cross the placenta.

Reaction

IgG

IgM

Neutralization

Strong

Weak

Agglutination

Weak

Strong

Complement fixation

Moderate

Strong

IgE is the only heat-labile antibody.

Clinical correlate:

  • Because of their short half-lives, the presence of IgM antibodies indicates a recent infection.
  • It cannot cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of this antibody indicates intrauterine infection.
  • Hyper IgM syndrome is a syndrome where there are high levels of IgM with very low levels of IgG and IgA. It occurs due to a deficiency of the CD40 ligand. CD40L is expressed on T cells and is required to induce B cells to undergo class-switching from IgM to IgG and IgA. 
 

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells

  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room in a comatose state. He weighs around 70 kg. On examination, his serum glucose levels were found to be 500 mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.33, with increased plasma ketone levels. His serum potassium levels are normal. What is the bolus dose of insulin that should be administered immediately to this patient?

choices.text: 7 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously
7 units of short acting insulin subcutaneously
14 units of short acting insulin intravenously
14 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient is likely to have diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The dose of insulin that should be immediately administered to this patient is 0.1 units per kg. Since the patient weighs around 70 Kg he should be administered 7 units intravenously.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, thirst/polyuria, severe abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. It is precipitated by various events like inadequate insulin administration, infection (pneumonia/UTI/ gastroenteritis/sepsis), infarction (cerebral, coronary, mesenteric, peripheral), drugs (cocaine), and pregnancy.

Clinical signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath (acetone breath)
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250–600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia - there is a 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis.
  • Osmolality – 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones – positive
  • Metabolic acidosis – increased anion gap (HAGMA)
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L – best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

The algorithm for the management of DKA is shown below.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, a shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous haemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text:
A senior resident uses the following system of classification while evaluating a woman, who was diagnosed with maxillary carcinoma. Identify the correct statements regarding this system of classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  1. The lines marked 'A' and 'B' in the image are called Sebileau lines.
  2. The name of this classification is Ohngren classification.
  3. The respiratory part of the nose is included under mesostructure.
  4. The vertical lines in this classification extend down the medial walls of orbit to separate sphenoidal sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.
  5. The suprastructure marked in the image contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lederman’s classification and the correct statements regarding this classification include 1, 3, 5.

Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma and the two horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the above image are called Sebileau lines, one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through the floors of the antrum.

 Sebileau lines divide the area into:

  • Suprastructure: It contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
  • Mesostructure: It has a maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
  • Infrastructure: It contains the alveolar process.

This classification further uses vertical lines, extending down the medial walls of orbit to separate ethmoidal sinuses (not sphenoidal sinuses) and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.


Note:

Ohngren's classification is also used to classify maxillary carcinoma. It includes Ohngren’s line, which is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible.

Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).

questions.text: A 60-year-old asthmatic lady on inhalational bronchodilators presents with shortness of breath. Incidentally, you also notice the outpatient slip to be bearing the same date with an entry in the ophthalmology glaucoma clinic. Which of the possible drugs would have most likely exacerbated her attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals due to its antagonist effect on β2 receptor on bronchial smooth muscles. 

Timolol reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptor which are present on ciliary epithelium.

Timolol is also used for hypertension, congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction,and migraine prophylaxis. In ophthalmology, timolol has been used inthe treatment of open-angle glaucoma and intraocular hypertension. 

Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma & COPD, bradycardia, hypoglycemia, depression, and impotence (Due to non selective β2 receptor blockade).

Other options:

Option B : Betaxolol is a  β1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Options C : Celiprolol is a third-generation selective β1  blocker with weak β2 agnostic action used for hypertension. It is safe in asthmatics. 

Option D : Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2α) analog and safe in patients with bronchial asthma. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A young man comes to the urology department with a chronic history of deformity of the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection.  On examination, there were palpable penile plaques and penile ultrasound showed a thickened area of tissue around tunica albuginea. He has been using the device shown below but is now seeking a permanent solution. What surgical procedure you would recommend for him?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be tried. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as that shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulty in their sexual and personal life because of it. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is. 

The images attached below depict the pathology in Peyronie's disease and the ultrasound finding observed in the disease-

Other options-

Options (A) and (B): Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option (D): Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

Whipple’s Triad

Insulinoma

Symptoms of hypoglycemia + Serum glucose <50 mg/dL + Symptomatic relief on glucose ingestion

questions.text: A 25-year-old, G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL).  Which of the following is not recommended in AMTSL according to WHO?
questions.solution:
Sustained uterine massage is not recommended according to WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping for at least 1-3 minutes. This reduces rates of anemia in infants.
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women

Note: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical.

Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL yet may be recommended by some and to be considered with the warning that evidence for this practice is not strong.

questions.text: In the process of gluconeogenesis, which of the following amino acids does not enter the Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA?
questions.solution:
In the process of gluconeogenesis, phenylalanine is the only amino acid that does not enter Krebs cycle via succinyl CoA. Phenylalanine enters this cycle as fumarate. 

Muscles constitute almost half of our body mass, and hence, amino acids derived from these muscles are a major source of substrate for gluconeogenesis during starvation.

The figure below shows the various points of entry of amino acids into Krebs cycle (tricarboxylic acid cycle). Valine, methionine, and isoleucine all enter in the form of succinyl CoA. 

All gluconeogenic substrates will ultimately form oxaloacetate, as shown below. Oxaloacetate will then undergo the reverse process of glycolysis, resulting in the formation of glucose.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum

questions.text: The given pattern of EEG is found in:
questions.solution:
Periodic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes are seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

It is a spongiform encephalopathy that is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual disturbances. Caused by Prions. It is fatal and death occurs usually within a year or less from the onset.

EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes (bi/triphasic). CSF assay is positive for 14-3-3 protein.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

Option A: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.

Option C: GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)will show high voltage bursts & high voltage spikes present in all the leads.

Option D: HSV encephalitis usually affects one side temporal lobe showing a characteristic periodic lateralised epiletptiform discharge.

questions.text: A woman brings her 8-year-old son with the complaint that the child wakes up at night and walks around the room for about 15 minutes. Any attempt to communicate with him during the episode is unsuccessful. The child is unable to recall the episodes when he wakes up. Identify the brain waves that correspond to the stage of sleep in which this condition occurs.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleepwalking) which occurs during NREM stages 3 and 4 which is represented by high-frequency, slow delta waves. 

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years, and has a familial pattern. It usually resolves after adolescence and is rarely seen in adults. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty. Upon awakening, they do not remember the sleepwalking episode (amnesia).

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road).

Forms of somnambulism include:

  • Sleep-related eating - the individual may ingest food during the episode.
  • Sleep-related sexual behavior (sexsomnia) - the individual may engage in sexual activities during the episode

Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques, and hypnosis may also be helpful.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

Related Pearl: Parasomnias

Disorder

Sleep stage and Characteristics

Nightmares (dream anxiety disorder)

REM

Memory of the event upon awakening

Treatment: Usually no treatment, REM suppressants (TCAs) may be used

Night terror (sleep terror disorder)

Stage 3 and 4

Awakened by a scream or with intense anxiety

No memory of the event the folowing day

Seen more frequently in children

More common in boys

Runs in families

Treatment: Rarely treatment is required. Benzodiazepines can be used

Sleep talking

All stages of sleep

Common in children

Usually, involves a few words

May accompany night terrors and sleepwalking

Treatment: No treatment is necessary

Sleepwalking

(Somnambulism)

Stage 3 and 4

Sequence of behaviors without full of consciousness

May perform perseverative behaviors

Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion

May return to sleep without any memory of the event

Begins at a young age

More common in boys

There may be a neurological condition

Sleep deprivation exacerbates

Treatment: Patient safety has to be ensured.

Benzodiazepines to suppress stage 3 and 4.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with cough, dyspnea, fever, and fatigue. On examination, inspiratory rales are present. A high-resolution CT image is given below. The lung biopsy showed characteristic Masson bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with cough, dyspnoea, fever, HRCT image showing characteristic reversed halo sign, and biopsy showing Masson bodies points to a probable diagnosis of cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) is idiopathic interstitial pneumonia that typically involves elderly patients. It usually presents as mild flu-illness with fever, cough, and dyspnoea. On auscultation, inspiratory rales are usually present.

This disease can be sporadic or can also occur secondary to conditions such as connective tissue disorders (polymyositis) and malignancy.

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the preferred imaging modality of choice. Patchy consolidation with a predominantly subpleural and/or peribronchial distribution is the most common finding. Some cases are associated with ground-glass opacity or crazy paving pattern. The characteristic reverse halo sign or atoll sign is highly specific but is seen in a few cases.


Histologically, COP is characterized by the presence of Masson bodies. These are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles, with foci of fibrosis. There is no interstitial fibrosis or honeycombing of the lung.


Treatment:

Corticosteroids provide substantial remission and are usually required to be continued for at least 6 months to avoid relapses. Cytotoxic (mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide) or biologic (rituximab) therapies can be helpful in both treating the disease and reducing the need for steroids.

Other options: 

Option A: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is the most common form of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia. It is a progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown etiology occurring in adults and is associated with the histological or radiological pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).

HRCT shows a patchy, predominantly peripheral, subpleural and basal reticular pattern. In advanced cases, honeycombing cysts and traction bronchiectasis may be present.

UIP has a poor prognosis and is generally refractive to treatment.

The below CT scan shows interstitial thickening, architectural distortion, honeycombing and bronchiectasis as seen in UIP.


Option B: Non-specific interstitial pneumonia is characterized by bilateral, subpleural, symmetrical ground glass reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. In contrast to UIP, honeycombing is uncommon and has a better prognosis. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis, but not as common as the UIP pattern. Management includes steroids, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, and rituximab with pulmonary rehabilitation.

Option D: Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities. Histologically AIP presents histopathologically as diffuse alveolar damage. It is associated with high mortality.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: An autopsy of a police officer revealed a bullet in the parapharyngeal space. There is a small healed entry wound on the neck. The bullet is surrounded by fibrous tissue and there is no fresh bleeding around it. What is this bullet called?
questions.solution:
This bullet is called a souvenir bullet.

A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on x-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the skull.

Other options - 

Option A - Dumdum bullets are bullets that fragment extensively when they hit an object.

Option B - Tracer bullets leave a visible trace while in flight which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. A small portion in the rear of the bullet is devoid of the core. This space is filled with a flammable chemical compound that is red in color. Flash from the propellant ignites this mixture that causes the bullet to shed red sparks during flight.

The image shows tracer bullets:

 

Option D - Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet) is when two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It occurs when the first bullet has been struck in the barrel, fails to leave, and gets ejected with subsequently fired bullet.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: An elderly tuberculosis patient on treatment is non-compliant to initial therapy. Drug susceptibility showed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid. He was started with the next-line drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis. Which of the following can be the newly given drug?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that inhibits mycobacterial ATP synthesis is bedaquiline.

Bedaquiline targets subunit c of the ATP synthase of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This results in inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

400 mg daily for 2 weeks followed by 200 mg three times a week thereafter is the regimen for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Cycloserine inhibits the alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine. This stops the reactions in which D-alanine is incorporated into mycobacterial bacterial cell wall synthesis. 

Option B: Ethioinamide inhibits mycobacterial growth by inhibiting the activity of the enoyl-ACP reductase of fatty acid synthase II which is an inhA gene product. Isoniazid inhibits the same enzyme. 

Option D: Pretomanid is used in extensively drug-resistant and multi-drug-resistant TB. It inhibits mycolic acids and proteins synthesis of M. tuberculosis and in non-replicating persistent bacilli.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

SLI: Second Line Injectable

questions.text:
Observe the following image and choose the correct statements about the drug X.
  1. It is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase 
  2. Patients with multiple sclerosis who are administered this drug will experience hyperkalemia
  3. Tachycardia is a common cardiac dysrhythmia seen in children
  4. History of malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication to its use
  5. Sugammadex reverses the effect of this drug
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct regarding the above image. The image shows the train-of-four stimulation (TOF). The image shows that following the administration of a muscle relaxant, the amplitude of all four twitches has declined to a similar extent. This is the pattern of depolarizing muscular block, which is seen characteristically in succinylcholine. 

TOF is a pattern of nerve stimulation used to monitor neuromuscular blockade. It consists of four supramaximal stimuli delivered no more than 10 seconds apart. It is calculated by dividing the amplitude of the fourth response by the amplitude of the first response and requires an objective measure of the response to stimulation. The TOF count denotes the number of detectable evoked responses, and it correlates to the degree of neuromuscular block

With depolarizing block, as in SCh, phase 1 will show a decrease in amplitude in all four twitches simultaneously, but no progressive decline in amplitude. If repeated doses or a prolonged infusion is given, phase 2 blockade with progressive decline in amplitude will be seen.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant. It acts by depolarizing the muscle similar to the action of acetylcholine. However, compared to acetylcholine, it acts for a longer duration and causes flaccid paralysis. It has a faster onset and shortest duration. It is administered intravenously. If there is no access to veins, it can also be administered intramuscularly.

It is metabolized by butyrylcholinesterase (also known as pseudocholinesterase or plasma cholinesterase). In patients with deficiency of this enzyme, the recovery from this agent may be delayed.

It is extensively used in the clinical setting for rapid sequence intubation due to its short onset of action

Important side effects of these drugs are malignant hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, fasciculations, bradycardia, and hyperkalemia. Conditions like neuromuscular diseases involving denervation like multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy, stroke, rhabdomyolysis, burns, and pre-existing hyperkalemia can further aggravate hyperkalemia.

Succinylcholine is absolutely contraindicated in patients with a history of malignant hyperthermia. 

Sugammadex does not reverses the effect of succinylcholine.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

Related Pearl: Side effects of succinyl choline

The following are the side effects of succinyl choline:

  • Cardiovascular effects:
    • Sinus bradycardia
    • Junctional rhythms
    • Ventricular dysrhythmias
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Myalgia
  • Masseter spasm: Succinyl choline can trigger malignant hyperthermia
  • Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may lead to an activation of the EEG and slight increases in CBF and ICP in some patients.
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Increased intragastric pressure

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with cutaneous bumps on the hand as shown in the image below. These are pink, painless, and sometimes itchy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is molluscum contagiosum. It can be diagnosed based on the classical pink pearly wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center (umbilicated), not associated with inflammation and necrosis.

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by a poxvirus named Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) which has two main variants, MCV-1 and MCV-2. The virus is oval or brick-shaped. The disease most commonly occurs in early childhood between the age of 2-5 years. 

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. In children, lesions are more often seen on the limbs. In teenagers and young adults, the mode of transmission is usually sexual leading to anogenital lesions. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. The majority of the lesions resolve spontaneously within some months, while some may persist for years.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required. If the lesions are very itchy then they can be treated. Stimulation of the immune response is done using destructive or inflammatory therapies. They include salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, or curettage. Cryotherapy is also effective but needs to be done repeatedly.

Option A- Keratoacanthoma is a rapidly evolving tumor of the skin now classified as a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. It mostly presents as a solitary firm, rounded, reddish-papule with a horny crust. The most frequently affected area is the central part of the face like nose, cheeks, eyelids, and lips.

The below image shows keratocanthoma.

Option B: Epidermoid cysts are made up of keratin and its breakdown products. They are most commonly seen on the face and upper trunk. As they enlarge, they raise the epidermis to white or skin-colored, spherical, a dome‐shaped elevation that is mobile over the deeper structures.

The below image shows sebaceous cyst

Option C: Verruca vulgaris present as firm papules with a rough horny surface. They are most commonly situated on the backs of the hands and fingers but may occur anywhere on the skin. 

The below image shows verruca vulgaris

questions.text: In a patient scheduled for an elective caesarean section, what is the preferred anaesthetic technique used?
questions.solution:
Spinal anaesthesia is preferred over other techniques for an elective cesarean section.

Advantages of spinal anaesthesia over general anaesthesia:

  • Less neonatal exposure to potentially depressant drugs
  • A decreased risk of maternal pulmonary aspiration
  • An awake mother at the birth of her child
  • Spinal opioids can be used for postoperative pain relief

Advantages of spinal anaesthesia over epidural anaesthesia:

  • Rapid and predictable block
  • Complete block (lesser failure rate)
  • Lesser risk of systemic toxicity or high spinal due to accidental intravascular or intrathecal injection seen with epidural anesthesia
  • More cost-effective

Paracervical block is used for labour analgesia, but not for elective cesarean section. Side effects include transient fetal bradycardia, maternal local anaesthetic toxicity, and accidental injection of local anaesthetic into the presenting fetal head.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visited a mining site 2 days ago, after which he had hearing loss for one day. He can now hear properly and on examination, the tympanic membrane looks normal. What is the most likely frequency range of noise that would have caused this?
questions.solution:
The given case suggests a temporary hearing loss, which happened after a specific exposure to noise at a mining site and disappeared after 24 hours. It is usually seen at the frequency range of 4000-6000 Hz.

Effects of noise exposure:

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in the ear occur with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300–500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise that can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text:
Match the following signs with the associated conditions:
Signs  Associated conditions
1. Double target sign a.Laryngocele
2. Bryce's sign     b.Lateral sinus thrombosis
3. Griesinger's sign c.Otosclerosis
4. Steeple sign d.CSF rhinorrhea
5. Schwartze sign e.Acute laryngotracheobronchitis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e, 5-c

Signs Associated conditions
 Double target sign CSF rhinorrhea
 Bryce's sign Laryngocele
 Griesinger's sign Lateral sinus thrombosis
 Steeple sign Acute laryngotracheobronchitis
 Schwartze sign Otosclerosis

Double target sign is seen patients with CSF rhinorrhea. The nasal discharge in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea after head trauma is mixed with blood. When this discharge is collected on a filter paper it shows a double target sign with a central red spot and peripheral lighter halo as seen in the image below. 


Bryce's sign is observed in a case of laryngocele. On application of pressure over the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. 

Griesinger sign is seen in a case of lateral sinus thrombosis. Thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein impedes venous drainage which leads to edema over the mastoid.

Steeple sign is seen in acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup. Edema of the subglottic larynx produces stridor and respiratory distress. A chest X-ray in the PA view will show this sign.


Schwartze sign is associated with active otosclerosis. There is a pink reflex seen through an intact tympanic membrane in the area of the oval window.

questions.text:
Which of the following are considered normal hematological changes during pregnancy?
  1. Raised blood volume
  2. Raised fibrinogen level
  3. Raised albumin: globulin ratio
  4. Raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate
questions.solution:
1, 2, and 4 are correct. The albumin: globulin ratio decreases during pregnancy.

Total plasma protein increases in pregnancy but due to hemodilution, the plasma protein concentration falls. This leads to diminished viscosity of the blood and reduced colloid osmotic tension. 

Due to a marked fall in albumin and a mild rise in globulin, the normal albumin: globulin of 1.7:1 ratio is diminished to 1:1.

There is a progressive, inconsistent marked rise in blood volume during pregnancy. The blood volume starts to increase from the 6th week of gestation and expands to a maximum of 40-50% above the nonpregnant level at 30 -34 weeks.

During pregnancy, due to a disproportionate increase in plasma and RBC volume a state of hemodilution is produced. 

Pregnancy is a state of hypercoagulability. The level of fibrinogen is raised in pregnancy. Due to a rise in fibrinogen, globulin level, and low blood viscosity, there is a fourfold increase in erythrocyte sedimentation rate.
