questions.text: A 24-year-old male athlete presents with shoulder pain after a sports injury.  As part of the clinical examination, you ask him to place one arm behind his back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. You then lift the hand off the back and ask him to hold it in that position. Which muscle does this test specifically test for?
questions.solution:
The test described in the stem is the lift-off test which tests for subscapularis tendon involvement. 

The lift-off test is done for the assessment of subscapularis tendon involvement. Here the patient is asked to stand and place one arm behind their back. The dorsum of the hand should be against the mid-lumbar spine. The examiner should then lift the hand off the back and ask him to hold it in that position. Inability to do this signifies subscapularis muscle weakness. 

Another test that assesses subscapularis tendon involvement is the belly press test. The patient is asked to place his hand on his abdomen and bring the elbow forward. He is then asked to press the hand into their abdomen. Inability to do this with backward movement of the elbow suggests that the subscapularis is torn.

The rotator cuff is formed by four muscles that originate on the scapula and insert on the superior humeral head. Its function is to improve the stability of the shoulder joint, which is a ball and socket joint. Ball and socket joints are extremely mobile but are not very stable. The rotator cuff stabilizes the joint by pulling the head of the humerus into the glenoid socket.  

The following image depicts the rotator cuff. 


The most common cause of pain around the shoulder is due to rotator cuff syndrome which comprises supraspinatus impingement and tendinitis, rotator cuff tears, acute calcific tendinitis, and biceps tendinitis/rupture. 

Patients will present with pain and weakness while performing certain movements of the shoulder. 

Specific tests for isolated weakness can be used to identify the muscle involved. 

Other options: 

Option B - Infraspinatus can be tested via resisted external rotation. The patient stands holding their arms close to the body with their elbows in 90 degrees of flexion. They are then asked to externally rotate both arms while the examiner applies resistance. 

Option C - Supraspinatus can be tested by the empty can test or Jobe's test. The patient is asked to elevate the arms to the scapular plane with the elbow extended and the thumb pointing down. The examiner applies pressure downwards. 

Option D - Teres minor can be tested by the Patte or Hornblower sign. Here, the patient's arm is elevated by the examiner to 90 degrees in the scapular plane and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. They are asked to laterally rotate the shoulder. Weakness or pain indicated teres minor involvement. 

Related Pearl: Important tests and signs to assess the function of rotator cuff muscles

 Drop sign  Seen in the tear in the   infraspinatus and the   posterior part of the   rotator cuff

questions.text:
A 62-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung and is found to have hypercalcemia on laboratory investigation. Which is the most likely mechanism by which he has developed this hypercalcemia?

PTH-rP: Parathyroid hormone-related protein

choices.text: Vitamin D secretion by the tumor
Bone resorption due to skeletal metastasis

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is one of the most common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung. Increased levels of PTH-rP (Parathyroid hormone-related protein) is the most likely mechanism of his hypercalcemia. 
 
Hypercalcemia is a common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with many tumors. This can occur by several mechanisms, the most common ones being the release of PTH-rP and vitamin D. Hypercalcemia due to PTH-rP is very common in squamous cell tumors like that of the lung, breast, and kidney. 
 
Osteolysis due to bony metastasis and cancers like multiple myeloma can also result in hypercalcemia, but this is not considered a paraneoplastic syndrome.
 
It is interesting to note that hypercalcemia is associated with cancer more often than it is with hyperparathyroidism.
 
Other options: 
Option (A): Inhibition of osteoclasts is the mechanism of action of bisphosphonates. These are the first-line drug of choice to treat hypercalcemia associated with malignancy.
 
Option (B): Vitamin D secretion as a paraneoplastic mechanism of hypercalcemia can be seen in some lymphomas. It is not the mechanism seen in SCCs.
 
Option (C): Bone resorption due to skeletal metastasis can cause hypercalcemia. Although bone metastasis can be seen in SCC of the lung, it is not the most likely mechanism of hypercalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient complains that he feels he is no longer in control of his body and thoughts. He says he hears his own thoughts aloud a short time after thinking them, for the last two years. He stopped going to college 6 months ago because he feels everyone can hear his thoughts and know what he is thinking all the time. Examination reveals disorganized speech. He has no history of drug abuse. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of loss of control of body and thoughts, thought broadcasting, disorganized speech and delusions is suggestive of schizophrenia.

The loss of control of the body and thoughts is known as the passivity phenomenon. The patient being able to hear his thought for the last two years is known as thought echo which is a form of auditory hallucination. The feeling that everyone can hear his thoughts is called thought broadcasting which is a disorder of thought process. All these signs point towards the diagnosis of schizophrenia.

Schizophrenia is a disorder comprised of a group of characteristic symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, negative symptoms, disorganized lifestyle, and continuous signs of these disturbances for at least 6 months. 

Dopamine excess is believed to play an important role in the development of the disease. A genetic component is also suspected to be contributory.

The symptoms are mainly divided into positive or negative symptoms. The positive symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, and motor disturbances. The negative symptoms include anhedonia, alogia, flattening of affect, apathy, and poverty of speech.

DSM-5 criteria for schizophrenia:

A. ≥2 of the following symptoms of which at least one of these is either 1, 2, or 3:

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucinations
  3. Disorganized speech
  4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
  5. Negative symptoms

B. Level of functioning in one or more major areas of functioning such as work or social life is markedly below the level it used to be before the onset of the disturbance.

C. Continuous signs of disturbance for at least 6 months.

D. Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out.

E. Disturbance cannot be explained by substance abuse or any other medical condition.

F. If there is a positive history of autism spectrum disorder or a communication disorder since childhood, diagnosis of schizophrenia is made only if the delusions or hallucinations are very prominent.

Anti-psychotics are the mainstay of treatment. They mainly act by antagonizing the postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the brain. Psychosocial therapy also plays an important role and can augment clinical improvement. Some cases may require short stays at the hospital either for patient safety or for stabilization of medications.

There are several factors that affect the prognosis of schizophrenia:

Good prognosis Bad prognosis
Late/acute onset Early/insidious onset
Mood disorder symptoms Withdrawn, autistic behavior
Family history of mood disorders  Family history of schizophrenia
Positive symptoms Negative symptoms
Married Single, divorced or widowed
  Neurological signs and symptoms
  Many relapses

Other options:

Option A- Schizoaffective disorder can be diagnosed when manic or depressive syndrome develops concurrently with major symptoms of schizophrenia. 

Option B- Schizophreniform disorder is described as acute psychiatric symptoms as in schizophrenia that were reactive and occurred in persons with relatively normal personalities that last at least 1 month but less than 6 months. 

Option D- Delusional disorder is characterized by the presence of one or more non-bizarre delusions (false beliefs that are possible but not true) lasting for at least one month. There is no significant impairment in functioning apart from the delusions.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

 

Related Pearl: Symptoms of schizophrenia

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a high fever and abdominal pain for the past 2 days. He has a history of inflammatory bowel disease. His abdominal radiograph is shown below. Identify the true statements regarding his condition.
  1. It is a common complication of Crohn's disease.
  2. It is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon, with a diameter of >6 cm.
  3. It can be triggered by electrolyte abnormalities and narcotics.
  4. Emergency colectomy is indicated in patients in cases of failed medical therapy.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the radiograph showing a dilation of the colon with loss of haustral folds is suggestive of a toxic megacolon. Statements 2, 3, and 4 correspond with the diagnosis of toxic megacolon.

Toxic megacolon is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is a rare complication and is associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. 

It may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Bacterial infection with features of sepsis may also be seen. It can result in perforation. 

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations.

It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy, which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

The clinical features include abdominal pain, diarrhoea, rectal bleeding, tenesmus, and passage of mucus. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss.

Investigations show it elevated C-reactive protein, platelet count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, faecal calprotectin, and faecal lactoferrin. A colonoscopy reveals loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, and ulceration in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Barium contrast enema shows a lead pipe appearance characterised by a smooth-walled colon with complete loss of haustrations.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD:

  • Episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis
  • Erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum
  • Arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis

questions.text: A myasthenia patient came with recurrent urinary tract infections. The urine culture report is positive for Klebsiella with microbial susceptibility to the drugs given below. Which of the following drugs would have the least adverse effect on the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of a myasthenic patient with recurrent UTI due to Klebsiella, gentamicin is the preferred drug among the given options because it has the least effect on neuromuscular blockade.

Aminoglycosides accentuate the neuromuscular blockade by decreasing the pre-junctional release of acetylcholine and reducing post-junctional acetylcholine sensitivity. Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea are seen with the use of aminoglycoside. Patients with myasthenia gravis are susceptible.

Decreasing order of potency for neuromuscular blockade:

  • Neomycin: Highest
  • Kanamycin
  • Amikacin
  • Gentamicin
  • Tobramycin

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction. Reflexes are normal in Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Bulbar weakness
  • Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetric
  • Deep tendon reflexes are preserved

In about 30% of the patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis, and about 10% have thymoma. The thymus normally contains small numbers of myoid cells, stromal cells that express skeletal muscle antigens. In both thymoma and thymic hyperplasia, the normal thymic function is disrupted leading to autoimmunity against ACh receptors expressed on thymic myoid cells. Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.

Ice-pack test - ice pack improves ptosis (decreases the activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft). Edrophonium chloride (Tensilon test) - edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft

Diagnosis is made by AChR antibodies, MuSK antibodies, LRP4 antibodies, single-fiber electromyography, repetitive nerve stimulation. Pyridostigmine, azathioprine, and thymectomy are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is being evaluated for sensorineural hearing loss after an episode of meningitis. The patient is screened for the threshold of hearing using a test that comprises the following waveforms. Which waveform represents the lateral lemniscus?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the waveforms seen in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), and wave V represents the lateral lemniscus.

Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. Stimuli are applied in the form of clicks or tone bursts, which then elicit brainstem responses. Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 minutes. 

  • Wave I by the distal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave II by the proximal part of the vestibulocochlear nerve
  • Wave III by the cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV by superior olivary complex
  • Wave V by lateral lemniscus
  • Waves VI and VII by the inferior colliculus

The first, third, and fifth waves are the most stable and are used in measurements.

Uses of BERA are:

  • As a screening procedure for infants.
  • To determine the threshold of hearing in infants also in children, and adults who do not cooperate and are malingerers.
  • To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumors.
  • To monitor VIII cranial nerve intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuroma to preserve the function of the cochlear nerve.

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: What attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure?
questions.solution:
The sequence CCA attaches at the 3' end of the transfer RNA (tRNA) cloverleaf structure.

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • TΨC loop
  • Variable loop

 

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options-

Option (A): The guanyl cap is not a part of tRNA. it is a molecule of 7-methyl guanosine triphosphate at the 5' end of mRNA. 

Option (B): The anticodon is present at the anticodon loop as shown in the above image. The anticodon is complementary to the codon present on the mRNA strand.

Option (D): The codon refers to sequences of base triplets on the mRNA strand. These codons base pair with the corresponding anticodons on the anticodon arm of the tRNA. This allows the correct amino acid at the 3' end of the tRNA structure to get added to the elongating polypeptide chain.

Related Pearl: Types of RNA

Protein coding RNA

Non Protein coding RNA

mRNA

Ribosomal RNAs (rRNA)

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)

Transfer RNAs (tRNA)

Small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs)

Micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding enzyme kinetics is true?
  1. The Lineweaver-Burke plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors 
  2. Competitive inhibition cannot be overcome by increasing substrate concentration
  3. IC50 is the concentration of an enzyme inhibitor that produces 50% inhibition
  4. Enzymes increase the activation energy barrier for reactions
  5. Noncompetitive inhibitors lower Vmax but do not affect km
questions.solution:
The true statements are: 

Statement 1: The Lineweaver-Burke plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors. Suicide inhibitors of enzymes are those that bind to enzymes and undergo catalysis to produce a substrate that binds to and blocks essential binding sites on the enzyme. It is called suicide inhibition because these substances undergo catalysis themselves to form compounds that can inhibit the enzyme. In this process, they are getting consumed. This plot does not apply to suicide inhibitors because this plot assumes that the enzyme concentration will not decrease during the course of the analysis.

Statement 3: IC50 is the less complex alternative to Ki as a measure of inhibitory potency. It is the concentration of inhibitor that produces 50% inhibition.

Statement 5: It is true that noncompetitive inhibitors lower Vmax but do not affect km.

Vmax- The maximum rate for a particular reaction with a specific enzyme

km- The Michaelis constant km is the substrate concentration at which the velocity of the reaction is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) attainable at a particular concentration of the enzyme

Noncompetitive inhibitors bind to a site on the enzyme that is different from the substrate-binding site. This makes it possible for the substrate to bind to the enzyme even if the inhibitor is also bound to the enzyme. However, this reduces the efficiency of the enzymes. Hence vmax, or the maximum possible attainable speed will be lower with noncompetitive inhibitors. Km, however, which is the substrate concentration at which 50% of Vmax can be obtained will remain the same.

The false statements are:

Statement 2: Competitive inhibition actually can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration. Competitive inhibitors structurally resemble the substrate and so they tend to bind to the same binding site on the enzyme. The enzyme-inhibitor complexes (EIC) reduce the rates of these reactions, so increasing the substrate will reduce the number of EICs and help overcome this inhibition.

Statement 4: Enzymes characteristically lower the activation energy barrier for a reaction. 

Graphs showing the changes in Vmax and Km in competitive and noncompetitive inhibition are given below.

Related Pearl: Difference between Reversible and Irreversible Inhibitors

Reversible Inhibitors

Irreversible Inhibitors

Binds via non-covalent interaction

Binds via covalent interactions

No chemical change

Inhibitor binds to the substrate & prevent catalytic activity of enzymes

Can be reversed, as there is no bonding between the inhibitor & substrate

Irreversibility due to strong covalent bonding

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text:
Match the toxin to its mechanism of action.
Toxin Mechanism of action
1- Diphtheria toxin A- Overactivates adenylate cyclase and increases cAMP
2- Cholera toxin B- Inactivates 60s ribosomal subunit
3- Clostridium perfringens- alpha toxin C- Inactivates elongation factor- EF2
4- Botulinum toxin D- Phospholipase action degrading cell membranes
   E- Inhibits release of neurotransmitter
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-E

Diphtheria toxin acts by inactivating elongation factor- EF2, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis.

Cholera toxin acts by over-activating adenylate cyclase and increasing cAMP which causes increased chloride secretion and water efflux into the gut.

The alpha-toxin of clostridium perfringens acts as a phospholipase (lecithinase C) and causes degradation of cell membranes and results in tissue damage. In the presence of calcium and magnesium ions, this toxin splits lecithin into phosphorylcholine and diglyceride.

Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the production or release of acetylcholine at the synapses and neuromuscular junctions.

Inactivation of the 60s ribosomal subunit is caused by Shiga toxin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S
